On 8/31/06, Parthan <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
> Dev Anand wrote:
> > Hi Chakkardeep ,
> >
> > Well your reply to Girishs suggestions for Projects for students was
> > just a beginning .
> >
> > As soon as some one as fresh as in college gets an idea about the
> > projects , his mind will give him more so that he can find his
> > specialisation and work on that .
> >
> > So going by your words that why re-invent the wheel , I would strongly
> > disagree with you because its not re-inventing the wheel , its finding
> > their way in the new world FS.
> >
> > I was about to start a project after going through the mail of Girish
> > and felt bad after seeing your mail . Its not that motivating , but
> > good to point out the issues but not create a problem in itself.
> >
> > Never mind , these are my humble thoughts , maybe my seniors or pro
> > ILUGC members can share their comments on this too .
> >
> > I would really appreciate if they can shed their valuable suggestions
> > . Expecting them :)
> >
> > Thats it for now ,
>
> Dev,
>
> Sorry that you got demotivated. LUG is always a place where people from
> various backgrounds and ideologies come together, with a similar
> interest rather than calling it single interest. We differ in our
> principles, thoughts, ideologies, philosophies and the way we interpret
> things. So, the chance of flame wars is too high and till now flame wars
> has been an occasional entertainer to many of the luggies. Note
> entertainer doesn't mean that this is for fun, it means we take in a
> positive sense.
>
> LUG is a common place where we share our views and when doing so,
> clashes of interest and ideas do occur. It should be taken in the
> healthy sense, and it has been so far. Otherwise ilugc wouldn't be as
> active as it is now. :)
>
> As far as your motivation is considered, I (though am not a guru or
> expert in any sense, but just an active physical contributor to ilugc)
> will tell you one single advice - Hear what 1000 people say, but do what
> your heart says. Criticism will always haunt you at every part of your
> life, you will hear things which will make you feel the world to be
> ugly, but still if your heart says you can do something then just do it.
> Don't think about the end result, don't get turned down by criticism and
> initial failures. Just keep doing what you feel doing, provided it
> doesn't affect others negatively. Its better to learn by making mistakes
> than being all the way conscious of making none. Every successful man's
> career starts by doing something which they themselves call as "mistake
> I did in my life" and its nothing wrong in doing it.
>
> so, if you are thinking of doing a project just do it and see. Don't
> keep thinking whether it will come out well or not. Trying out is always
> better than thinking out, especially with software ;)
>
> --
> With Regards
>
> Parthan ('technofreak')
> ------------------------------
> Research Assistant @ NRC-FOSS and Python\PHP Developer
> A Proud Tuxian and an Ubuntero
>

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Fri Sep  1 10:03:10 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Fri Sep  1 10:03:21 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Projects for students
In-Reply-To: <12087730608311324i2bf3e335v579351b85ce9ea21@mail.gmail.com>
References: <7938ae610608300117x3d40eb0byd9eeae5c2030cea6@mail.gmail.com>
	<a54a308e0608300149r32c9ee28l1b2431a3dc7a9398@mail.gmail.com>
	<12087730608301606h60c6a9f4m78679d552f4ad07d@mail.gmail.com>
	<44F6471F.5070905@gmail.com>
	<12087730608311324i2bf3e335v579351b85ce9ea21@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7938ae610608312133k3677303cw5915e8e4f6968604@mail.gmail.com>

My humble request to you would be to not analyze things.

Instead try to motivate students thro' positive ideas. If possible
try to throw in some technical tips. I wish to quote this here.

"Nearly everything we do will be insignificant but it is very
important that we do it. "

 -- Mahatma Gandhi

The problem with we seniors is that we only demotivate since
we have seen failures. But young students need motivation.
If you can motivate them, do it. If not it is better to keep quiet.

Please don't misunderstand me. I don't mean to point my finger
at anyone.

I really appreciate Chandradeep's efforts to share his experiences. I
really respect his experience and his efforts to make it known to the
public. It takes a great deal of strength and courage to openly speak
of one's failings.

I would urge more of the seniors to narrate their experiences.
Doesn't matter if it is success or failure. It will help students.
They will figure out what is good for them automatically.

I disagree with Chandradeep as far as my experience goes.
No, I don't mean to say he is wrong, definitely not. Just that my
experience is different.

I recently thought that adding a resume feature to scp would be cool
but that patch was rejected. Since their project goals were different
from what I thought.

At the same time engineers should never reinvent the wheel. But
students should at least do it for some time. Otherwise how do you
learn?

So I wish to vehemently oppose the stance that these projects are all
already done. It is the most demotivating statement one can ever make.
Please please refrain from making such remarks.

If posibble, motivate young people. And help them. Do something real
and practical. If not at least don't demotivate.

This is my humble request to you. Consider me as your brother  and
weigh my words. Please don't get offended.

All of these projects as far as I am concerned have lot of potential
and real life value.

Let me leave the students to decide.

Wish you good luck!  Please don't hesitate to mail me in person or to
the list in case you need further guidance.

regards,
Girish

PS:- I would much appreciate if references to my name stopped. I
neither need praise nor criticism. I just want you to take my words at
face value and evaluate my words. If you like them, take it . If you
don't , reject . Don't associate my name with it. It is a humble
request. This is a community effort, not an individual one. Remember
that we are a team.

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Fri Sep  1 14:31:57 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Fri Sep  1 17:11:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Programmers needed
Message-ID: <1400.61.247.255.57.1157101317.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

Some new job opportunities at Songbird Technologies:

- PHP programmers with excellent understanding of PHP, PEAR, MySQL, PgSQL
etc. Experience working with templating systems such as smarty will be a
definite plus. Must have good communication skills in english (spoken and
written). Experience: 6+ months. Very talented freshers will also be
considered. People with multiple skills (Python/Ruby/Java/C++) will be
given preference.

- Java programmers with excellent understanding of J2EE. Should have
worked on frameworks such as struts/tapestry/myfaces/ADF etc. Should have
worked on hibernate/jdo etc. Experience: 6+ months. People with multiple
skills (Python/Ruby/PHP) will be given preference.

- Business Development - Someone with 3/4 years of experience in the
software industry with experience in sales and marketing; someone with
good deal of interest in and who keeps abreast of developments in software
and technology. Must have very good communication skills in English and
very good written english skills. Your job will involve interacting with
clients to obtain project leaders, writing proposals, negotatiations,
public relations etc.

- QA Professionals - Must have an excellent eye for detail. Must be able
to perform manual and automated testing. Must be able to develop test
plans when presented with the requirement specification. Experience: 6+
months.

Songbird Technologies is a 2.8 years old Chennai-based company with an
office in Anna Nagar. We work with various technologies and have two
streams - web applications and core technologies. We work with clients
from across the globe. We are in the process of setting up our US
presence.

For further details, please visit our website:
http://www.songbirdtech.com


Thank you and regards,
Prem Kurian Philip

Songbird Technologies
http://www.songbirdtech.com

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Fri Sep  1 13:07:56 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)

Subject: [Ilugc] chennailug site update needed
In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f0608311349i321d97a2jbf90f0460c92848a@mail.gmail.com>

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Sep  1 00:47:59 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Sep  1 17:44:27 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Monthly reminder: mailing list guidelines
Message-ID: <20060901074759.2998.qmail@web50207.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

Please don't reply to this e-mail. If you would like
to update it, do it here:

  http://chennailug.org/guidelines

1. Use a proper subject line.

2. Do not troll in the mailing list

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_troll

3. Use [OT] for off-topic, non-technical discussions.
But, don't misuse this to start flame wars or to troll
in the mailing list.

4. Do not top-post:

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Top-posting

Example of a top-post:

Because it messes up the order in which
people normally read text.
> > Why is top-posting
> > such a bad thing?
Top-posting.
> > What is the most
> > annoying thing in e-mail?

Always use bottom-posting.

> What is your name ?
My name is ILUGC.

5. Do not over-quote:

Example of an over-quote:

>>> On Friday you said
>>> blah blah blah
>> On Saturday you said
>> foo foo foo
> On Sunday you said
> foobar

6. Do not post HTML messages

7. Do not recycle messages

8. Do not send attachments

9. Do not attach obnoxious, nonsensical legal
disclaimers. If your company uses disclaimers, don't
use your company ID for the mailing list.

10. Do not reply to a digest. (If you are in digest
mode and want to reply to a post use ILUGC Gmane blog
interface.

Link:
http://blog.gmane.org/gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc

11. Search for answers for your questions/problems in
google.com or any other search engine before posting
your query to the mailing list.

If any of the above are not clear to you, Please read
the detailed list guidelines:

Link:
http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

12. Do not post messages in all capital letters. Mails
in CAPS is considered rude and is similar to shouting
during a conversation.

13. If you or your company is into GNU/Linux
migration, or you want help into GNU/Linux migration,
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/GNU_Linux_migration

14. If you are looking for GNU/Linux distro CDs please
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/CDs_for_Grab

15. Following these guidelines could be helpful
http://people.debian.org/~enrico/dcg/

16. Don't send season's greetings or birthday invites
to the group. Its not mailing list etiquette.

We must use the above guidelines to maintain better
readability, proper archives, efficient bandwidth
usage, etc. 

__________________________________________________
Do You Yahoo!?
Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around 
http://mail.yahoo.com

From blizzard_venkat at yahoo.co.in  Fri Sep  1 06:03:53 2006
From: blizzard_venkat at yahoo.co.in (Venkatraman S)
Date: Fri Sep  1 18:34:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Projects for students
In-Reply-To: <44F64905.4050108@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060901130357.5693.qmail@web8415.mail.in.yahoo.com>



Parthan <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
How many of the so-called college students do innovative projects 
otherwise ?? maybe a 10% ?! And, why people always mean final year 
projects when it comes to the term "doing projects" ? what about the 
earlier 7 semesters ? Do you think that the student is not technically 
mature and capable of doing a projects in the earlier 7 semesters and 
suddenly out of nowhere does one "innovative" project on the last 
semester, when he is already placed in some XYZ company and has no 
further interest in putting up a best performance in the last term ?
If your answer is yes, then he is not a Professional at all and his 4 
years of professional educations attains no meaning.



The problem is not w.r.t the students; its w.r.t the lack of interest on the teacher's(note: i am not calling them profs, as most of the instructors in pvt colleges arent profs and are mere teachers who do not have any specialization in any field) end. I had pathetic experience during my University days, most of the instructors could not even understand a basic Object Recognition System; worst of all the instructor who used to teach me Neural Network couldnt understand the most fundamental of the networks that I had implemented. It is right in here (the VOID) that i expect orgs like ours to chip in. 

We ought to inculcate students about the technologies that are available and how easily accessible they are. LUGgers are doing a great job w.r.t tis objective. I am neither a proponent nor an opposer of FOSS, but i do understand the potential merits that it can bring in to the society.

--vEnkAt
http://blizzardzblogs.blogspot.com

From lv.shankar at gmail.com  Fri Sep  1 20:40:03 2006

Date: Fri Sep  1 20:40:11 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Kubuntu shutdown problems
Message-ID: <72288b670609010810s3062315fh5752c72741294d03@mail.gmail.com>

Firstly, thanks to Prashanth, Shakthi and this group in general...my sound
problem is solved! Thanks again!!

However, I've discovered a another problem. I'm loving it ;)
Kubuntu halts half way through shutting down. It just stops, sometimes
making a flamboyant display on the screen (with a blinking cursor) or says
"Will halt now", which it never does or a blank screen (I think I saw a
cursor).
The same is the case with init 0.
Also there was this delay before it shutdown, I could still click, open
terminal and type something etc. for a few seconds.

Restarting is not a problem.


My specs:
AMD Athlon 64 3000+
Asus A8V UAYKZ mobo, 512 MB RAM, 80 GB SATA HDD.

Looking forward to another learning experience

~LVS
From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Fri Sep  1 20:58:21 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Fri Sep  1 20:58:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] regarding doubt in redhat linux
In-Reply-To: <20060901141454.58717.qmail@web8905.mail.in.yahoo.com>
References: <20060901141454.58717.qmail@web8905.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609010828i40206853hfb85a5e9b5c07dd3@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/1/06, karthik loganathan <karthikrhce@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> I have successfully installed redhat linux 9.0 after
> installing linux shutdown the pc , it shows powerdown,
> it cannot automattically shutting down the pc. what can i do?

You need to install the ACPI "button" module.  As root, run
"modprobe button", failing which run "modprobe acpi_button",
and then call shutdown.  Read your distro's documentation on
how to automatically load the button module.

Here is a Gentoo help document that you may find useful:
http://gentoo-wiki.com/HOWTO_Shutdown_headless_server_when_power-button_pressed


>  I'm expecting your mail or phone immediately.

You are asking for free advice and nobody is obligated to
come to your assistance.  In such a circumstance, it's
good manners to not demand help, but make a polite request.

- Raja
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Sep  1 08:39:26 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Sep  1 21:10:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Projects for students
In-Reply-To: <20060901130357.5693.qmail@web8415.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060901153927.96928.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

My thoughts below:

--- Venkatraman S <blizzard_venkat@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> The problem is not w.r.t the students; its w.r.t the
> lack of interest on the teacher's(note: i am not
> calling them profs, as most of the instructors in
> pvt colleges arent profs and are mere teachers who
> do not have any specialization in any field) end. 

It depends on who blames whom.

It should be more like:

Students: should blame themselves for not learning or
doing anything productive in their four years of
learning, and wasting lot of their precious time
(exceptions are 5-6 students who do *practical*
implementation).

Faculty: should blame themselves for not trying to
learn, or keep themself current with technology,
avoiding inter-departmental politics (and misusing the
students for the same), and helping students in their
*practical* work (exceptions are 2-3 professors who
really motivate their students and help them).

Management: should blame themselves for not providing
sufficient resources/freedom to students, faculty
(there are exceptional management too). 

So, each one should blame themselves and correct
themselves and see what they can really do and show it
proudly as *their work*, irrespective of the odds/pain
 they suffer, and the drawbacks/limitations they face.

It is all about *attitude*.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
> All it shows is that Linux on Desktop is fragmented and as long as it
> stays that way, it will always lag behind Windows. And Ubuntu's
> precious Bug #1 will never close.
>
> Keep up the in-fighting distro's, I'm proud of you.
I don't think Ubuntu's Bug #1 is meant to be serious. With or without 
in-fighting, it's gonna take some time to fix that bug anyway. I'm an 
Ubuntu fan myself, but I sure don't want *only one* distro out there. 
Simply because choice is good. When I get bored of Ubuntu, maybe I'll 
move to Gentoo or FreeBSD (when I'm feeling masochistic) - but I like 
the fact that I have the choice.

Don't worry about Bug #1. Just be thankful that we don't have to worry 
too much about it. Have fun - if they have any sense, they will catch on ;-)


Vamsee.

On 9/1/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Faculty: should blame themselves for not trying to
> learn, or keep themself current with technology,

Faculty should blame themselves for not inspiring the
students and helping them discover their best.  A
teacher/guru's role is to identify raw potential in
students, and mold it in the same way a potter moulds
clay on his wheel.


> Management: should blame themselves for not providing
> sufficient resources/freedom to students, faculty
> (there are exceptional management too).

Management should be questioned about their true intent
for running the institution -- profit or education.
If it's the latter, management should also be asked
what they have done to inspire their faculty and
support them in their quest.


> It is all about *attitude*.

Well said.  It's also about *our* attitude.  Enough
complaining.  I'm glad you/we are acutally doing
something about it.

- Raja

On 9/1/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> > You need to install the ACPI "button" module.  As root, run
>
> Can't remember encountering this guy... is it available in Redhat 9?

The final version of Redhat I used was 4.0!  I'm probably
not best equiped to answer your question.

On my debian boxes that run 2.4/2.6 kernels, enabling this
kernel module allows me to "halt -p" and power off the box.

A good thing for headless servers is that you can also
shutdown by pressing the power button in the front panel.

From sachinpurohit at gmail.com  Sat Sep  2 16:46:38 2006
From: sachinpurohit at gmail.com (Sachin Purohit)
Date: Sat Sep  2 16:48:06 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Commercial] Content Filtering Internet Proxy
Message-ID: <00d101c6ce81$44521190$0801a8c0@oe2000.com>

Dear all,

Since this site is all about sharing Linux based applications, I would like to bring to your attention to an excellent Linux based content filtering Internet proxy software - SafeSquid?. 
SafeSquid? is the first INDIAN software product that is being used around the world (85% of the users are US and UK based). 
It has been developed by Office Efficiencies (India) Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai.

SafeSquid?, arguably, is the world's most feature-rich proxy server. Following, in brief, are it's features - 

  a.. Browser based GUI Interface 
  b.. Cluster friendly 
  c.. A multi-tier, md5-encrypted, totally manageable cache 
  d.. Supports ICP & CARP 
  e.. Request forwarding 
  f.. Transparent Proxying 
  g.. Reverse Proxying - Secure Web Servers 
  h.. Provides simultaneous virus scanning at the gateway using any number of Antivirus softwares of your choice 
  i.. Generate virus signatures on-the-fly for undetected viruses while you wait for updates 
  j.. Ready-to-use connectivity to ICAP Servers, the latest in Antivirus Technology 
  k.. Built-in connectivity to PAM - Authenticate users from ADS, POP3, Radius, MySQL Database, Flat File Database, etc.  
  l.. Bandwidth Management based on Users, Time, Web Sites or a combination of all  
  m.. Block web-sites using URL Blacklist, DNS Blacklist, MySQL Database, Category DNS and the database-independent - Weighed Keyword Scoring Method  
  n.. Filter unwanted contents like ActiveX Controls and Java Scripts from unknown sites (Ads, Banners, Pop-ups, spy wares, etc.)  
  o.. Prevent access / downloads based on MiMe type 
  p.. Prevent users from logging into unwanted sites - Cookie Filter 
  q.. Increase enterprise privacy - Header Filter 
  r.. Prevent access to applications like chat & IM - User Agent based access control 
  s.. Generates log reports in Firewall and Squid format compatible with many open source and paid Log Analysers like Sarg, Calamaris, Squint, Webalizer, Sawmill, SquidTaild, etc.

A FREE version with limited features for non-profit / non-commercial organisations, is available for download at http://downloads.safesquid.net
You need to register on the SafeSquid? Forum (free) at http://www.safesquid.com/html . You can use the forum's username and password to access the download site.Fully functional trial versions, with limited time period, are also available.

On 02/09/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
> Don't know about others, but I don't think this is right. This will
> create a students-community with almost zero-MS knowledge and when
> they go out looking for jobs, they are going to have problems.

Indeed. All students in -schools- are going to use the skills they
learnt in schools (< 10th) when they go out looking for jobs.

What you learn in schools is your foundation for higher education. It
is the path, not the destination. Your argument is akin to arguing
that using hydro-electric power instead of nuclear power to run trains
will cause the trains to run slower. It is a complete non sequitur.

Binand

From siva.ilugc at gmail.com  Sat Sep  2 19:04:38 2006
From: siva.ilugc at gmail.com (Sivasankar Chander)
Date: Sat Sep  2 19:04:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Kerala logs Microsoft out of schools
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610609020559u3a13dd0ax41579315c5b4bbb5@mail.gmail.com>
References: <f6a0291a0609020439g4c1e9c12ve45a6c1f395f9dfc@mail.gmail.com>
	<c293dd340609020539u61a3fda2vbad23930c4bdbdff@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610609020559u3a13dd0ax41579315c5b4bbb5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <a8f990120609020634o2e9ee92aia25d79212b95865e@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/2/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 02/09/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
> >  when
> > they go out looking for jobs, they are going to have problems.
>
> What you learn in schools is your foundation for higher education. It
> is the path, not the destination.

   IMHO, they've done the right thing, for the wrong reasons. They'll
polarize the debate by creating a David-vs.-Goliath analogy, as well
giving an anti-MNC, anti free-market flavour to the debate.

   It's got nothing to do with M$, really. It's basically a question of
the optimal use of public money - IMHO, it is best spent on creating
the conditions that allow a local services industry to flourish. In the
long run, FLOSS is the best choice to allow that to happen.

  If you go the proprietary, packaged route, the bulk of the wealth-
creation will probably not be locally created, but rather at the
location of the shareholders of the vendor - which is likely to be
mostly in the US (there aren't many Indian shareholders in M$,
if any).

    I'm not against globalization, free trade or any of the other
bogey-men - however, I've always got the best deals with the
local merchant next door, even in the US - and never from
mail-order or direct-sales outfits like Dell.

   It almost always pays to enrich the local merchant - he's
likely to spend the money in the neighbourhood. That lowers
the frictional coefficient in the economy by a much larger
amount than by shipping your money out to a faceless
company elsewhere in the world with huge administrative
overheads - your money goes towards subsidizing those
administrative overheads, including executive vacations in
Hawaii, etc.

   It's a no-brainer, and it's got nothing to do with communism.

-Siva

Hi all,

On 9/2/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> On 9/2/06, Vasudevan A <vaslin@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Hi All,
> >
> > Here is an interesting link
> >
> > http://in.rediff.com/money/2006/sep/02microsoft.htm [8]
>
> Don't know about others, but I don't think this is right. This will
> create a students-community with almost zero-MS knowledge and when
> they go out looking for jobs, they are going to have problems.
>
> Pushing students out with FOSS knowledge into an MS world is bound to
> create problems.



I totally agree.A student needs to be educated with every technology out
there. Today, OSS is not in the syllabus, so we should see that Govt. puts
them in, but not by removing M$. Which student will refuse job given to him
in a Big Company here in India ?

Today, many look to get into top 5 companies and unfortunately, they are all
into M$ projects. However, there are also good OSS companies but today
students have no exposure towards OSS since it is not there in their
syllabus.

I would say, If Kerala Govt. is totally removing M$ syllabus from the
curriculum, they are doing a BIG Mistake. Instead,they could include both
OSS and M$ subjects equally.

-Toufeeq

vc++ even in tamil nadu , though we dont use foss :) so even if kerala didnt 
have the policy of complete foss , chances of teaching vc++ is very low .

Well, when one says Windows Programming, you should be geared towards
learning VC++ - the Windows way , which I see many dont. I have taken many
seminars and classes and once I go deep into explaining what MFC generated
code does, they stop me and ask, why to learn those internals!. I am not
sure of other courses and colleges, but when I did my PG at Amrita-CBE, we
had many works done with VC++

Anyway, why to discuss about VC++ here in this list :)

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:

Looks set to be a recipe for disaster :-). No support and people will

that every Uncle has a prodigal nephew who can magically fix (or
reinstall) windows no matter what.

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Sat Sep  2 21:11:33 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Sat Sep  2 21:13:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Kerala logs Microsoft out of schools
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0609020821h7fee61b8v295ac96088411452@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340609020614g6804968fj4ab458f845bee2cf@mail.gmail.com>	<BAY12-F13688D3E42D69C41092D479E3D0@phx.gbl>
	<a54a308e0609020821h7fee61b8v295ac96088411452@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44F9A62D.1090704@gmail.com>

Chakkaradeep C C wrote:
> Hi Antano,
> 
> On 9/2/06, Antano Solar John <solar345@hotmail.com> wrote:
>>
>>
>> anyone who uses linux can learn ms windows in a day , but not the other
>> way
>> round :)
> 
> 
> I dont agree to this. Can you learn VC++ and its technologies in a 
> day!...Oh
> My!..Please dont give statements that are not correct. Like GNU/Linux,
> Microsoft is also strong in its Development Platform. Dont think its too
> easy to master Microsoft Development Platform.I am able to tell this becoz,
> am a Windows Developer as well GNU/Linux enthusiast.
> 
> so doesnt make it a hard deal for the kerala students.
> 
> 
> Well, that you will know when they are exposed to the MS world !

This is a general misconception of new entrants into FOSS. They think, 
we are anti-M$ which is not true to even .1%. We just want them to be a 
bit ethical by not using Windows w/o paying for them. If they are going 
to get a legal copy, who raises objection. And, additionally our second 
proposal which leads to this miss conception is "why buy a proprietary 
software when a free software is available". And they take this to be 
anti-XXXX somehow. I have observed this in many people, esp students who 
are just getting to know about FOSS and GNU/Linux and who start thinking 
anti-M$ is a way to become a true tuxian or a FOSSian. This makes pro-M$ 
people, to take the exact opposite and start bashing FOSS. Only, when 
this misconception is ended and both M$ and FOSS are put on an equal 
arena to play their own games and compete in an healthy way, we will see 
a more healthier software environment around us and will be spending 
better of our time for things other than flaming ourselves.

-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.
Research Engineer, NRCFOSS
A Proud Ubuntero and Linuxian

Hello guyz,

The session started around 10:25. Mr. Antano Solar John started with LAMP
archeitecture, Basic coding structure, with Programming Logic and technique.
We had a break at around 11:30. In the tea break  Solar was shining :) in
PHP filled the  corridor.He took the audience till login page and induced
them to do a tiny project. He covered basic commands in mysql, and  the php
code to interact with the mysql. I was on and off the session. Good work
John.

The  gemini pair of  ILUGc  Srini and Balavignesh arrived in between the
"PHP" session.
Srini explained the job possiblities in the lamp arena. While Bala took the
show explaining the SERVER-CLIENT conversation with  lay man examples.
Impressive stuff Bala.

Srini and bala was interacting with the students at the fag end of  LAMP
session. we had lunch around 1:30 and we gathered for Hands on session on
php by 2:00pm. Srini and Bala continued with the hands on session installing
xampp in 5 machines and started with PHP coding. By now students finished
the "Hello world".while srini made a demo on making a form with few
variables.

Mr.R.Subramanium joined the party around 3:00pm.R.S added feather to the
hat.
He started the talk with the need of "Tech Knowledge", "Inter personal
interaction","G.k" ,"Common sense" and "personality". He addressed the need
of presenting a  content rich biodata with some correction to a sample
resume got from one of the aspirant.

In between Luggies, Raja Talks on web technologies  by tommorrow 10:00 am to
1:00 pm. All of the luggies are invited. We are going to have the php
hands-on on 3rd sept  by 2:00 pm to 5:00pm .The resumes which are fetched
from the session attendes , can it be kept in our site www.chennailug.org
for any job prospects?.

This day is an excellent day with satisfaction to cheer about.

Regards

Thyagarajan Shanmugham

The most desirable things in life is "Love","Peace" and "Freedom" are
attained by giving them to some one else- Anon
From trshash84 at gmail.com  Sun Sep  3 00:01:17 2006
From: trshash84 at gmail.com (T.R.Shashwath)
Date: Sun Sep  3 00:01:33 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Kerala logs Microsoft out of schools
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0609020832s18947c1bme72398c3bbe72805@mail.gmail.com>
References: <a54a308e0609020821h7fee61b8v295ac96088411452@mail.gmail.com>
	<BAY12-F145F05F7BC6335295FAEE29E3D0@phx.gbl>
	<a54a308e0609020832s18947c1bme72398c3bbe72805@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200609030001.18121.trshash84@gmail.com>

On Saturday 02 September 2006 21:02, Chakkaradeep C C wrote:
> Well, when one says Windows Programming, you should be geared towards
> learning VC++ - the Windows way , which I see many dont. I have taken many
> seminars and classes and once I go deep into explaining what MFC generated
> code does, they stop me and ask, why to learn those internals!. I am not
> sure of other courses and colleges, but when I did my PG at Amrita-CBE, we
> had many works done with VC++

I for one disagree with that. I learnt most of my programming under DOS and 
then with Linux, but I was able to get into both VC++ and VC# with very 
little effort. As long as you keep in mind that it's just a toolkit and a 
different compiler, you're fine.

Anyway, we have Qt and GTK for windows, which are both much nicer than MFC, 
and .Net's toolkit is quite good (and self-explanatory) too. I don't see much 
of a problem in learning to program under one OS or the other, except maybe 
some details with the IDE's UI. Even that's easy to get around...

Shash
-- 
"Where shall  I  begin, please your Majesty ?" he asked.
"Begin at the beginning,", the King said, very gravely, 
"and go on till you come to the end: then stop."

From binand at gmail.com  Sun Sep  3 01:45:42 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Sep  3 05:15:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Kerala logs Microsoft out of schools
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0609020818oa8a2183h74c6078c81008a09@mail.gmail.com>
References: <f6a0291a0609020439g4c1e9c12ve45a6c1f395f9dfc@mail.gmail.com>
	<c293dd340609020539u61a3fda2vbad23930c4bdbdff@mail.gmail.com>
	<a54a308e0609020818oa8a2183h74c6078c81008a09@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609021645ta26ba45re27c12dae03ca85f@mail.gmail.com>

On 02/09/06, Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote:
> I totally agree.A student needs to be educated with every technology out
> there. Today, OSS is not in the syllabus, so we should see that Govt. puts
> them in, but not by removing M$. Which student will refuse job given to him
> in a Big Company here in India ?

Can you tell me ONE company in India or elsewhere that employs a
person SOLELY on the basis of what he/she learnt in his/her < 10th "IT
@school" class?

> I would say, If Kerala Govt. is totally removing M$ syllabus from the
> curriculum, they are doing a BIG Mistake. Instead,they could include both
> OSS and M$ subjects equally.

I think people here are assuming this IT @school to be something that
teaches kids programming, web development, what not. It is not. It is
just a few fundamentals of computers - check, for example, one
question paraphrased from last year's (2006) public examination:

- Create a new document. Save it with a given name in a location specified.
- Enter some text into the document. Run the spellchecker.
- Mark certain sections of this text in bold, some other sections in italics
- etc...

I really don't understand what the hullabaloo is if the government
decides that the kids can do all this very well in OO.o on Linux. How
does this make the kid unemployable?

In my mind, the computers in schools for sub-tenth kids serve a
similar function as the "instrument box" or graph paper - it is just a
tool to teach the kids the basic principles - foundation stones for
his/her higher education, the real education that prepares him/her for
professional life. Does the fact that a kid uses a particular brand of
instrument box improve his understanding of the concepts behind
"bisect an angle using a straight-edge and compass"? It doesn't.
Similarly, it doesn't really matter to the kid or the school whether
he used Firefox or IE to look up a piece of information on Wikipedia -
what matters is that the kid has access to Wikipedia from his/her
school. The goverment(s) of Kerala needs to be lauded for initiating
an IT @school project - and while doing that, if they went for cutting
costs by choosing Free Software instead of expensive commercial
alternatives, then so be it.

Binand

From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Sun Sep  3 13:29:37 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)
Date: Sun Sep  3 13:29:48 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Drivers on 64 bit PC
In-Reply-To: <9acfbb0b0609021942n36716c06pfe08d6837a13da4@mail.gmail.com>
References: <9acfbb0b0609021942n36716c06pfe08d6837a13da4@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310609030059t1cb87bfdt585bed9e265f8adb@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/3/06, Adithya Narayanan <adi2d2@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi guys,
>
> I'm going to buy a 64 bit PC. I've Ubuntu 6.06 64 bit OS with me.
> Is it wise to run 64 bit OS on 64 bit PC. I read in an article that 64 bit
> Drivers are scanty and are hard to find. Even giants like Logitech and
> Creative are not providing 64bit driver.

Before installing a 64 bit OS make sure all the application you need
(eg. OO, java, flash, ...) are available as 64 bit ports otherwise you
have extra work to make them work.
There shouldn't be problem with the opensource drivers - mainly the
one already in the kernel tree, but you can expect some problems in
finding closed source drivers.

> Next, is it possible to run a 32 bit OS on this 64 bit PC.

Ofcourse it is possible. it is even possible to run a 32 bit
application in a 64 bit OS.

> Finally, recommend me between AMD 64 and Intel Dual Core.

If my understanding is right, Dual core should offer a better performance.

--
Warm Regards,
Vijairaj

From: priya0207 at rediffmail.com (priya sridhar)
Date: Sun Sep  3 17:18:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] threads
Message-ID: <20060903114543.20620.qmail@plus2.rediffmail.com>

 ?
hi all,
can u please tell me the difference between nptl and linux threads and which version of linux supports kernel threads?
From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Sun Sep  3 17:33:52 2006
From: toufeeqh at gmail.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Sun Sep  3 17:34:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] threads
In-Reply-To: <20060903114543.20620.qmail@plus2.rediffmail.com>
References: <20060903114543.20620.qmail@plus2.rediffmail.com>
Message-ID: <c293dd340609030503s32947901ya2ff963425e0ffb@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 3 Sep 2006 11:45:43 -0000, priya sridhar <priya0207@rediffmail.com> wrote:
>
> hi all,
> can u please tell me the difference between nptl and linux threads and which version of linux supports kernel threads?

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_POSIX_Thread_Library
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LinuxThreads

And this:
http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-threading.html?ca=dgr-lnxw07LinuxThreadsAndNPTL

Just use any version of the 2.6.X kernel and you should be safe w.r.t threading.

Also, consider using Google and Wikipedia before asking questions on
the list. Most of the answers you seek are available on
Google/Wikipedia.

-Toufeeq
-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net

Hello
   
  I am running a dual procs opteron 242 64 bit built from the slackware 10.2 AMD64 distro, SCSI hdd with adaptec scsi card and its fine. I just made sure that the hardware I had were all supported by seeing from linuxquestions.org : forum -> linux hardware.

Creative are not providing 64bit driver.

Finally, recommend me between AMD 64 and Intel Dual Core.

> 2. LDD info
> 3. Open source participations list

My ideas, we can have something like this..

* Past events by ilugc - under the categories of LDDs, GLVs, Intro talks 
and topic specific seminars. GLV list might be linked to appropriate 
additional resources if possible the slides and materials used by the 
speaker for the same
* Forthcoming events - events which have been fixed and going to take 
place in the near future.
* Proposed events which are under planning and discussion.
* Speakers Info, who can talk on what ?
* Physical Volunteers list, a list of luggies who are/will be able to 
volunteer physically for ilugc events ;)

And also, a special this weekend banner or a sticky somewhere will help 
to find out whats happening the coming weekend, either LDD, GLV or some 
other meets.

Instead of using the chennailug.org for posting resumes, it would be a 
better idea to open up a google-group and use it for the purpose. The 
link for the same can be given in our chennailug.org site instead of 
using our site for such purposes. If you start putting resumes on our 
site, hundreds of resumes will come and we will rather become an 
employment portal than a LUG :D

Note: The above statement is my humble opinion, there is every 
possibility that this might lead to arguments, counter-arguments and 
flames... am a bit afraid of fire! ;)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.
Research Engineer, NRCFOSS
A Proud Ubuntero and Linuxian
[http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com]
From rajaramcomputers at hotmail.com  Mon Sep  4 03:27:12 2006
From: rajaramcomputers at hotmail.com (ramkumar lakshminarayanan)
Date: Mon Sep  4 08:57:27 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] SFD-2006 - Mahadanapuram.
Message-ID: <BAY116-F133B544EA55CF2EC11198DD330@phx.gbl>

   Dear All,
   A team of us has planned to celebrated SFD 2006 in our village
   Mahadanapuram. The Leading Educationalist of South India Dr. Meena,
   Principal, HOD. Department of Computer Science of Indira Gandhi College,
   Trichy has accepted to give lecture and preside over the function on
   September 16, 2006.
   We have started conducting computer awareness programme in the following
   schools,
   1. Government High School, Thitamplayam, Mahadanapuram.
   2. Government High School, Mettumahadanapuram, Mahadanapuram
   3. Government Higher Secondary School, Sithalavai, Karur District
   4. Government Higher Secondary School, Lalapet, Karur District.
   .. We are having discussion with more schools.
   At the same time we are having discussion with Colleges to form Computer
   Literary Association and to conduct a group discussion about "Importance
   of Software Freedom".
   We have planned to put banner in all the places in tamil. Sample banner is
   posted in the following link
    
   http://www.softwarefreedomday.org/Artwork/Logo?action=AttachFile&do=view&target=SFD-2006-rajaram-tamil.png
    
   Please share your suggestions.
    
   This our small effort.If any of you in and around trichy want to share
   your thoughts and give guidance, you all are always welcome.
    
   Regards,
   L.Ramkumar
From rajaramcomputers at hotmail.com  Mon Sep  4 03:35:09 2006
From: rajaramcomputers at hotmail.com (ramkumar lakshminarayanan)
Date: Mon Sep  4 09:05:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Job Posting in ChennaiLUG
Message-ID: <BAY116-F37BE1993353C6B9B8EB161DD330@phx.gbl>

   Hai All,
   Regarding job postings, companies are expecting persons with good skills.
   The Subject of arguments started with the resume we got  through
   SESSION ON EMPLOYMENT EMPOWERMENT INIT INDUSTRY THROUGH FLOSS
   Instead of planning for posting resumes and handling. We can post articles
   (discussion) related to the expectation of companies with FLOSS
   background. A team list who are interested to guide for beginners can be
   formed.
   This will help the freshers to understand the area and get into a right
   job.
   Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.
   Regards,
   L.Ramkumar

ramkumar lakshminarayanan wrote:
>   Dear All,
>   A team of us has planned to celebrated SFD 2006 in our village

>   1. Government High School, Thitamplayam, Mahadanapuram.

>   3. Government Higher Secondary School, Sithalavai, Karur District
>   4. Government Higher Secondary School, Lalapet, Karur District.
>   .. We are having discussion with more schools.
>   At the same time we are having discussion with Colleges to form Computer
>   Literary Association and to conduct a group discussion about "Importance
>   of Software Freedom".

Surprising and really appreciable effort. If you wish some one from 
ilugc (Chennai members) can join with you, so we get acquainted with 
contacts around Trichy for planning further endeavors ?!

My ideas,

* Distribute Edubuntu CDS a few per school and show the students how to 
play around. This will create interests in them to start innovative 
learning.
* Teach them how to install and use GNU/Linux for their day to day 
activities, and help them adopt GNU/Linux into their lives.
* Get to know real-time needs of softwares which can be taken up as a 
project by students and developed as a FOSS solution. Thus, students 
will get a chance to work on something useful and applicable in real 
life and also, the need for a free software solution gets fulfilled.
* Try to avoid anti-XYZ propaganda, but stick to creating awareness 
about FLOSS. Generally, people presume that we are against something 
instead of understanding that we are showing them a better and parallel 
solution.

>   We have planned to put banner in all the places in tamil. Sample 
> banner is
>   posted in the following link
>      
> http://www.softwarefreedomday.org/Artwork/Logo?action=AttachFile&do=view&target=SFD-2006-rajaram-tamil.png 
> 
>      Please share your suggestions.
>      This our small effort.If any of you in and around trichy want to share
>   your thoughts and give guidance, you all are always welcome.
  Big things start small. Its not how you start that determines the end 
result, its how you perform, how you transform your ideas into action. 
Hope you do put up a good show :) Good Luck!!

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Mon Sep  4 09:32:17 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Mon Sep  4 09:34:41 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Job Posting in ChennaiLUG
In-Reply-To: <BAY116-F37BE1993353C6B9B8EB161DD330@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY116-F37BE1993353C6B9B8EB161DD330@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <44FBA549.6000702@gmail.com>

ramkumar lakshminarayanan wrote:
>   Hai All,
>   Regarding job postings, companies are expecting persons with good skills.
>   The Subject of arguments started with the resume we got  through
>   SESSION ON EMPLOYMENT EMPOWERMENT INIT INDUSTRY THROUGH FLOSS
>   Instead of planning for posting resumes and handling. We can post 
> articles
>   (discussion) related to the expectation of companies with FLOSS
>   background. A team list who are interested to guide for beginners can be
>   formed.
>   This will help the freshers to understand the area and get into a right
>   job.
>   Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.

IMHO, FLOSS should be <em>just considered</em> as another technology or 
opportunity for employment. It should be something similar to "I learn 
Java/.NET/ASP, I get a decent Job". I still remember a few years back, 
when I was at my high school, a lot of people rushed towards Oracle, 
then sometime later towards Java, then towards .NET. This shouldn't be a 
trend repeating with Open Source.

Students/Freshers should not just take up a career in Open Source just 
because they get a Job. I don't mean that "Job" is not a/the way to get 
people into FOSS, but it shouldn't be the foremost reason. They should 
understand and appreciate the philosophies and ideologies of FLOSS and 
then make a decision whether it is good for them.

Thus emphasis should be on letting them be aware of FLOSS, know at least 
a few of the nook-and-corners and then let them decide what they are 
going to pursue depending upon their interest.

"Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime." - Yes this is 
what the max we can do. Its up to them, whether they fish a shark or a 
snail! ;) Community can only share your weights, not carry your weights 
for you :)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.
Research Engineer, NRCFOSS
A Proud Ubuntero and Linuxian
[http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com]

  learnt in schools (< 10th) when they go out looking for jobs. 
 
 What you learn in schools is your foundation for higher education. It

 --------
 Precisely. to the extent that, i still use a "i" as the index variable in a for loop. that tells us something else. 
 
 Why is linux considered not-so-user-friendly? One argument is that people started seeing windows on their machines and then came linux. Windows set the path. for some of us, the destination tends to linux. for most of others, their work will be on windows. I am confident that most corporates won't shift already to linux. So, they better know where the start button is or what File->save can do for them! Or the path to destination could just be frustration. Actually, there must be a mix of both. They shouldn't neglect any. Isn't that how we study. I did some "biology" in school, then that was never any destination for me!!

Dear Luggies,
On 3rd Sep 06, NRCFOSS has arranged for a Seminar on FOSS to
M.Sc-bioinformatics students. Me and Parthan conducted which covered
installation, basic gui, some intro to command line,shell script and
perl.

The students were enthusiastic. This is the first college (in my
experience), where faculty sat through entire day and actively
participated.

On behalf of ILUGC I thank College Management,HOD Dr.Ordetta and
faculty and NRCFOSS for the opportunity.

Raman.P

Hi murugan,

The default web server comes with redhat 9 does not support JSP. You
need to install apache tomcat for running servlets and JSP.
On 9/4/06, murugan m <mmuruga@gmail.com> wrote:

From vpadarsh at gmail.com  Mon Sep  4 09:44:25 2006
From: vpadarsh at gmail.com (~adarsh~)
Date: Mon Sep  4 11:14:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] doubt to run jsp
In-Reply-To: <47b442230609032235g345c3c12x58e8dd4a4f072679@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/4/06, murugan m <mmuruga@gmail.com> wrote:
> I want to know What I should do
>  to run jsp (java server pages).
> My pc is running on Redhat linux 9
> and I use the web server apache.
> When I run following program
> <html>
> <body>
> murugan <br>
> <% out.println("jsp program"); %>
> </body>
> </html>
> the output was only "murugan".
> I want to know jsp statement was ignored.
apache webserver dont have a servlet/JSP engine to parse the jsp files.
You need to install a servlet/JSP container like Apache Tomcat to run
java/jsp files.

> Pleae help.
> My thanks in advance.

From ksankar_hello at yahoo.com  Mon Sep  4 03:07:23 2006
From: ksankar_hello at yahoo.com (Sankar K)
Date: Mon Sep  4 15:37:29 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] <Help> Ubuntu Password
In-Reply-To: <20060904093024.53569.qmail@web30808.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060904100723.24190.qmail@web32814.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

hi,

The Live disk is not for general use, however. There is no password protection for any system functions. So with the Live disk running, you can do anything, up to and including a full disk format. Ubuntu Live makes an excellent introduction, and is a very useful disk to have around if you want to use Linux on an unfamiliar machine (as long as the owner trusts you).

Unlike all the other Linux distros we have tried, Ubuntu does not ask you to set a root password during the install process. It actually, we are told, sets up a root user with a random password, that's never intended to be used. It then lets the first user have admin privileges, prompting for the password and performing actions through sudo ('superuser do') a Linux feature by which users can be allowed to operate with root privileges.

for example if you are goint to mount some partation.
simply type in sudo before the command such as sudo mount...

or do it this way:

$ sudo su

ten you'll be getting root previlagies. 

With Regards,
Sankar.K

From stylesen at gmail.com  Mon Sep  4 16:08:32 2006
From: stylesen at gmail.com (Senthil Kumaran S)
Date: Mon Sep  4 16:08:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] <Help> Ubuntu Password
In-Reply-To: <20060904100723.24190.qmail@web32814.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20060904093024.53569.qmail@web30808.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
	<20060904100723.24190.qmail@web32814.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <5ef2113c0609040338r3e088431wcf1014c26f5448ae@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/4/06, Sankar K <ksankar_hello@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Unlike all the other Linux distros we have tried, Ubuntu does not ask you to set a root password during the install process. It actually, we are told, sets up a root user with a random password, that's never intended to be used.

In order to login as root inside a Ubuntu system you can change the
password of the root user by following steps:
1) Login as the first user you have created during installation
2) Issue the following command
    $ sudo passwd su
3) Enter a new password for the root user
4) Logout
5) Login as root with the password you have just changed

HTH

--

Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding Installation of Linux

Dear Luggies,

I am trying to install linux in a machine which has the following
configuration:

Pentium 4 3.06 Ghz 

512 Mb Ram

80 Gb Sata Hard disk

ATI RADEON XPRESS 200 Display Adapter.

When I try installing FC 5 on this machine the screen gets filled up
with colour grains. This happens when the graphical interface for the
installation starts.

I tried installing Red Hat 9 it gave a message saying no hard drives
found in the machine.

What could be the problem

Thanks and Regards

From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Mon Sep  4 22:07:58 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)

Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding Installation of Linux
In-Reply-To: <44fc0c76.359c112d.013f.5ca4@mx.gmail.com>
References: <44fc0c76.359c112d.013f.5ca4@mx.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310609040937xfebed6fsfe77f352291c6786@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/4/06, Vinayak Mahadevan <vinayak.mahadevan@gmail.com> wrote:
> Dear Luggies,
>
> I am trying to install linux in a machine which has the following
> configuration:
[...]
> When I try installing FC 5 on this machine the screen gets filled up
> with colour grains. This happens when the graphical interface for the
> installation starts.

Try ctrl alt + or ctrl alt - to switch between different mode.

> I tried installing Red Hat 9 it gave a message saying no hard drives
> found in the machine.

You need a 2.6 kernel to detect your _SATA_ hard disk.

--
Warm Regards,
Vijairaj

From devafree at yahoo.com  Mon Sep  4 19:57:05 2006
From: devafree at yahoo.com (deva free)
Date: Tue Sep  5 08:27:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding Installation of Linux 
In-Reply-To: <44fc0c76.359c112d.013f.5ca4@mx.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060905025705.1994.qmail@web50807.mail.yahoo.com>

Dear Vinayak,
  What are the conf for the xorg conf file? The video card can best be changed, see http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/showthread.php?t=480441 for a similar bad experience with this card. You can also follow this thread to see if it gets resolved, it already did partially by getting up a 2d display rather than a 3-d.So, you can install perhaps in text mode and then edit the x conf.
  Reg hard drives not found , maybe you had it searching for IDE HDD instead of SATA. Also , further you can try reformatting from the end of free space rather than the start of free space, sometimes that may sort out HDD install troubles.
  Warm Regards
  Mahadevan


Vinayak Mahadevan <vinayak.mahadevan@gmail.com> wrote:

Dear Vinayak,
  The Red Hat 9 will not detect if the bios has your drive as SATA- raid , which is probably the case. Can't you try RHE instead or I generally use slackware, with wchich I usually have no probs ata all. Sorry for the incorrect input last mail.
  Regads
  Mahadevan

On 9/5/06, Natarajan V <rajanvn@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 9/4/06, murugan m <mmuruga@gmail.com> wrote:
> > I want to know What I should do
> >  to run jsp (java server pages).
> > My pc is running on Redhat linux 9
> > and I use the web server apache.
>
> You need a Java Web Application Server.
> The most favourite ones in the opensource market are
> 1. Apache TomCat (http://tomcat.apache.org/)
> 2. JBOSS (jboss.org)
> 3. IBM WebSphere WebAppilcation Server Community Edition
> (http://sourceforge.net/powerbar/websphere/ind/)

4. Sun Java System Application Server Platform Edition 9.0
(http://www.sun.com/software/products/appsrvr_pe/index.xml)
From rajanvn at gmail.com  Tue Sep  5 09:05:41 2006
From: rajanvn at gmail.com (Natarajan V)
Date: Tue Sep  5 09:21:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] doubt to run jsp
In-Reply-To: <47b442230609032235g345c3c12x58e8dd4a4f072679@mail.gmail.com>
References: <47b442230609032235g345c3c12x58e8dd4a4f072679@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <e977d4310609042035i2b8d6dafq92ad8d6528ea71c9@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/4/06, murugan m <mmuruga@gmail.com> wrote:
> I want to know What I should do
>  to run jsp (java server pages).
> My pc is running on Redhat linux 9
> and I use the web server apache.

You need a Java Web Application Server.
The most favourite ones in the opensource market are
1. Apache TomCat (http://tomcat.apache.org/)
2. JBOSS (jboss.org)
3. IBM WebSphere WebAppilcation Server Community Edition
(http://sourceforge.net/powerbar/websphere/ind/)

If you have a lot of $$$, u can choose IBM WebSpehre (Advanced
Server), BEA WebLogic, Oracle Application Server and so on....

Cheers,
Natarajan

Natarajan V wrote:
> You need a Java Web Application Server.
> The most favourite ones in the opensource market are
> 1. Apache TomCat (http://tomcat.apache.org/)
+1
> 2. JBOSS (jboss.org)
More bloated than Hindenburg. Forget it.

> 3. IBM WebSphere WebAppilcation Server Community Edition
> (http://sourceforge.net/powerbar/websphere/ind/)
>
A more recent effort. IBM essentially added some bells and whistles to 
the open source Geronimo project. Haven't tried this one.

> If you have a lot of $$$, u can choose IBM WebSpehre (Advanced
> Server), BEA WebLogic, Oracle Application Server and so on....
>
Unless you have really sophisticated needs like supporting thousands of 
users, load balancing and need professional support, don't go there. 
However, there are some really nice open source java app servers apart 
from Tomcat like Caucho Resin, JOnAS. You can't go wrong with Tomcat, 
but you can take a look at these options too.


Vamsee.

> Unless you have really sophisticated needs like supporting thousands of
> users, load balancing and need professional support, don't go there.
> However, there are some really nice open source java app servers apart
> from Tomcat like Caucho Resin, JOnAS. You can't go wrong with Tomcat,
> but you can take a look at these options too.

I have seen an implementation supporting about a lakh users, atleast a
few thousand concurrently online, using TOMCAT :-). You can ofcourse
keep adding plugins and external load balancers and take care of
things yourself, and use it to handle such huge stuffs..... But no
EJBs on Tomcat......

If you are on a learning spree... Go For TOMCAT. This is the reference
implementation for all other servers in the market, meaning, if it
works on TOMCAT, it has to work on all other servers.
From vamlists at gmail.com  Tue Sep  5 11:12:33 2006

On 9/5/06, Vamsee Kanakala <vamlists@gmail.com> wrote:
> Huh? Rational Rose is a UML design/code generation tool. Sure, it costs
> a lot, but it's got nothing to do with app servers.

Now-a-days, IBM has integrated Rational Suite with Eclipse and has
made a RAD tool. You can draw the UML, generate the code, create
sequence diagrams by running the code, integrate with WebSphere,
profile the code, and so on..... But still Rational is not a server,
it is only a UML/RAD tool. (and a good one too.)

From tshrinivasan at gmail.com  Tue Sep  5 21:42:23 2006
From: tshrinivasan at gmail.com (Shrinivasan T)
Date: Tue Sep  5 21:42:34 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Huawei Relience card Worked in opensuse10.1
Message-ID: <dd680c2b0609050912n1af12874pa3864e9f7d4a106d@mail.gmail.com>

Friends.

Today, I tried Huawei relience card with Opensuse 10.1
at asan(saravanan)'s laptop.

Accedently got this link,
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/ilug-mangalore/message/3115

I followed it.
But there is no pppconfig.
Kppp also died.

So, tried with wv-dial.
Wow. It worked well.
(Hope sudharsan will glad to hear this  :-)

I think, identifying the device name for the card
is the major problem.

I watchd the /var/log/messeges while repluging the card.
It took at /dev/ttyUSB0.
giving that, it worked well.

I did not tried with ubuntu.
Hope it also easy.

Thanks for ilugc-mangalore keegan.

regards,
T.Shrinivasan.

Subject: [Ilugc] Sep Month ILUGC Meeting
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0609061650360.1848-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

ILUGC Meet (Sep 9th):-
======================

Time : Sat Sep 9th 15:00 IST 2006 
Venue: ADI-TeNeT Seminar Hall,
       #CSD 320, ESB, IIT-Madras.

Visit: http://www.chennailug.org/location-tenet.php

Agenda:

NOTE: All Talks are yet to be conformed.

Talk 1: GNU extensions to the C and C++
        By Vijay Kumar B

        Talk about the features provided by GNU compiler, which not 
        found in ISO standard C. Read 'info gcc'.

Talk 2: Role of FOSS in UCH Project.
        By Alex Cravan

        An Australian Volunteer for the Uluru Children's Home (UCH)  
        Project, Is Look for a help from ILUGC members to setup a 
        small Linux based Center in Kadapakkam Village, Kancheepuram 
        District.

Talk 3: MOOL Project (http://lotus.iitm.ac.in/MOOL/)
        By Vinay

        Minimalistic Object Oriented Linux(MOOL) project aims at 
        redesigning the existing Linux Kernel with minimal set of 
        core OO components.

* Software Freedom Day celebrations discussion.

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

/media/<name>)

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Sep  6 07:24:40 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Sep  6 19:55:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Net,usb drive not working on Kubuntu 6.06
In-Reply-To: <72288b670609060519h3a923184v1aeb14ad11ee629c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060906142441.90708.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Vidhya Shankar,

--- Vidhya Shankar L <lv.shankar@gmail.com> wrote:
> But neither
> works anymore. 

Tell us what error/output message you got when you
tried connecting to the Internet or when using the USB
pen drive.

After connecting the USB pen drive. open a terminal
and post output of:

  /bin/dmesg | tail
  /bin/lsmod
  /usr/bin/lsusb

Note, you can redirect output to a file:

  /bin/lsmod > lsmod.txt

> I've tried even reinstalling, in
> vain.

It is very _bad_ to reinstall *nix. You always fix the
problem/issue.

SK

Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Thu Sep  7 02:36:50 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Thu Sep  7 02:36:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] sendmail config for gmail relaying
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609061406n2ae616d3l5ec841b99155ff1@mail.gmail.com>

Hi All,

I want to relay email from my home FreeBSD 6.1 box running
sendmail by using gmail as the smarthost.  I've been pampered
by Debian's eximconfig for too long and I am lost with my
freebsd.mc.

I've added the following in my freebsd.mc file:

define(`SMART_HOST',`smtp.gmail.com')dnl
define(`confAUTH_MECHANISMS', `EXTERNAL GSSAPI DIGEST-MD5 CRAM-MD5
LOGIN PLAIN')dnl
define(`RELAY_MAILER',`esmtp')dnl
define(`RELAY_MAILER_ARGS', `TPC $h 587')dnl
FEATURE(`authinfo',`hash /etc/mail/auth/client-info')dnl

My /etc/mail/auth/client-info looks like this:
AuthInfo:smtp.gmail.com "U:root" "I:rajasuperman@gmail.com" "P:<password>"

I rebuilt the sendmail with "make" and "make restart" to
restart sendmail.  When I send a test email to
rajasuperman@gmail.com, the following error appears in
/var/log/maillog and message delivery is deferred.

Sep  7 02:11:47 mithila sendmail[6007]: k86KfkBh006007: from=rsubr,
size=131, class=0, nrcpts=1,
msgid=<200609062041.k86KfkBh006007@mithila.ath.cx>,
relay=root@localhost

Sep  7 02:11:48 mithila sm-mta[6010]: k86KflH8006010:
from=<rsubr@mithila.ath.cx>, size=458, class=0, nrcpts=1,
msgid=<200609062041.k86KfkBh006007@mithila.ath.cx>, proto=ESMTP,
daemon=Daemon0, relay=localhost [127.0.0.1]

Sep  7 02:11:48 mithila sendmail[6007]: k86KfkBh006007:
to=rajasuperman@gmail.com, ctladdr=rsubr (1001/1001), delay=00:00:02,
xdelay=00:00:01, mailer=relay, pri=30131, relay=[127.0.0.1]
[127.0.0.1], dsn=2.0.0, stat=Sent (k86KflH8006010 Message accepted for
delivery)

Sep  7 02:12:03 mithila sm-mta[6014]: k86KflH8006010:
to=<rajasuperman@gmail.com>, ctladdr=<rsubr@mithila.ath.cx>
(1001/1001), delay=00:00:15, xdelay=00:00:15, mailer=esmtp, pri=30458,
relay=gmail.com., dsn=4.0.0, stat=Deferred: Name server: gmail.com.:
host name lookup failure


Note: I don't have any dns problems on the box, and it
has perfect access to the internet.  Interestingly, any
email I send to remote domains through the smarthost always
fails with a host name lookup failure.  Local delivery is
fine.

Can someone please hit me with a clue stick?  Thanks in
advance for any help or suggestions.

- Raja

[Dialer Defaults]
Init1 = ATZ
Init2 = AT+CRM=1
Stupid Mode = 1
ISDN = 0
Modem Type = USB Modem
New PPPD = yes
FlowControl = Hardware (CRTSCTS)
Phone = #777
Modem = /dev/ttyACM0
Username = internet
Password = internet
Baud = 460800
From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Thu Sep  7 06:23:10 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Thu Sep  7 06:23:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] sendmail config for gmail relaying
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560609061406n2ae616d3l5ec841b99155ff1@mail.gmail.com>
References: <92f9a9560609061406n2ae616d3l5ec841b99155ff1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44FF6D76.7040000@frodo.hserus.net>

Raja Subramanian wrote:
> define(`SMART_HOST',`smtp.gmail.com')dnl
> 
> Sep  7 02:12:03 mithila sm-mta[6014]: k86KflH8006010:
> to=<rajasuperman@gmail.com>, ctladdr=<rsubr@mithila.ath.cx>
> (1001/1001), delay=00:00:15, xdelay=00:00:15, mailer=esmtp, pri=30458,
> relay=gmail.com., dsn=4.0.0, stat=Deferred: Name server: gmail.com.:
> host name lookup failure

smtp.gmail.com is a CNAME to gmail-smtp.l.google.com

Sendmail might not like your setting a cname there in the smarthost

Try changing smtp.gmail.com to gmail-smtp.l.google.com or do something
like [smtp.gmail.com] - note the square brackets - instead of just
smtp.gmail.com [dont attempt to resolve that hostname further and follow
things on - just connect to "smtp.gmail.com" and push email out]

From masivakumar at gmail.com  Thu Sep  7 11:01:25 2006
From: masivakumar at gmail.com (Sivakumar Ma)
Date: Thu Sep  7 11:01:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux in consumer electronics - TV Laptop
Message-ID: <139e14f00609062231q607ddcf6s6c9d71028142da82@mail.gmail.com>

When a new model of laptop with latest devices come out it is another battle
for the open source community to get them working with linux distributions.

It is a joy when Ubuntu 6 detects the sound card and stars playing sounds
without having to spend hours.

It is nice to see a few lines of script on the web to enable Tata Indicom
Data Card and connect to internet wirelessly in Ubuntu.

Now more good news.

[Portable personal computers target the movie mad] (
http://www.hindu.com/2006/09/06/stories/2006090603721400.htm) talks about
"one of the first portable machines that comes with a built-in TV tuner.
This means one can attach it to a TV antenna or cable connector to see all
the usual television feeds."

"And you don't have to boot the PC's Windows software to use it as a TV or a
DVD player: these controls are available separately with start, stop, fast
forward and rewind controls, much like a stand-alone video player."

"the Lenovo 3000 series offers a ``One Key'' recovery utility to restore the
laptop's last working condition in case of disk crash ? and this is based on
a Linux tool, not the machines Windows operating system."

"PowerCinema too is being offered by its makers in a Linux version ? and
this opens up the interesting possibility that TV-laptops can be made even
more affordable in the future by going Open Source all the way."

The march of open source power is finally arriving in India brought by
commercial players. Interesting times ahead!

Best regards,

Ma Sivakumar

Hi,
There will be no lettering or label for the new partition of vfat you
created under GNU/Linux. You have to create a Lettering for that
partition. You can do that through MMC (Microsoft Management Console).

NOTE: I guess this will work. never tried.

Subject: [Ilugc] REG: track wiki - Trac admin unable to create env variables

But when i went on creating the environment, it throws an error

root@ubuntu:/var/www# trac-admin /home/thyagarajan/trac-0.10b1 initenv
Initenv for '/home/thyagarajan/trac-0.10b1' failed.

From joe_steeve at gmx.net  Thu Sep  7 12:55:52 2006
From: joe_steeve at gmx.net (Joe Steeve)
Date: Thu Sep  7 12:44:33 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] REG: track wiki - Trac admin unable to create env
	variables
In-Reply-To: <ed2d3c000609062334n20a4ff1fm29c679c1b039ba90@mail.gmail.com>
References: <ed2d3c000609062334n20a4ff1fm29c679c1b039ba90@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44FFC980.3030205@gmx.net>

Thyagu rajan wrote:
> root@ubuntu:/var/www# trac-admin /home/thyagarajan/trac-0.10b1
> initenv Initenv for '/home/thyagarajan/trac-0.10b1' failed. Directory
> exists and is not empty.

Looks like you got confused with 'trac environment'

After 'trac' is installed., you can create multiple instances of 'trac'
for your different projects (collections). So., the 'trac environment'
is one such instance. So., for a project 'foo'., i'd probably create a
'trac environment' as.,

$trac-admin /home/joe/projects/foo initenv

Now., the folder 'foo' should not exist. The 'trac-admin' utility will
create the folder and put the respective files for serving the wiki,
ticket-tracker, etc.., into the /home/joe/projects/foo folder. You can
serve this folder over HTTP using apache or the inbuilt HTTP server that
comes with trac.

Trac will refuse to create an environment in an existing directory to
avoid accidental over-writing of project information.

-- 
.o. A proud GNU user
..o
ooo [W] http://www.joesteeve.org/

From shyamky at yahoo.com  Thu Sep  7 00:50:09 2006
From: shyamky at yahoo.com (K.Shyam)
Date: Thu Sep  7 13:20:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: vfat free space errors
In-Reply-To: <20060907055115.7FDCE1DB269@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <20060907075009.58409.qmail@web30609.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Hi All;
Well problem solved. Seems that it had some free cluster issues.
I did a "fsck.vfat -vVa /dev/sda1" and it is now reporting the
correct free space and i am also able to write files properly.
The hard disk is of make "crossfire" and windoze was used to create
the vfat(fat32) partition initially.
Thanks to all for your inputs/suggestions
K.Shyam

Subject: [Ilugc] vfat free space errors

References: <d6e7f37f0609062340y1edd0208v26441346a2063a41@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060907074042.95987.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <d6e7f37f0609070050t51877791we07690a9c97e3ea2@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/7/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> --- Pushparajan V <vprajan@gmail.com> wrote:
> > There will be no lettering or label for the new
> > partition of vfat you
>
> What are you refering to as "lettering" or "label"?

Let me get it clear to you all. By default, in M$ windows, every
partition is assigned a drive letter like C:, D:. When we create a
vfat partition under GNU/Linux, it will not be visible in windows
under a drive letter. Thats what i refered with lettering. You need to
assign a letter for that partition using MMC.
But,  Vivek wrote:
> No.. when we try to assign label, it shows only Delete partition option, but
> it
> recognized it as FAT32 partition.

Want to check out and tell. :)

Hello LUGies,

Mr. Srinivasan of NRCFOSS and Myself made a trip to Layola college today 
and had a small interactive session with students of MCA dept. (Computer 
Science Dept). The students as well as the HOD & Faculty are very much 
eager to take up FOSS activities and wish at least a few students could 
take up some really worthy projects in FOSS as they have a 6 month 
project period.

As SFD is very near, we suggested them to formally open up a 'GNU/Linux 
club' on the Software Freedom Day. The HOD said he will invite all other 
departments that are interested in FOSS, like Statistics, 
Bioinformatics, etc., to join this initiative. In addtion, as from 
NRCFOSS we are ready to offer projects for the students who are 
interested in doing. The SFD will be the starting point for them to 
focus on FOSS.

We, in regards to the SFD at Layola, need a speaker to speak on the 
occasion as they are starting up a GNU/Linux club on the day. Will 
discuss more about this, in our coming LUG meet this saturday at IITM.

If posible I invite the HOD, Dept. of Computer Science, Layola college 
to join us this saturday at our monthly LUG meet, held at IIT-Madras :)

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Sep  7 07:35:06 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Sep  7 20:05:52 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to configure Hathway Broadband Internet on Linux
In-Reply-To: <45002573.408@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060907143506.50896.qmail@web50211.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- dineshraop <dineshraop@gmail.com> wrote:
>    I tried configuring the LAN(Ethernet) for this
> purpose and started network 
>    again but it doesnot work. 

What do you mean "does not work"?
 
>    I tried configuring DSL Modem as well but that
> also does not work

How did you configure it? How did you test it to come
to the conclusion that it "does not work"?

> If someone could give me the exact shell commands
> it would be really
>    helpful. 

Open a terminal and post output of:

  /sbin/lsmod
  /sbin/ifconfig -a
  cat /etc/resolv.conf
 
Note, you can redirect output to a file:

 /sbin/lsmod > lsmod.txt

These are useful for debugging. Please paste them
inline and send the e-mail (_not_ as attachments).

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From aanjhan at gmail.com  Thu Sep  7 20:20:39 2006
From: aanjhan at gmail.com (Aanjhan R)
Date: Thu Sep  7 20:20:49 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to configure Hathway Broadband Internet on Linux
In-Reply-To: <45002573.408@gmail.com>
References: <45002573.408@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <adc51dea0609070750y4a6af6bfm882c258902c9c63e@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 9/7/06, dineshraop <dineshraop@gmail.com> wrote:
>    The *Hathway* guys have given me a static IP, DNS and Gateway.
>

Yes. I have been using HAthway on GNU/Linux for the past 1.5 years at
Bangalore.
GUI (Ubuntu - GNOME):
Click on System -> Administration -> Networking
Type your Administrative password
Enable your ethx (should be 0)
Click on properties and Select Static IP (default would be DHCP)
Enter the IP address that was given
Leave the default subnet mask
Enter the gateway adresss

Go to the DNS Tab and enter the two DNS address they gave.
Put your Default interface to eth0

Click OK. You will be up online

CLI:
Use ifconfig command to set your IP
Edit /etc/resolv.conf to give you DNS address (must be Administrator)


Regards,
-- 

Aanjhan
----------------------------------
a.k.a Tuxmaniac
Locations: #ubuntu-in, #linux-india, #gnu-india @irc.freenode.net
CyberHome: http://www.tuxmaniac.com
----------------------------------

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Thu Sep  7 22:26:18 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Thu Sep  7 22:26:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] sendmail config for gmail relaying
In-Reply-To: <44FF6D76.7040000@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <92f9a9560609061406n2ae616d3l5ec841b99155ff1@mail.gmail.com>
	<44FF6D76.7040000@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609070956w21492274vc942e3d9b1b73e7b@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/7/06, Suresh Ramasubramanian <linux@frodo.hserus.net> wrote:
> Raja Subramanian wrote:
> > Sep  7 02:12:03 mithila sm-mta[6014]: k86KflH8006010:
> > to=<rajasuperman@gmail.com>, ctladdr=<rsubr@mithila.ath.cx>
> > (1001/1001), delay=00:00:15, xdelay=00:00:15, mailer=esmtp, pri=30458,
> > relay=gmail.com., dsn=4.0.0, stat=Deferred: Name server: gmail.com.:
> > host name lookup failure
> smtp.gmail.com is a CNAME to gmail-smtp.l.google.com
> Sendmail might not like your setting a cname there in the smarthost

Thanks for the tip.

I turned out that I *was* having DNS problems.  My DSL router barfed
when trying to fetch MX records (dig -t mx gmail.com failed), but A
records were working perfectly.  That settled, my box is now happily
email me output from cron jobs.

My experience is chronicled at:
http://rajasuperman.blogspot.com/2006/09/gmail-as-smarthost-for-fre_115764792412436946.html

- Raja

Subject: [Ilugc] [REQUEST] Application to the mailing list gods!

Hi,

I know, I know, this has been discussed ad nauseam, but can the list 
admin please turn on reply-to munging (I'm not exactly sure who it is, 
so this open request)? It's getting on my nerves to reply to the list. 
The whole world works one way and ILUGC mailing list works one way. I 
have to do a reply all, remove a ton of email addresses, change the 'cc' 
into a 'to' field for ilugc list id and then send it (in Thunderbird at 
least). Half the time, I just hit 'close' on a half-done reply thinking 
"gah. why bother?".

The other day, one more hold-out, the Erlang mailing list, started 
munging it's reply-to header. The list admin needed only two emails to 
convince him. Please, save our fingers.

Is it just me, or have every body inured themselves to this PITA?


Vamsee.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Sep  7 20:13:35 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Sep  8 08:43:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] RHEL 3 + USB disk problem
In-Reply-To: <20060907175917.33966.qmail@web36711.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060908031335.35274.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Anandh G <anandhg02@yahoo.com> wrote:
> There is no message logged, 

Where did you check this? After plugging in the
device,  open a terminal and post output of:

  /bin/dmesg | tail

Note, you can redirect output to a file:

  /bin/dmesg | tail > dmesg.txt

Please post it inline when sending the e-mail (_not_
as attachments).

Similarily, when you try to unmount the device, get a
dmesg output.

> I have to forceably
> remove
> the disk. But this corrupts the data. 

Yes, the disk write is cached. If you mount with -o
sync option then it is ensured that all disk writes
are written immediately.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

mobile number.

[Dialer Defaults]
Modem = /dev/ttyUSB0
Baud = 115200
Init1 = AT+CRM=1
Init2 = ATQ0 V1 E1 S0=0 &C1 &D2
#Init3 =

Phone = #777
Username = 9430502456
Password =9430502456
Ask Password = 0
Dial Command = ATDT
Stupid Mode = 1

Auto DNS = 1

saran
