From akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in  Fri Sep  8 12:50:46 2006
From: akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in (Kumar Appaiah)
Date: Fri Sep  8 12:36:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Suggestions for software in IITM mirror
Message-ID: <20060908072046.GA4453@localhost>

Dear ILUGC,

As many are already aware, IIT Madras' ftp.iitm.ac.in is a mirror for
quite a lot of free software. As of now, it is an "official" Debian
i386 repository mirror, and has the following:

* Debian repository
* CentOS repository
* Fedora Core updates
* Cygwin
* Red Hat 9 (required for legacy; some users can't do without it!)
* Linux kernel (This machine is actually http://www.in.kernel.org
  http://ftp.in.kernel.org)
* Slackware contents (without ISO, I guess)
* The Linux Documentation Project

and some more things. The site is administered by Dr.Sriram (Dept. of
Aerospace Engg., IIT Madras).

This morning, I had a chat with Dr.Sriram, and he made the following
comments:

* The server is used by people from all over the world.
* Cygwin is, by far, the top downloaded package.
* There is lots of bandwidth available for outgoing traffic, so the
  site is, essentially, very fast.
* There is about 200GB of space available, so we can put a lot more
  software for download there.

So, immediately suggested that he add the ISO images of Slackware
10.2, FreeBSD 6.1 and the latest Mandriva. I have also suggested that
he get hold of Fedora Core 6 when it is rolled out next month. He
accepted the suggestion, and said that he was open to more suggestions
on mirroring software, though he laid down the following conditions:

* Space, though available, must not be wasted. So, anything that is
  left untouched for about a month will be *removed*.

* Preference will be given to packages/software for x86 only. It is
  not worth the trouble of mirroring software for some architecture
  which may hardly be of use to the general users.

Keeping these in mind, please suggest some packages/distributions
which you think will be worth mirroring, and will be of use.

Also, please mention whether you want the ISO images of the CDs or
DVDs in case of distributions. Personally, I would vote for CDs, as I
do not possess a DVD writer, and because I generally don't get every
CD.

Awaiting your suggestions :-)

Thanks.

Kumar
-- 
Kumar Appaiah,
462, Jamuna Hostel,
Indian Institute of Technology Madras,
Chennai - 600 036

have you considered the possibility that the list admin may not read the list
postings on an hourly (or more frequent) basis? your present list admin (myself)
checks the postings for interesting threads maybe once in 2-3 days. of course,
the admin will respond to mails addressed to ilugc-owner in a shorter time
scale. ok, that brings up two things.

(1) the immediate issue is of munging or not munging reply-to headers. i will go
with whichever way the list wants it. perhaps, someone could set up a vote
somewhere for this? or is this something that is so obvious today that we dont
need to do this? 

(2) list adminship is open to anyone interested in taking it on (perhaps, there
might be preference for someone who checks for new postings once every minute).
i did start on this some time ago, but did not follow up.

sriram

From sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in  Fri Sep  8 14:06:17 2006
From: sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in (Prof. P. Sriram)
Date: Fri Sep  8 14:06:20 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Suggestions for software in IITM mirror
In-Reply-To: <4501210B.2050209@fedoraproject.org>
References: <20060908072046.GA4453@localhost>

On Fri, 8 Sep 2006, Rahul wrote:
> Mirroring a years old end of life distribution is rather unnecessary 
> IMO. It encourages use of software with known security vulnerabilities.

note that the original posting said 'for legacy users'. there are legacy
machines that dont need updates and work quite well with end of life
distributions. i have a couple of machines in my lab which run redhat 7.2
and there is no need for me to update them (of course, updating to any
current distro would probably fail due to hardware requirements). they are
on isolated intranets and security is not a major issue. the image
processing software on them works just like it did years ago and will
continue to be used for some more years. why would i update these? in case 
something conks out, i will try to restore it to exactly the same distro 
and software instead of trying to migrate to new distros. and thats what 
legacy support is all about. there are others on campus like this. not to 
sound mean, but ftp.iitm.ac.in is primarily meant for iitm users - but 
since we have the bandwdith to spare, we dont mind sharing the contents 
with others.

-- 
sriram

end users.  I tried ftp.iitm.ac.in ~3 years ago and found it slower
than mirror.aarnet.edu.au.  I'm was and still am using an Airtel
DSL connection from Chennai.  Has connectivity/bandwidth improved
recently?

From akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in  Fri Sep  8 15:18:26 2006

On Fri, Sep 08, 2006 at 03:10:39PM +0530, Raja Subramanian wrote:
> On 9/8/06, Kumar Appaiah <akumar@ee.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> >As many are already aware, IIT Madras' ftp.iitm.ac.in is a mirror for

> end users.  I tried ftp.iitm.ac.in ~3 years ago and found it slower

> DSL connection from Chennai.  Has connectivity/bandwidth improved

Yes. Recently, there have been major infrastructure upgrades in IITM,
which have brought a perceptible speedup to IITM sites/server. Also,
usage statistics (available only in campus) indicate that
international traffic is more than Indian traffic. So, it should now
be a better choice as a mirror (I think).

From binand at gmail.com  Fri Sep  8 11:50:02 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Sep  8 15:20:11 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Suggestions for software in IITM mirror
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560609080240p660b300fg32fb53121ef03aaf@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20060908072046.GA4453@localhost>
	<92f9a9560609080240p660b300fg32fb53121ef03aaf@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609080250l1b39bbaarfb1d9034c7f28086@mail.gmail.com>

On 08/09/06, Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:
> The utility of a mirror depends primarily on the access speed to
> end users.  I tried ftp.iitm.ac.in ~3 years ago and found it slower
> than mirror.aarnet.edu.au.  I'm was and still am using an Airtel
> DSL connection from Chennai.  Has connectivity/bandwidth improved
> recently?

Due to poor peering practices, till about a few years ago, a Sify DSL
user would go all the way to the US and return to India to access a
colocated server in VSNL. This could have led to the general
perception that Indian servers are slower to access than their foreign
counterparts. With improved co-operation between ISPs, I do think this
is no longer the case (check http://www.nixi.org/, for example).

Binand
From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Fri Sep  8 14:50:55 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Fri Sep  8 15:39:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: [REQUEST] Application to the mailing list gods!
In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f0609080102r530c6be9wdf2e9d6b8dee7598@mail.gmail.com>
References: <45006418.1070004@gmail.com>	<F2002DE8-478F-4AB6-9BC8-979F49E437B5@thenilgiris.com>	<a54a308e0609072331o65977173t5d76b2a6275fa9e0@mail.gmail.com>	<loom.20060908T092314-813@post.gmane.org>
	<dc538c3f0609080102r530c6be9wdf2e9d6b8dee7598@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <450135F7.8040200@gmail.com>

balachandar muruganantham wrote:
> hi
> 
>> (1) the immediate issue is of munging or not munging reply-to headers. 
>> i will go
>> with whichever way the list wants it. perhaps, someone could set up a 
>> vote
>> somewhere for this? or is this something that is so obvious today that 
>> we dont
>> need to do this?
> 
> i guess the present settings is far good enough.
> also take a look at the url http://www.unicom.com/pw/reply-to-harmful.html
> 
> my suggestion is the user should never be restricted. its user wish
> whether he wants to send the reply to list back or to the individual.
> either u can use reply | reply to all option in most of the mail
> clients (both desktop and web based).
> 
> please dont try to control the user. give user the flexibility and let
> him decide.
> 
IMHO, by munging a 'reply-to' header, I don't think the freedom of the 
user to decide where his reply is sent to will be controlled anyway. In 
a mailing list, the default procedure is mailing your replies back to 
the mailing list so it gets distributed to everyone. So, making the 
'reply-to' field to point to the mailing list's is not a wrong idea, it 
indeed is the best thing to do.

Also, we have seen many time in the past that instead of sending back 
the reply to the mailing list, replies had been sent to the individuals. 
This is especially true in cases when the thread grows and more people 
start multi-quoting one another that eventually we miss who-said-what 
and start replying to in-appropriate people instead of mailing to the 
person whom we are actually replying in regards with. To prevent such 
issues as well as prevent the drive to send personal mails flaming 
people for their comments, we can have a reply-to field point to the 
mailing-list id, so by default the mails indeed reach the mailing list 
rather than individuals.

Even when I started with this mail, I had to manually remove the 
individual mail id and replace it with the mailing-list's id. Rather 
than calling it pain in the fingers I would like to call it an overhead, 
which indeed as  someone in the beginning said, de-motivates us from 
completing the reply which we had actually intended to... especially 
when more individuals were addressed in the previous mail and thus reply 
to or reply-all both adds extra work to change the to: field.

++1 voting for reply-to munging :)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.
Research Engineer, NRCFOSS
A Proud Ubuntero and Linuxian
[Tech Blog: http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com]
[NRCFOSS HelpLine: http://nrcfosshelpline.in/code/wiki/]

>   software for download there.

Hi,

On 9/8/06, SRIRAM. P <sriram@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> (1) the immediate issue is of munging or not munging reply-to headers. i will go
> with whichever way the list wants it. perhaps, someone could set up a vote
> somewhere for this? or is this something that is so obvious today that we dont
> need to do this?

++1 to set set the reply-to header to the list address. Many new
user's are not aware of clicking on "Reply-To-All" and just do a
reply. This will ensure that new user's don't endup sending a
personal-mail to other members on the list.

Thanks for making this process trully democratic. :)

-Toufeeq

blog @ http://toufeeq.net

On 08/09/06, balachandar muruganantham <mbchandar@gmail.com> wrote:
> i guess the present settings is far good enough.
> also take a look at the url http://www.unicom.com/pw/reply-to-harmful.html

Every time this topic comes up, this very antediluvian opinion piece
is thrown about as some sort of authoritative standard.

In any case, I used to have this procmail rule for ilugc (before
moving to gmail):

# ilugc doesn't have reply-to set to list. This is a workaround
:0
* ^List-Id:.*ilugc
{
   :0 fw
   | formail -I "Reply-To: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in"

   :0:
   $MAILDIR/Lists/ilugc
}

Binand

From binand at gmail.com  Fri Sep  8 21:36:37 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sat Sep  9 01:06:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] ip address from mail sent using gmail
In-Reply-To: <BAY12-F176312551436C2757C8FC69E370@phx.gbl>
References: <f3cf3ae70609080653m42ee2c2eo74edeca85299c749@mail.gmail.com>
	<BAY12-F176312551436C2757C8FC69E370@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609081236v19bd91a4kefb7865530bd8a5a@mail.gmail.com>

On 08/09/06, Antano Solar John <solar345@hotmail.com> wrote:
> when mails are sent using gmail , the x-originating ip is the ip address of
> google .Looks like its relaying the mails through its own server.I was just
> wondeirng if the original ip is encrypted and stored or not along with
> header.

It is not. Google does not divulge the IP address of the sender.

http://mail.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=26903&topic=1560

There have been several skirmishes between Google and Spamhaus/Spamcop
because of this.

http://www.ironport.com/company/pp_marketwatch_03-27-2006.html
http://foo-projects.org/node/27

etc...

Personally speaking, I laud Google's position in this matter.

Binand
From sanjay_chigurupati at yahoo.com  Fri Sep  8 13:59:02 2006
From: sanjay_chigurupati at yahoo.com (Sanjay Chigurupati)
Date: Sat Sep  9 02:29:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] unikix
In-Reply-To: <20060908045419.38634.qmail@web54113.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060908205902.20710.qmail@web42403.mail.scd.yahoo.com>

Hi,
Unikix is a software solution. Its not an OS. Its
purpose was to allow IBM Mainframe applications to be
run on Unix boxes. ( CICS applications or in other
words transaction oriented applications). CICS is IBM
technology for transactions.

Unikix was bought over later by Sun and renamed sun
mainframe rehosting solution and offered only for
solaris OS.

HTH,
Sanjay

--- Ashok Antony <anjeas_net@yahoo.com> wrote:

> unix.

This doesn't stop here, but Microsoft is much more bad than you might think.

IIRC if the manufacturer pre-installs any other OS alongside of Windows, 
only Windows should be bootable by default, the other OS should be 
bootable only by alternate means, say a  floppy or CD etc.

This approach is one of the primary reasons for the death of Be Inc and 
some others IMO.

I believe this cannot be prevented.

From binand at gmail.com  Sat Sep  9 09:23:47 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sat Sep  9 12:54:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Why does Desktop/Notebook Manufacturers not recommend
	linux?
In-Reply-To: <809586140609082353h6b23a2edtb0c3248027067a65@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609082353h6b23a2edtb0c3248027067a65@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609090023p3131d854y68cb9be9bb2758c@mail.gmail.com>

On 09/09/06, Vishnu Vijayaraghavan <vishnu.vijayaraghavan@gmail.com> wrote:
> I have seen ads of all Desktop/Notebook manufacturers from Dell to
> Leneova, which only recommends XP inspite of it being more vulnerable
> to attacks. Why can't they recommend GNU/Linux  or BSD's which is more
> stable and trouble free? Is that M$ is paying the manufacturers for
> putting the caption
> "XYZ recommends Windows XP"

That is one of the conditions of Microsoft's OEM licensing - that all
promotional material (advertisements, brochures etc.) should include
the statement "Fubar recommends Microsoft Windows XP". For this, OEMs
get Windows XP at very cheap rates - $20 or so - as opposed to retail
selling price of $400.

Binand
From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Sat Sep  9 12:56:09 2006

From chaks.yoper at gmail.com  Sat Sep  9 13:01:58 2006
From: chaks.yoper at gmail.com (Chakkaradeep C C)
Date: Sat Sep  9 13:02:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Why does Desktop/Notebook Manufacturers not recommend
	linux?
In-Reply-To: <809586140609082353h6b23a2edtb0c3248027067a65@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609082353h6b23a2edtb0c3248027067a65@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <a54a308e0609090031t1400ee83ye38f7f5316eff3ce@mail.gmail.com>

Hi Vijay,

On 9/9/06, Vishnu Vijayaraghavan <vishnu.vijayaraghavan@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> I have seen ads of all Desktop/Notebook manufacturers from Dell to
> Leneova, which only recommends XP inspite of it being more vulnerable
> to attacks. Why can't they recommend GNU/Linux  or BSD's which is more
> stable and trouble free? Is that M$ is paying the manufacturers for
> putting the caption
> "XYZ recommends Windows XP"


Unfortunately this cant be stopped, but yes, if DELL,Compaq etc., are
provided with all the drivers and if GNU/Linux OS pass their End User
Testing (out of the box functionality), they will sure make it available.

Microsoft has a list of Hardwares and Devices which it says that Windows
"XXX" will work and passes this to all OEM Manufacturers. Since GNU/Linux is
not a single body as Microsoft, here you dont have a single body for this.
You may tell Community is there, but the OEM Manufacturers wont look for
answers, they will only get it from you.


The main problem what i feel makes the vendors neglect GNU/Linux is,
1) Lack of drivers
2) GNU Ethics (for example, the Multimedia and other Entertainment issues)

If GNU/Linux can pass these, I am sure, OEM Manufacturers will look into
shipping GNU/Linux with Laptops and Dekstops.


--

From girish1729 at gmail.com  Sat Sep  9 13:43:07 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sat Sep  9 13:45:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Entrepreneurship based on Open Source Model
In-Reply-To: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060909081307.GA4049@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Sat, Sep 09, 2006 at 12:53:31PM +0530, Vishnu Vijayaraghavan wrote:
> Hi all,
>     I would like to set up  a start-up based on the Open Source Model
> in the near future. How effective will Open Source Model suit for
> enterpreneurship. What are the prerequsities to be satisfied before
> starting. I would also like to know about some of the most successful
> enterpreneur based on open source. Or to simply put up
> 
> How to set up an enterprise based on Open Source Model from scratch
> (for indian scenario)
> 
> Pls. kindly help me.

What do you mean "near future"? Does it mean immediate or few months
down the line? 

Today open source is critical for business. There are no two ways about
it. The benefit is not only in terms of cost but also in terms of
tweakability, customizing stuff to your needs etc. In fact many
companies add masala to open source code and provide timely support. And
the term open source has become so ubiquitous that you can easily
convince MBA guys that it can save money for you. 

First the global scenario. Then I will try to address the Indian
scenario. Let us take google for instance. Google used to run RedHat on
its server farm, I don't know what they are running now. Yahoo!,
Amazon,eBay everyone are out and out FreeBSD shops not to mention
hotmail which runs a combo. Juniper routers are all FreeBSD based. 

Let us come to the question of making money thro' Open Source?
Definitely possible. I will urge you to take a look at the damn
small linux homepage, there John has written a nice practical
article on how to make money via a "successful" open source product.
Mind you, damn small linux is damn successful , that is why he is
able to say this. So if you do a really good job and develop a world
#1 software which you make open source, you will definitely make money
down the line thro' ads(Google AdSense) and support and other sources.

Look at it this way  buddy. How do Suryan FM and Sun TV make money?
Do they charge for programming? No. They get huge Ad revenues. In
fact if Tamil had been as popular as Hindi, then Sun would have got
even more viewership, ad revenue and so on. Not to say that Sun
doesn't have enough money right now. :-)

Something similar applies to open source. However channels like Jaya
TV hardly have any revenue. So if you do manage to do something cool
and highly technically challenging; something that is novel and
useful. Then being open source, it spreads by word of mouth
marketing and few months down the line, as ppl download and find it
interesting, you will start getting hits on your website that
translate into revenue in various ways. 


One strategy that works somewhat well though I don't like it is you
make a program open source and then give a premium edition with
certain killer features. I personally hold it immoral and cruel to
do it, however you can try it. AFAIK not many ppl do this these
days.


Though I cannot substantiate my statements with facts these are my
general opinions and observations. Recent acquisition of snort by
Checkpoint is a case in point. All I am saying is if you do a good
job, money will come. :-)

Coming to the Indian scenario, I am also finding the answer to the
question you posed. I don't actually understand the question since
open source means available to all ppl at all parts of the world. So
if I understand correctly you are talking about such a thing working
in the Indian society/culture. I would say a fat chance. Bcoz Bram
Cohen was surviving on credit cards until he finished his bittorrent
program. U know how high expenses can be in US. And Linus Torvalds
wrote linux in a country like Finland where you have proper weather
only for two months in a year. Most of the time you won't even have
sunlight. Some ppl believe lack of sunlight can lead to depression.


In India we don't have these problems. The problems however are of a
different nature. Our society still considers entrepreneurship as
taboo. And being a developing nation we have 100s of small small
things to take care. You can never take anything for granted.
However things are lookup up very much these days and I am sure
things are only going to get better in the coming days.

We don't have proper academia/industry interaction largely bcoz our
industries don't even know the meaning of innovation and world
classness. IITM is the first institute as far as I know that has
shown that it is indeed possible to create real world biz solutions
from inside academic culture.


However open source is all about excellence and we have a very long
way to go before we can claim that. However as individuals you and
I can do  quite a lot,get the right ppl, do the right things etc.

I cannot tell you what you should do, but I certainly can tell you
what you should not do.

Don't get an army of programmers. Get a small cohesive set of hand
picked programmers.

Have an informal culture. Dont say, "come in formal dress." It
positively kills creativity. Ppl should feel as comfy at office as
they are at home. At the same time you should ensure professionalism
and make sure that work gets done. 

That is all from my side. 

Wait, I just noticed you mentioned the word "from scratch". I personally
dont like it. Do you mean reinventing the wheel? If you try that, then
other ppl will overtake you and you will be left in the lurch.

My God help you in your noble endeavors!

Best,
Girish

Subject: [Ilugc] How to configure Hathway Broadband Internet on Linux
In-Reply-To: <adc51dea0609070750y4a6af6bfm882c258902c9c63e@mail.gmail.com>

	<adc51dea0609070750y4a6af6bfm882c258902c9c63e@mail.gmail.com>

Hi Aanjhan,

   I configured exactly  as you said but still I am not able to access 
Internet.
   I have entered the Static IP, Default Gateway, DNS servers all as root.
   I have edited the file /etc/resolv.conf and placed DNS address (as 
Administrator) as well.
   I tried to ping the dns addresses given it says destination unreachable.
   I have also enabled & disabled the network card eth0 and has 
restarted the network again but no effect.
   When I open up mozilla and type url as www.google.com and enter it 
does not show up.
   Do I need to do anything more.

   My Hathway setup works in Windows2000 very well.

Kindly help me. Thanks in advance.

Regards
Dinesh


Aanjhan R wrote:
> Hi,
>
> On 9/7/06, dineshraop <dineshraop@gmail.com> wrote:
>>    The *Hathway* guys have given me a static IP, DNS and Gateway.
>>
>
> Yes. I have been using HAthway on GNU/Linux for the past 1.5 years at
> Bangalore.
> GUI (Ubuntu - GNOME):
> Click on System -> Administration -> Networking
> Type your Administrative password
> Enable your ethx (should be 0)
> Click on properties and Select Static IP (default would be DHCP)
> Enter the IP address that was given
> Leave the default subnet mask
> Enter the gateway adresss
>
> Go to the DNS Tab and enter the two DNS address they gave.
> Put your Default interface to eth0
>
> Click OK. You will be up online
>
> CLI:
> Use ifconfig command to set your IP
> Edit /etc/resolv.conf to give you DNS address (must be Administrator)
>
>
> Regards,

On Sat, Sep 09, 2006 at 02:31:29PM +0530, Vishnu Vijayaraghavan wrote:
> Is it really so. But, what about MySQL, IBM etc.... They have both
> Premium edition and community edition.
> 
Well, I think Postgres is several times better than MySQL. For small
sizes I hear MySQL outperforms Postgres but Postgres is really free.
And stable and scales well,blah blah. I am no DB guy, others shud
comment.

IBM? I wonder. I hear IBM does a lot of open source particularly Linux
work. How much do they give back? What do they sponsor? I really don't
know. I do know that FreeBSD does get commercial support from companies
that use it. For NetBSD too. I heard that Theo got pissed off with
Iraqi invasion and hence he lost a huge funding opportunity from US DoD.
But so far as my exp goes, OpenBSD is the sexiest thing since sliced
bread.

OpenBSD is a bad example. Since they have certain silly ideologies like
Debian. Doesn't work too well in the real world. As a result ppl exploit 
these ppl and kick them in the chest. U see what Ubuntu has done. Or
what companies that use OpenBSD software like OpenSSH have done. They
clearly mention in the home page that not a single company has repaid a
cent towards development. 

Welcome to the real world. This is how things work. If that is so in
cash rich US, forget such a thing happening in India. 

I still believe that with a lil bit of cleverness and ingenuity you can
avoid these problems. It is not just enough to be a good hacker. You
have to be a good businessman, entrepreneur and have a lil bit of
enterprising skills.

I heard an Indian Standford prof. say during the dot com days that we
Indians have a great deal of networking, entrepreneurial and
enterprising skills in our blood. I also have reason to believe that. 

However what we lack badly is team skills. We fall apart in no time. 
This has been the problem since time immemorial. We neither trust each
other nor do we behave in a manner worthy of trust. So finding the right
partner is not easy in the Indian context.
> >I don't actually understand the question since
> >open source means available to all ppl at all parts of the world. So
> >if I understand correctly you are talking about such a thing working
> >in the Indian society/culture.
> Yes in the Indian society and how indian market sees open source

How Indian market sees open source? Indian market sees nothing. Its eyes
are blindfolded. Just kidding. :-)

I am more or less convinced that the only model that will work in the
Indian context is a hardware/software combo. Nobody will pay for
software. Tally is the only counter example. I think even open source
kills this. Only if you sell a cheap piece of hardware with your
superior software you can think of making money in the Indian market.

Others, plz plz correct me if I am wrong.
> 
> >Our society still considers entrepreneurship as
> >taboo. And being a developing nation we have 100s of small small
> >things to take care. You can never take anything for granted.
> Exactly
Largely for software and hardware dev there is no problem. However
buying a Soekris box or a Digium card is not something like I go to
Circuitcity or Walmart. 

Provided you procure the hardware you can do the rest pretty well since
you have plenty of mailing lists and other info on the Internet to help
you out. 

I am yet to figure out a hardware mailing list. I am sure there are
many. Chennai does seem to have very good hardware experts too.

> That is well said. Even the same thought was going in on my mind.
Actually  it is much deeper than what I can possibly express. Management
is an art, not a science. You can't say, follow these 10 commandments
and you succeed.

Fundamentally a leader needs a spirit of sacrifice. It is very
important. And strong business ethics. Mind you, biz ethics, not some
stupid ideology like I will not lie or steal or cheat. :-)

You should be loyal and kind and understanding towards your employees.
We see two extremes bet Blore and Chennai. Blore lets employees do
anything. And Chennai is too conservative.

And you should somehow solve the team work problem I mentioned above. It
is nearly impossible to make two smart ppl work in the same team in
India. I have seen that together they pull you down. Or waste time
fighting with each other.

Another thing I forgot to mention. The ppl who call the shots should be
top class. A grade. If you get B grade ppl to do the job, then they
reject smart ppl in the interview stage itself and you won't even know
that they are eating into your viscera.

So I guess if you get a team of 5 or 6 world class ppl who work
cohesively as a team, your job is done. 
> 
> >Wait, I just noticed you mentioned the word "from scratch". I personally

> >other ppl will overtake you and you will be left in the lurch.
> 
> "from scratch" here does not refer to the open source softwares. It
> refers to my start-up ie. how to proceed.

Takes a long time. Setting up your own shop is very very difficult.
Needs lot of patience, endurance, guts, determination etc.

Fundamentally you should love what you do. 

Otherwise you cannot survive. Period.

It is not moonshine and roses.

regards,
Girish

From binand at gmail.com  Sat Sep  9 16:45:01 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sat Sep  9 20:15:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Courier IMAP Maildir location
In-Reply-To: <edd8ce540609090605mdb603e2r9a35905a63c179ae@mail.gmail.com>
References: <edd8ce540609090605mdb603e2r9a35905a63c179ae@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609090745w5254fd19x10069bc2b5ea206d@mail.gmail.com>

On 09/09/06, ~adarsh~ <vpadarsh@gmail.com> wrote:
> how to specify maildir location in courier imap?
> is it in the imapd config file ? if so how to specify new path like
> /home/Mails/%u/Maildir .%u and $LOGNAME are not working.
> Any points to solve this problem.

Courier-IMAP gets the path to the Home Directoy & Maildir from the
authentication module (from courier-authlib package) it uses.
Depending on the authentication module you want to use, then answer to
your question is slightly different. A thumb rule is that if the
authentication module does not specify a Maildir, then the Home
Directory is suffixed with the MAILDIRPATH variable from the imapd
config file (the auth module is required to provide a Home Directory).

So, in the simplest virtual hosting scenario with authuserdb, you'd
specify home=/home/Mails/whatever in the userdb entry for
user=whatever and MAILDIRPATH=Maildir in imapd to achieve what you
want to do.

Binand

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Sat Sep  9 20:37:56 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Sat Sep  9 20:38:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Courier IMAP Maildir location
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610609090745w5254fd19x10069bc2b5ea206d@mail.gmail.com>
References: <edd8ce540609090605mdb603e2r9a35905a63c179ae@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610609090745w5254fd19x10069bc2b5ea206d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4502D8CC.50902@frodo.hserus.net>

Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> So, in the simplest virtual hosting scenario with authuserdb, you'd
> specify home=/home/Mails/whatever in the userdb entry for
> user=whatever and MAILDIRPATH=Maildir in imapd to achieve what you
> want to do.

And in a more complex scenario you'd use hashed maildir structures - the
simplest being /path/to/Mails/u/s/username etc, and some more hashing to
split users even further between maildirs, and across multiple
fileservers ..

Dont stick all the maildirs into a single directory. You will ultimately
run into issues with that.

On 9/9/06, dineshraop <dineshraop@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>    When I open up mozilla and type url as www.google.com and enter it
> does not show up.
>    Do I need to do anything more.
>

try to ping google or access any website from some other browser like
Konqueror(where IPv6 is not enabled default), or disable IPv6 in your
mozilla and see. May be if its a problem with IPv6, you may disable IPv6 in
your mozilla alone by setting network.dns.disableIPv6 to true, or else
disable it system wide by

echo "alias net-pf-10 off" >> /etc/modprobe.conf

and rebooting.

Date: Sat Sep  9 22:44:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Why does Desktop/Notebook Manufacturers not recommend
	linux?
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0609090031t1400ee83ye38f7f5316eff3ce@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609082353h6b23a2edtb0c3248027067a65@mail.gmail.com>
	<a54a308e0609090031t1400ee83ye38f7f5316eff3ce@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <adc51dea0609091014n757a563ek8e65a0420ed96229@mail.gmail.com>

From kums at gmx.net  Sun Sep 10 00:03:50 2006
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Sun Sep 10 00:03:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] time
Message-ID: <4503090E.1040308@gmx.net>


priya sridhar wrote:

> hi
> i would like to print the thread execution time with milli second
>  accuracy.. i am not able to find anything relevant in time.h.. can u 
> please help
> 


Hi,

ANSI/ISO c standard libraries don't have the capability but the
gettimeofday function defined in <sys/time.h> (POSIX 1003.1-2001)
can help you out.

/******************************************/

#include <stdio.h>
#include <sys/time.h>

int main()
{			
	struct timeval tv;
	gettimeofday(&tv,NULL);
	printf("%d Seconds and %d microseconds have elapsed since the
epoch\n",(int)tv.tv_sec,(int)tv.tv_usec);
	return(0);
}

/******************************************/

lookup 'man gettimeofday' for more details.


Regards
Kumaraguru

--

From citizenofgnu at gmail.com  Sun Sep 10 00:19:27 2006
From: citizenofgnu at gmail.com (Thyagu rajan)
Date: Sun Sep 10 00:21:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to configure Hathway Broadband Internet on Linux
In-Reply-To: <e0900f3e0609090953sda79be8md03b075dc7f80875@mail.gmail.com>
References: <45002573.408@gmail.com>
	<adc51dea0609070750y4a6af6bfm882c258902c9c63e@mail.gmail.com>
	<45028DE7.4000706@gmail.com>
	<e0900f3e0609090953sda79be8md03b075dc7f80875@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <ed2d3c000609091149v6872c043ia35f996b71151e9d@mail.gmail.com>

Hi Dinesh and friends,

The hathway team is a tragic team in providing linux based  internet
solutions. The big nonsense of their service is thier archeitecture they do
not have a dhcpd server running under their service. Hathway boys are using
windows based machine for NAT and all netty jargons.
Their way works like this , The machine needs a connection to internet has
to bind the network mac address and one has to configure the
pachacharum(five elements) 'IP,Netmask,Gateway, Primary DNS and secondary
DNS' after this the connection establishes

The problem which anyone faces is that if there are two network card
installed in the machine , All the tragic music starts there .  if you are
using any eth0 like device like a wireless card is treated as eth1 will have
conflict in binding the mac address to the server kept in the ISP end.
This will not enable in a proper handshake.

Kindly have only one ethernet card, bind it ,configure the panchacharum, you
will be connect to the ethernet.if you have another disable, it in the
network panel and then try.

I am quoting here that "Hathway biling system is either
manupulative/errorneous which shoots the traffic score,"this is my personal
experience.


Cheers

Thyagarajan Shanmugham.

Date: Sun Sep 10 01:06:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Entrepreneurship based on Open Source Model
In-Reply-To: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <c293dd340609091154j66291998wa46c6d25332684a6@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/9/06, Vishnu Vijayaraghavan <vishnu.vijayaraghavan@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi all,
>      I would like to set up  a start-up based on the Open Source Model
> in the near future. How effective will Open Source Model suit for
> enterpreneurship. What are the prerequsities to be satisfied before
> starting. I would also like to know about some of the most successful
> enterpreneur based on open source. Or to simply put up
>

Looks like your current model is..

1. Open Source
2. ???
3. Profit!

If you look at today's FOSS-world there's something called Open Source
2.0 happening. OpenSource 1.0 was companies like MySQL AB, RedHat.
OpenSource 2.0 is BlackDuck,CollabNet, SpikeSource, ActiveGrid and
Ubuntu. OpenSource 1.0 was all about creating Open Source products and
dual licensing it. Have one free version and have one with paid
support. The thing about Open Source 2.0 is you are now seeing
companies which are managing to re-package Open-Source and make it
enterprise ready. Choose which model you want to follow.

-Toufeeq
PS: I claim trademark for the "OpenSource 2.0" buzzword.
-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net

Which kind of thread you are using?.. Try using ftime() function which
is available under sys/timeb.h for getting milli seconds accuracy.

See man pages for more info.

From kums at gmx.net  Sun Sep 10 02:48:57 2006
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Sun Sep 10 02:49:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to configure Hathway Broadband Internet on Linux
References: adc51dea0609070750y4a6af6bfm882c258902c9c63e@mail.gmail.com
Message-ID: <45032FC1.4040006@gmx.net>


dineshraop wrote:

 >>  I tried configuring DSL Modem as well but that also does not work..
>  
>    I configured exactly  as you said but still I am not able to access 
> Internet.
>    I have entered the Static IP, Default Gateway, DNS servers all as root.
>    I have edited the file /etc/resolv.conf and placed DNS address (as 
> Administrator) as well.
>    I tried to ping the dns addresses given it says destination unreachable.
>    I have also enabled & disabled the network card eth0 and has 
> restarted the network again but no effect.
>    When I open up mozilla and type url as www.google.com and enter it 
> does not show up.
>    Do I need to do anything more.
> 
>    My Hathway setup works in Windows2000 very well.
> 
> Kindly help me. Thanks in advance.

Are you subscribed to DSL or Cable broadband? Putting my question in an 
another way, does Hathway even offer a DSL service?

I am a Hathway *Cable* Broadband subscriber for 2 years now and never 
had a problem with linux. The network config settings are exactly the 
same as in Windows. I am guessing that you haven't installed their 
'24Online authentication client' (this app authenticates every so often 
with their Cyberoam server for access to the internet). Ok, Here's a 
step-by-step guide.

1) Note your LAN settings setup for it in Windows.
    Your Static IP, the Gateway's IP address, subnet mask {mostly
    255.255.255.0} is all you need. The Gateway also runs a DNS server.
    so DNS Server IP = Gateway IP (just this one is enough)

2) Boot to Linux, configure your ethernet with the above settings.
    After this you should be able to ping your Gateway machine.
    If you can't, I will be mostly clueless.

3) Download the '24Online Linux authentication client'.
    You have 3 choices:

    a) Download it from somewhere on the internet (not recommended)

    b) Open your browser (most likely firefox), modify its useragent
       reporting to impersonate Internet Exploder and go to
       http://{your gateway IP here}/24online/webpages/myaccountlogin.jsp
       login with your account, and click the 'client' tab and look for
       the linux client download link (How Ironic!!!).

    c) Probably the easiest path -- ask me by mail. I have both the rpm
       package (got from PCQ Linux 2006 CDs) and the deb package (which I
       built myself using alien)

    d) Use an Open-Source alternative to the Cyberoam/24Online client:
	http://linc.sourceforge.net/ (Note: I haven't tried this!)


4) The client package doesn't come with an init/rc script -- if needed
    make your own! I personally run the app manually by hand everytime I
    need to connect. The very first time you try to login it will autorun
    configuration. Usually, I need to do something like..

   24onlineClient -u {YourUsername}

   and enter password when prompted. To logout:  24onlineClient -l


5) Once you are logged in, you should be able to connect to the
    Internet.


HTH!!!

Regards
Kumaraguru

--

From binand at gmail.com  Sun Sep 10 05:40:23 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Sep 10 09:10:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Entrepreneurship based on Open Source Model
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340609091154j66291998wa46c6d25332684a6@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
	<c293dd340609091154j66291998wa46c6d25332684a6@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609092040q763c5ebfrdaf334a8014c2d8c@mail.gmail.com>

On 09/09/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
> If you look at today's FOSS-world there's something called Open Source
> 2.0 happening. OpenSource 1.0 was companies like MySQL AB, RedHat.
> OpenSource 2.0 is BlackDuck,CollabNet, SpikeSource, ActiveGrid and
> Ubuntu. OpenSource 1.0 was all about creating Open Source products and
> dual licensing it. Have one free version and have one with paid
> support. The thing about Open Source 2.0 is you are now seeing
> companies which are managing to re-package Open-Source and make it
> enterprise ready.

You have several fundamental problems in your assumptions.

1. Dual licensing is NOT "one free version and one with paid support".
Dual licensing is what MySQL and Trolltech do - have one completely
GPL'ed version, and another non-GPL'ed version which can be used in
proprietary software products (remember, GPL forbids proprietary
licensing for software that builds upon GPL'ed software).

2. "Re-package OSS and make it enterprise-ready" is what Redhat has
been doing for years now, quite successfully at that.

3. The companies you cite as part of your 2.0 have been around for
years - Collab.Net has been around since the late nineties.

Binand
From binand at gmail.com  Sun Sep 10 05:42:22 2006

Message-ID: <dc538c3f0609092054v5b6681e5n43ba0dbfebc6e81c@mail.gmail.com>

hi

> Interesting that you consider Open Source as a business model, whereas
> in reality it is a software development model.
not necessarily it should be. Open Source as a business model is
different from software development model.

FYI, software development model says how software development should
happen. whereas open source business model is how to make money using
open source. so there's a lot of difference between business model and
development model.

--

From binand at gmail.com  Sun Sep 10 06:47:37 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Sep 10 10:34:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Entrepreneurship based on Open Source Model
In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f0609092054v5b6681e5n43ba0dbfebc6e81c@mail.gmail.com>

	<dc538c3f0609092054v5b6681e5n43ba0dbfebc6e81c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609092147o69ff1a35t9434c178910e789f@mail.gmail.com>

On 10/09/06, balachandar muruganantham <mbchandar@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Interesting that you consider Open Source as a business model, whereas
> > in reality it is a software development model.

> FYI, software development model says how software development should
> happen. whereas open source business model is how to make money using
> open source. so there's a lot of difference between business model and
> development model.

1. First of all, business models are not all about making money.
Revenue streams are only a part of any business model; not all of it -
in fact, I'd say the value proposition of a business model is what
makes it click.

2. Open source business model should ideally be a business model which
is open to everyone to change, copy, adopt and distribute :)

Binand

2. Open source business model should ideally be a business model which
> is open to everyone to change, copy, adopt and distribute :)


No, This is bad. The success depends on how strong you lay your Business
Model.When one enters Business, Money and Profit only speaks.The Business
Model should always be the Insiders thing and not Community driven, whereas
the Product can always be Community driven,

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Sep  9 23:16:38 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Sep 10 11:46:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Net,usb drive not working on Kubuntu 6.06
In-Reply-To: <72288b670609090718l134edb2cv2a89050bfbfac229@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060910061638.49456.qmail@web50207.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Vidhya Shankar,

--- Vidhya Shankar L <lv.shankar@gmail.com> wrote:
> ls -d /dev/sd* gives
> /dev/sda /dev/sda1 /dev/sda2 /dev/sda3 /dev/sda4
> sda1 -> ntfs
> sda2 -> linux-swap
> sda3 -> /boot
> sda4 -> /

These are your hard-disk partitions. 
 
> [  223.424298] usb 5-1: device not accepting address
> 2, error -110

When you plug-in your USB device, the device gets
enumerated, and the first step in this process is a
SET_ADDRESS command. This is failing with your USB
device.

>/bin/lsmod
> Module                  Size  Used by
> sg                     40368  0

SCSI generic driver.

> ehci_hcd               34184  0
> uhci_hcd               26904  0

USB Host controller drivers.

> usbcore               145844  3 ehci_hcd,uhci_hcd ->

USB support is available, but, I don't see your USB
mass-storage modules loaded. Try this as root:

  modprobe usb-storage
  modprobe sd-mod

and then plug in your USB device.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Sep  9 23:39:37 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Sep 10 12:09:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Photos] "Bioinformatics-FLOSS" workshop,
	Karpagam Arts and Science College, Coimbatore
Message-ID: <20060910063937.85461.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

Deepan Chakravarthy and myself conducted a one-day
workshop for the Bioinformatics department, Karpagam
Arts and Science College, Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu,
India on Saturday, September 9, 2006. The photos taken
during the workshop can be viewed from here:

 http://www.shakthimaan.com/Mambo/gallery/album37

I introduced them to FLOSS, and then Deepan spoke on
how FLOSS is useful in bioinformatics. He showed a
demo of emboss, and lot of other applications. I think
he can elaborate on that as I am not familiar with the
subject. After lunch, I gave a demo of the GNU/Linux
desktop environment, and also explained basic commands
that they can use in the console environment. Deepan
then continued with his demo of bioinformatics
applications and discussed about FLOSS projects at
bioinformatics.org.

The students/faculty were really enthusiastic, and
wanted follow-up sessions. I emphasized that they
should get started with setting up a FLOSS lab, and a
GNU/Linux user group on-campus. They are ready to
provide facilities, stay, food even if you want to
spend a week there, and give them hands-on training.
There are no distractions until October 5, 2006, after
which they have model exams, followed by holidays and
exams. 

I would like to thank Prof. Hemalatha for working with
us for the past couple of weeks in coordinating and
organizing this event. Special thanks to the
department faculty and management for the facilities
and hospitality offered.

Best regards,

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From dandolls at yahoo.co.in  Sun Sep 10 13:04:27 2006
From: dandolls at yahoo.co.in (amit saha)
Date: Sun Sep 10 17:34:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Communicating From User Space to Kernel Space
Message-ID: <20060910120430.57902.qmail@web7610.mail.in.yahoo.com>

struct rule{
         int proto;
          char source[15];
        }instance;

I have written this structure into a file in user space ,say rule.txt .
Say this file contains 10 records , i. e 10 instances of the above
structure.Now I would like to read the same file in kernel space by a
kernel module by reading 1 record at a time. How can i do this ?

Is there any other way to do this without using files ?  My objective
is to read the 10 records from kernel  space one record at a time and
not the individual bytes.


Amit Saha
  
http://amitsaha.in.googlepages.com

From srinivasg at esntechnologies.co.in  Sun Sep 10 18:33:21 2006
From: srinivasg at esntechnologies.co.in (Srinivas G.)
Date: Sun Sep 10 18:33:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] mkfs.msdos implementation in 2.6.16 kernel
Message-ID: <15C2CAD382CB69409395ED4F159BED700E1276@mail.esntechnologies.co.in>

Dear All,

 

I developed a small prototype for the block driver as given in the 16th
chapter of Alessandro Rubini book in 2.6.10 kernel and ported to
2.6.16.9 kernel.

 

Everything works fine except the ioctl part. When I issue commands like
mkfs.msdos and mkfs.vfat, the ioctl of the driver gets invoked in 2.6.10
but not in the 2.6.16.9.

 

I did strace on the command mkfs.msdos and noticed that the application
is issuing the 0x301 ioctl to the block layer which is returning with
the following error:

"Inappropriate ioctl to the device"

 

This error in turn is resulting in mkfs.msdos error.  The command says
"unable to get the disk geometry"

 

Can any one provide a pointer about the usage of the above two commands
in the 2.6.16.9 kernel.

 

Thanks and Regards,

Srinivas.

From dandolls at yahoo.co.in  Sun Sep 10 14:32:09 2006
From: dandolls at yahoo.co.in (amit saha)
Date: Sun Sep 10 19:02:25 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Communicating From User Space to Kernel Space
Message-ID: <20060910133209.82329.qmail@web7611.mail.in.yahoo.com>



Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote: On Sun, Sep 10, 2006 at 01:04:27PM +0100, amit saha wrote:
|struct rule{
|         int proto;
|          char source[15];
|        }instance;
|
|I have written this structure into a file in user space ,say rule.txt .
|Say this file contains 10 records , i. e 10 instances of the above
|structure.Now I would like to read the same file in kernel space by a
|kernel module by reading 1 record at a time. How can i do this ?
|
|Is there any other way to do this without using files ?  My objective
|is to read the 10 records from kernel  space one record at a time and
|not the individual bytes.
#include <"Std disclaimer: I am no kernel programmer".h>

Usually kernel code doesn't read files directly. It uses a helper
program running in  user space. If you are talking about reading user
memory from kernel space then I guess you are talking about mmap(2)

I think the standard approach is that of never making the kernel
do anything on its own save interrupt and other async
processing. Always the kernel acts on behalf of someone in user
space, IOW kernel code is always executed in user context. Don't
take this in the technical sense. I mean on behalf of a user
spaec process...

My two cents

Best,
Girish

Thanks for your prompt help. But,perhaps you didnt get me clearly.  I want some data which is generated by my user space program to be available to the kernel module. And i require the kernel module to be able to access those independently without requiring the intervention of a user process.

Any positive feedback wiil be acknowledged!


Amit Saha
  
http://amitsaha.in.googlepages.com
http://codejourno.blogspot.com

Hi Amit,

Don't do that. Please read:

By Greg Kroah-Hartman

I think Suman Adak is listening and will get back to u at the earliest. 

AFAIK mmap(2) will do what u want to do. Did you RTFM?

Once u setup the mapping then the kernel as well as user space can access the relevant pages. after that your kernel code I think driver can do whatever it wants with it.

From rs2003 at gmail.com  Sun Sep 10 21:16:54 2006
From: rs2003 at gmail.com (R.Subramanian (RS))
Date: Sun Sep 10 21:17:03 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Entrepreneurship based on Open Source Model
In-Reply-To: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7a7d6df30609100846t5d955a01n2f114aa4c316f5fe@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/9/06, Vishnu Vijayaraghavan <vishnu.vijayaraghavan@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
>     I would like to set up  a start-up based on the Open Source Model
> in the near future. How effective will Open Source Model suit for
> enterpreneurship. What are the prerequsities to be satisfied before
> starting. I would also like to know about some of the most successful
> enterpreneur based on open source. Or to simply put up
>
> How to set up an enterprise based on Open Source Model from scratch
> (for indian scenario)
>
> Pls. kindly help me.



Hey. This is Great.

Now to give a few tips:
A business model should make financially profits.
To start a business based on Oss first identify a business sector of your
interest / expertise.

Auction Business sector  : ( ex ebay)
Advertisement Business sector  : ex google / yahoo
Pure Information  Business sector   ( ex matrimonial web sites, )
Training & Education Business sector   :

The process should be first identify the business opportunity and then
capitalise on the opportunities using foss. Foss repositories may not have
all the components, You have to develop the missing links yourself . And may
be add them to the foss repository also.

You need to develop some good business knowledge in addition to technical
knowledge.
and need to have the vision to see emerging business opportunities.

jfyi the business revenue of  www.tamilmatrimony.com is  Rs 60 crores for
the year 2005. the site  was started around  10 years ago. there are a lot
of similar matrimony sites  started recently. not all of them make this kind
of money. In fact some of them have lost money and closed down.

so you need to have the visibility to see thro the future.
There may be  many similar opportunities today which  no one has noticed it
so far.
If you can spot an opportunity, then slowly build the idea, then you will
have crores of money flowing in 5 / 10 years from now.

you need to have the patience and the determination.
Not only Foss , all the successful businesses go thro these phases


Best of luck
From binand at gmail.com  Sun Sep 10 18:33:18 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Sep 10 22:03:28 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Communicating From User Space to Kernel Space
In-Reply-To: <20060910120430.57902.qmail@web7610.mail.in.yahoo.com>

On 10/09/06, amit saha <dandolls@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> Is there any other way to do this without using files ?  My objective
> is to read the 10 records from kernel  space one record at a time and
> not the individual bytes.

I think the best way for you to proceed is to implement an ioctl in
your kernel module, and call it from your user space program when you
have each record ready and populated.

Binand

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Mon Sep 11 06:41:50 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Mon Sep 11 06:42:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Net,usb drive not working on Kubuntu 6.06
In-Reply-To: <72288b670609100835v66876aeem72c78c1904dc71af@mail.gmail.com>
References: <72288b670609100835v66876aeem72c78c1904dc71af@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4504B7D6.2000104@frodo.hserus.net>

Vidhya Shankar L wrote:
> How can I mount/unmount my USB drives manually?
> When I chose 'Turn off computer' after some messages, it says 'Will now
> halt' and stays there. My box won't shutdown.
> The same happens with init 0. However, restart works perfectly.


6.06 somehow doesn't install the required debs for this.  Install dbus
and the related debs for it so that hald and dbus are started.

That will let you automount / remove usb devices, cdroms etc.
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Sep 10 19:58:27 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Sep 11 08:28:37 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Net,usb drive not working on Kubuntu 6.06
In-Reply-To: <72288b670609100835v66876aeem72c78c1904dc71af@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060911025827.18777.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Vidhya Shankar L <lv.shankar@gmail.com> wrote:
> modprobe usb-storage
> Nothing happened. Control returned to prompt

Your driver is loaded now. Check in output of:

  /sbin/lsmod | grep usb
 
> >modprobe sd-mod
> FATAL: sd storage not found

Looks like it is not set as M in your kernel. Search
for the module in /lib/modules/2.6-<version>.

> >and then plug in your USB device.
> nothing happened.

Always give complete information. See what
error/output messages you got in:

  /bin/dmesg | tail

SK

From mohan.tux at gmail.com  Mon Sep 11 10:03:36 2006
From: mohan.tux at gmail.com (Mohan Sundaram)
Date: Mon Sep 11 10:05:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Entrepreneurship based on Open Source Model
In-Reply-To: <7bf1bec50609090241n1caa8460rc59963932214adaa@mail.gmail.com>
References: <809586140609090023y130e557arb2d10565bd35df8e@mail.gmail.com>
	<7bf1bec50609090241n1caa8460rc59963932214adaa@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4504E720.5090706@gmail.com>

Mano wrote:
> On 9/9/06, Vishnu Vijayaraghavan <vishnu.vijayaraghavan@gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>> Hi all,
>>      I would like to set up  a start-up based on the Open Source Model
>> in the near future. How effective will Open Source Model suit for
>> enterpreneurship. What are the prerequsities to be satisfied before
>> starting. I would also like to know about some of the most successful
>> enterpreneur based on open source. Or to simply put up
>>
>> How to set up an enterprise based on Open Source Model from scratch
>> (for indian scenario)
>>
>> Pls. kindly help me.
>>
>>
> First thing to do before starting a venture is decide what product or
> service you wish to provide.  If you beleive that it is an irresistable
> product/service every other question or problem will be too trivial to 
> solve
> :-)
>
> regds,
> mano
+1.

A lot of mails have crossed on this subject. I believe, you need to be
clear where you want to be. Options are
1. Company that would make money by supporting and promoting usage of
OSS: This is a very viable business model. Given the over-distribution
practiced by guys like M$, sale of M$ products yield very low margins.
This prompts vendors to provide service and charge for it. This model is
no different except that S/w is OSS instead of M$ or other priced
products. Overall cost of ownership to the customer is lower. I used to
run a business on this model. It is very viable. you'll need to build
domain expertise in verticals and experiment, participate and contribute
to software that you pick to support. The selling of this service is not
as easy as a M$ vendor as you'd have to establish your credentials and
also provide comfort that OSS can do the job. The customer will be wary
of a single point support availability.

2. Build a product and publish a part/version of it in OSS like MySQL
and others do. Here your to success is building a good product. This is
a completely different ball game from the option above. You could make
money on a commercial version and/or support fees.

Mohan

From ilugsuman at gmail.com  Mon Sep 11 11:18:33 2006
From: ilugsuman at gmail.com (Suman Adak)
Date: Mon Sep 11 11:18:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Communicating From User Space to Kernel Space
In-Reply-To: <20060910140235.58045.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20060910120430.57902.qmail@web7610.mail.in.yahoo.com>
	<20060910140235.58045.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <ab4304140609102248k47b556c7m60b4b8cf38472596@mail.gmail.com>

hi Shakthi and all ,

Yes before that i read this article and implemented some bad coding which
has been showing on that article. Don't try this code in vendor's
kernel.InFC5 doesn't  export sys_open,sys_write system call. But a
fresh vanilla
kernel could do. The question was how to read file from user space to kernel
space efficiently .  And more ever i used to wonder how many configuration
files are being read by kernel? I tried to give answer as per my knowledge.
Please correct me

. More ever i and amit submitted one paper at ILUG-Delhi annual festival
Freedel 2006. It has been selected and amit is going to give talk. We have
proposed one host based intrusion detection and prevention system. Our
approach is like , User space will act as a detection system and gather
intrusion knowledge. After some time it will pass this info to kernel where
packets with intrusion would be blocked at IP layer.We are not thinking
about performance now. We just want to implement it. And yes i could read
the file using sys_open(), sys_read() kernel system call. But AFIK we had
several solution to do that job.
Might be amit has posted this to know better solution from other kernel
programmer.
1) implementing a char device and  ioctl() system call and creating /proc
entry
2) using kernel system call which has been exported by kernel
3)  create and use sysfs files within a kernel module.
4) using netlink socket.
[Sorry: All solutions have been suggested by other member. Thanks to all. I
just wrote it to summarize the whole things to keep in mind that later
anybody could get help from that].

But the question is that why we shouldn't read or write files in kernel
space? And what is the efficient way to do that?does kernel actually reads
or writes files?

The only one reason that i could find , "where" and "how" files would be
located and loaded . and it is policy decision in the linux community that
we shouldn't do. The problem is , where this config file lives? Is there any
particular location where all config file can stay and read by kernel. If i
am correct, the various same config file location could be different in
different distribution. So one my kernel module can run only one
distribution. It is not guaranteed that it will run in different
distribution.

And yes how to load the config files. May today u r using very simple file
but tomorrow you could use very complex database file and in that case
kernel doesn't have more flexibility to handle such file.

So many kernel hackers suggest not to read and write file in kernel space.
But what is the solution?

Yes as per my knowledge, We could do like
1) Implement file reading and writing in user space
2) communicate vis /proc entry.

 I can give some example
1.Mounting file system [ mount program reads config file /etc/fstab and
issue mount system call]

2.Netfilter filrewalls gets rule from user space application[iptables which
read the configuration file and communication with kernel via socket]
3. Many more.....


I think i should write one article with example.....hope i will finish as
early as possible..

Thanks
Suman

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Sep 11 01:04:34 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Sep 11 13:34:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Communicating From User Space to Kernel Space
In-Reply-To: <ab4304140609102248k47b556c7m60b4b8cf38472596@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060911080434.58415.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Suman and others,

--- Suman Adak <ilugsuman@gmail.com> wrote:
> And more ever i used to wonder
> how many configuration
> files are being read by kernel? 

Treat kernel as a resource manager. As a user you make
requests to the kernel, not force the kernel to do
things as you as a kernel developer would like it to
do. Freedom is always to the end user. 

> More ever i and amit submitted one paper at
> ILUG-Delhi annual festival
> Freedel 2006. It has been selected and amit is going
> to give talk. 

Congrats!

> But the question is that why we shouldn't read or
> write files in kernel
> space? 

"The most common problem is interpreting the data.
Writing a file interpreter from within the kernel is a
process ripe for problems, and any errors in that
interpreter can cause devastating crashes. Also, any
errors in the interpreter could cause buffer
overflows. These might allow unprivileged users to
take over a machine or get access to protected data,
such as password files.

Trying to protect the kernel from dumb programming
errors is not the most important reason for not
allowing drivers to read files."

http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/8110

>  I can give some example
> 1.Mounting file system [ mount program reads config
> file /etc/fstab and
> issue mount system call]

Yes, but, it is initiated by the end-user as a request
to the kernel, via a system call.

It is always the end-user or user daemons that make
requests to the kernel, and the kernel just services
it.

Regards,

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

__________________________________________________
Do You Yahoo!?
Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around 
http://mail.yahoo.com

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Tue Sep 12 11:10:06 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] FOSS text book
Message-ID: <A77A1B53-8C52-434A-85F7-CD4D5960690E@thenilgiris.com>

Hi,
As you all know Anna University has offered two FOSS elective  
subjects in the engineering and MCA streams. The syllabi for this has  
been drafted by NRC-FOSS and the textbook on elective 1 has been  
published. We are now writing the text book on elective 2. The draft  
of what is done so far is on our wiki here:

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/code/wiki/FossElectiveTwoBook

Please go through what has been done and add your contributions:
1. Correct spelling
2. Correct code errors
3. Add examples and explanations

In any place where there is a heading and no text, feel free to add  
text.

please mark your corrections and add your name also, you will be  
credited in the book if you do so. You do not need to log in to edit  
the wiki. Please help us make the text book a great success. And dont  
crib later if you didnt help now.

kg

From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Tue Sep 12 18:51:38 2006
From: toufeeqh at gmail.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Tue Sep 12 18:53:32 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] map rendering in linux
In-Reply-To: <056b01c6d66a$5d228a60$5c00000a@sripriyan>
References: <20060911174806.D9EBF1DB266@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<056b01c6d66a$5d228a60$5c00000a@sripriyan>
Message-ID: <c293dd340609120621p10477cfcx41b0f8c1e222b5fc@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 9/12/06, Sripriyan C <sripriyanc@amiindia.co.in> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> In a navigator project, I want to read shapefile (say chennai map) and show
> the map on the screen. For Window, .Net & WinCE we got activex
> controls; we can directly use. For linux i am searching for such a control.
> I searched my best, but could not find any :(
> Any input from you will help.

Convert Shapefile to SVG ?

http://www.carto.net/papers/svg/utils/shp2svg/

Then use GTK's ImageView widget to display the image ?
If Gtk's Image View doesn't support SVG, use Gtk-MozEmbed, which is
based on Gecko and should render the SVG file.

-Toufeeq

-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Wed Sep 13 02:21:12 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Wed Sep 13 02:21:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] information management tools -- redux
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609121351j4e369043rbe1552a7a87af983@mail.gmail.com>

Hi All,

A while ago, I asked what people use for knowledge/information
management.  The original post is here:
    http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/pipermail/ilugc/2006-May/026024.html

I've hit on the perfect tool for my needs -- Wikidpad.
    http://wikidpad.python-hosting.com/

Wikidpad claims to be "an IDE for your thoughts", and for me
it has lived up to the claim.  There are still a few rough
edges (I'm using 1.7RC1), and some missing features (inability
embedd external files/photos, collaboration, etc).  But the
flexible tagging system and easy interface makes it an
exceptionally useful tool.

If you suffer from information overload, I urge you to
give it a try.


Btw, Danny O'Brien's Life Hacks talk from:
    http://quernstone.com/notcon04/
is entertaining as well as enlightening.

- Raja

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Wed Sep 13 11:23:01 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Wed Sep 13 11:25:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] add/remove programs in FC5
In-Reply-To: <3a2d02840609122226o7248818asb5c5f9ca6c1ecd89@mail.gmail.com>
References: <3a2d02840609122226o7248818asb5c5f9ca6c1ecd89@mail.gmail.com>

From mohan.tux at gmail.com  Wed Sep 13 11:35:39 2006
From: mohan.tux at gmail.com (Mohan Sundaram)
Date: Wed Sep 13 11:37:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Configuring Sendmail
In-Reply-To: <727912d50609120054w652614cel3d061f7be4251147@mail.gmail.com>
References: <727912d50609120054w652614cel3d061f7be4251147@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <45079FB3.4010009@gmail.com>

Vinayak Mahadevan wrote:
> Dear Luggies
> 
> I would like to know as to how to configure sendmail so as to prevent
> certain email ids from sending mails to other addresses which are not there
> in my domain.
> 
> Regards
> 
By default, sendmail will accept mails from/to the domains it is 
configured for. You can use the access database to specify which email 
IDs from/to are allowed to relay - use the /etc/mail/access file. 
Assuming sendmail 8.12 upwards.

I've not used it to specify combinations of From/To addresses. I know 
the LHS tags can be used but am not sure if you can use two LHS tags per 
line for action. Since it is a hash table, I doubt it.

I'd do this by using the SMTP auth mechanism. Create a separate 
uid/password auth mechanism in PAM for SMTP and put in only those users 
for whom you want to allow external relaying. Use the access db to allow 
only To:<your domain>.

Mohan
From srini.it at gmail.com  Wed Sep 13 14:00:03 2006
From: srini.it at gmail.com (Srinivasan Sundararajan)
Date: Wed Sep 13 14:00:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] LUG at Vellore Institute of Technology
Message-ID: <328077850609130130t6ded2817n24737b984a84f65f@mail.gmail.com>

Dear friends:
The LUG at Vellore Institute of Technology (VIT) was started during
the visit of RMS -- I think couple of years back. It has been
sporadically active and the current members are keen to be
continuously active. They are well supported by Prof Ganesan who has
also set up a Linux lab in the computer department. They are also
having Linux in B.E., and FOSS subjects in masters programmes.

While the plan is to have FOSS workshops, LDDs, projects, etc. they
have informed me that
quote
the L.U.G at VIT has decided to spread awareness on free software
through a meeting on the 16th inst. We have also seriously taken up
the work of determining areas of interest to pursue projects.
Furthermore we will be glad to establish contact with any member of
the L.U.G Chennai and seek his assistance.
unquote

They are keen to have a presence of at least one member from ILUG-C on
16th -- the function can be in the morning for an hour or two.
Interested members could contact:
Mr. Ambuj Thacker, ambuj.mbp@gmail.com

(** Bharathi: would you be free? raman will try to make it just for
the morning, if nobody else is available).

Thanks and best wishes, Srinivasan.

From sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in  Wed Sep 13 13:23:11 2006
From: sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in (sriram)
Date: Wed Sep 13 18:54:21 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Suggestions for software in IITM mirror
References: <20060908072046.GA4453@localhost>
	<4501210B.2050209@fedoraproject.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609081358220.20875@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <loom.20060913T151117-563@post.gmane.org>

Prof. P. Sriram <sriram@...> writes:
[solicited suggestions for iitm mirror]

ubuntu and freebsd seem to be viable additions (there were also suggestions for
alternate architectures like ppc, arm etc; it would be a stretch for me to
justify - remember, the mirror is primarily a resource for iitm and we dont mind
sharing the contents with others as long as the bandwidth is available). i dont
use ubuntu or freebsd, so i need some help with pruning the contents - the
ubuntu mirror is around 100gb and freebsd is over 300gb. in contrast, our
current debian mirror is about 45gb, centos is about 25gb and others like
fedora, redhat, mandrake etc are around 10-12 gb each. if some kindly soul would
suggest as to what i can prune from the freebsd and ubuntu trees, i can get on
this. please dont make conceptual suggestions like exclude all but 386
architecture - give me something that applies directly to the distribution in
question (if you want to be really kind, give me a set of excludes for use in
rsync). lets make the mirror more useful.

sriram

This should be useul for Ubuntu:

http://www.mail-archive.com/uug-list@uug.byu.edu/msg17250.html

However, I guess we can't become the official mirror for Ubuntu unless
we mirror all architectures.

I couldn't find much about FreeBSD mirror setup. However, I did notice
that they have neatly separated the architecture setup. For example,
it may be sufficient to just mirror for the latest releasr from the
following sites:

ftp://ftp.is.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/releases/i386/ (for the release,
packages etc.)

ftp://ftp.is.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/ports/i386/ (for the ports).

However, more experienced FreeBSD users may be able to suggest better
ways.

Kumar
-- 
Kumar Appaiah

First of all we as a community are immensely indebted to you. No words can show the gratitude we owe to you. Having resources is one, willing to share it for the common good quite another.

Anyway let me come to the point. I can take over the FreeBSD and Ubuntu mirroring if that is your decision. To me the decision seems quite fair. I would love to learn the steps involved in a live mirror setup.

FreeBSD I guess is the largest OS out there and there are plenty of binary blobs and huge source trees that build automatically. It has plenty of compatibility layers and stuff like that.

Please let me know if my coming there is acceptable to you. If not I will try to help you out with the necessary stuff remotely. I will have to do some research on pruning for instance.

On 9/13/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
> First of all we as a community are immensely indebted to you. No words can show the gratitude we owe to you. Having resources is one, willing to share it for the common good quite another.

This is not to belittle any contributions, but...

IIT-M gets significant funding from the Government, which is
in turn funded by the tax payers (you, me, and the public).
Any morally binding organisation that is Govt funded (of
which IIT-M is a fine example) *owes* it to society to
make its resources available for the common good.

I can't think of *any* other educational institution, Govt
funded or private, that would be interested/capable of
running a LUG in the fine manner it's being run all these
years.  There is no one else.  It is IIT-M's *duty* to
do support the LUG.

That said, the mirror space offered is highly appreciated.

- Raja

From sundaram at fedoraproject.org  Thu Sep 14 01:57:20 2006
From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul)
Date: Thu Sep 14 01:57:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] add/remove programs in FC5
In-Reply-To: <ab4304140609130433t3bf32098i16d1f25244293300@mail.gmail.com>
References: <3a2d02840609122226o7248818asb5c5f9ca6c1ecd89@mail.gmail.com>	<45079CBD.6020106@gmail.com>
	<ab4304140609130433t3bf32098i16d1f25244293300@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <450869A8.3090504@fedoraproject.org>

Suman Adak wrote:

> ...We just need to search the program name in YaST[in one module],YaST will
> search the packages from list of CD(It depends on the configuration of the
> your Installlation source. U need to just deselct the all other network
> source]. YaST resolves the dependencies and just ask for the particular
> CD...I don't need to dump 5 FC5 CD with my box...
> 
> I think mahesh is asking this things and me also. Beacause i don't have
> internet at my home system. And franckly speaking why FC5 removed this
> feature as it was with FC4.

Not removed as much as rewritten. System-config-packages in previous 
versions does not work with repositories at all. Pirut is yum based and 
Yum needs some work to work with media in a better way. This is being 
tracked on https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=188750 
and is a FC6 blocker.

> i am thinking why should we not start a project which i can offer mixed
> power of yaST[Installtion module and yum [ But i don't know of these
> application programming python,qt, etc..].........
>

That would be duplicating work already being done.

Rahul
From girish1729 at gmail.com  Thu Sep 14 08:33:04 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Sep 14 08:33:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Pruning FreeBSD...
Message-ID: <20060914030304.GA30918@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Sep 13, 2006 at 01:03:13PM -0400, Brian Reichert wrote:
> On Wed, Sep 13, 2006 at 08:45:29PM +0530, Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> > 	However we are concerned about the size of 300GB. Is there a way by which we can prune certain "unnecesssary" or let me put it this way, less frequently downloaded stuff?
> 
> Depending on how you mirror (rsync, CVSup, etc.), you can craft exclude
> clauses to avoid what you want.

You can almost certainly drop the ia64 packages without anyone
noticing, but you should really try to mirror the full i386 and amd64
sets.  sparc64 is probably lower use, but still worth mirroring if you
can (at least 6.x and 7.x).

Kris

Dear Sriram,

     (I sent an e-mail yday to freebsd-hubs@freebsd.org for our problem.
      I am attaching the response here.)

     Nobody gave me specifics or numbers as you can see, but at least this much I am able to guess that we can get a lot below the 300 GB number.

     I am just curious, are you concerned about the disk space (which is peanuts these days) or the bandwidth? As CVSup is really efficient once you download the entire thing. It only patches deltas.

     Because though FreeBSD distribution is large the number of ppl downloading it going to be minuscule compared to linux. So whichever way you look at it I don't see bandwidth hog an issue here.

     Please correct me if I am wrong here.

     Anyway I am waiting for you to get back to me on how to proceed.

regards,
Girish

----- End forwarded message -----

-- 
Whenever people agree with me I always feel I am wrong.

    - Oscar Wilde

Message-ID: <92f9a9560609140111w636be468m3956edcf42ceaa72@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/14/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 13/09/06, Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Any morally binding organisation that is Govt funded (of
> > which IIT-M is a fine example) *owes* it to society to
> > make its resources available for the common good.
>
> Careful with that axe, Raja...
>
> What next? That IIT auditoria should be available for use of the
> "people's representatives" for their rallies, meetings, demonstrations
> etc.? :)

LOL!

It all depends on the interpretation of "common good".  And by
any interpretation, the people's representatives don't count :-)

Nearly all government funded universities overseas have Community
Outreach Programs or atleast Open Days which contribute to the
"greater good".  For example, NASA for has several outstanding
community outreach programs that target schools and colleges.
And these are all official programs mandated and approved by
the Govt and funding agencies.

Btw, an excellent example a useful mirror is AARNet.  It's a
non-profit organisation run by 37 universities and CSIRO to
provide a huge mirror with fast access within Australia (from
most Australian universities, aarnet is faster than a local
cdrom).  mirror.aarnet.edu.au was (and probably still is) the
largest and most used mirror site in the Asia/Pac region.

Would be nice to see IIT-M's mirror being the start of something
like AARNet :-)

- Raja

From raamanp at yahoo.co.in  Thu Sep 14 09:55:07 2006
