Date: Thu Sep 14 14:25:25 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Software Freedom Day - 16th Sep 2006 - Invitation
Message-ID: <20060914085507.42989.qmail@web7908.mail.in.yahoo.com>

Hello All,

*Software Freedom Day 2006 Celebration *
*
Date :    16-Sep-2006
Time :    6.30 pm to 8.30 pm
Venue :  Asiad - Rohini Park
              Asiad Colony (between Thirumangalam Signal
              and Anna nagar- West bus stand) 
              Anna Nagar - West,
              Chennai 600101

Programme :
6:30    -   Welcome Address
6:35 - 7:10   -    Why Software Freedom, What is FOSS & Who we are ?
7:15 - 7:45   -   Live Demo of Linux Desktop, Open Office,    
                   Browsers,Mail Clients
7:50 - 8:00   -   3D Desktop
8:00 - 8:15   -   Introduction of Educational Softwares 
                  - Astronomy,Maths, Chemistry

                    Games for Kids
8:15 - 8:30   -   Q & A

**Organised by : 
Indian Linux User Groups - Chennai - www.chennailug.org 
and 
Lynus Academy, Chennai (www.lynusacademy.com)

**All are Welcome, Entry Free

What is Software Freedom Day ?
*Software Freedom Day (SFD) is a worldwide celebration of Free and
Open
Source Software (FOSS). Our goal in this celebration is to educate
the
worldwide public about of the benefits of using high quality FOSS in
education, in government, at home, and in business -- in short,
everywhere! The non-profit company Software Freedom International
provides guidance in organizing SFD, but volunteer teams around the
world organize their own SFD events to impact their own communities.

*Whom should attend ?
*Home Users, Internet Users, Schools students, College Students, IT
Professionals, Office System Users.

Contact persons: Saravanan A, +919840880558
                 Raman P, +919884115970


for More Information about :
Indian Linux User Groups - Chennai - www.chennailug.com
Software Freedom Day 2006 - www.softwarefeedomday.org*
*

syncing the cvs tree every hour. the total size of the tree is given as
2.x gb. but, where is it? i do see a cvsup directory, but i dont think
that is THE cvs tree. this is why i suggested someone who uses freebsd
might be able to make better sense of the tree structure and recommend
which directories to mirror and which to skip so as to get a usable mirror
that is, say, less than 50gb in size.

Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Suggestions for software in IITM mirror
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0609152210420.24793@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
References: <20060908072046.GA4453@localhost>	<4501210B.2050209@fedoraproject.org>	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609081358220.20875@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>	<loom.20060913T151117-563@post.gmane.org>
	<450AC309.5030608@gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609152210420.24793@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <450B4799.5060801@frodo.hserus.net>

cvsup is a tool that gets you the freebsd OS source cvs tree, and the
ports tree

So you get source to build the base OS, and you get a ports tree - a
bunch of software ported to bsd but the tree just has makefiles,
location + md5sum of various source tarballs, a list of OS specific patches

Prof. P. Sriram wrote:

http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/bsd/2001/08/16/Big_Scary_Daemons.html?page=1
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/bsd/2001/08/16/Big_Scary_Daemons.html?page=2

<quote>
If you have the hardware and the bandwidth to donate, contact Polstra at 
jdp@freebsd.org. Include your location, as he tries to balance mirrors 
by geography. If your area is short on mirrors and you fit his other 
requirements, he might take you up on it. John chooses the mirror sites 
carefully, balancing the needs against the locations offered and the 
capacity. "I would be unlikely to allow 30 mirror sites in, say, 
Iceland," he says.
</quote>
Why don't you please write to jdp@freebsd.org ?  He is the author of 
CVSup and also manages issues with the worldwide freebsd mirrors.
From girish1729 at gmail.com  Sat Sep 16 08:22:50 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sat Sep 16 08:23:11 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Suggestions for software in IITM mirror
In-Reply-To: <450B4799.5060801@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <20060908072046.GA4453@localhost>
	<4501210B.2050209@fedoraproject.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609081358220.20875@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<loom.20060913T151117-563@post.gmane.org>
	<450AC309.5030608@gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609152210420.24793@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<450B4799.5060801@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <20060916025250.GA5930@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Sat, Sep 16, 2006 at 06:08:49AM +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
|cvsup is a tool that gets you the freebsd OS source cvs tree, and the
|ports tree
|
|So you get source to build the base OS, and you get a ports tree - a
|bunch of software ported to bsd but the tree just has makefiles,
|location + md5sum of various source tarballs, a list of OS specific patches

Couple of points here.

  a) The ports tree does not come with source of course. It is the job of the Makefile rule to fetch the source from various sources. It could even be the FreeBSD mirror itself. But on a FreeBSD machine, the ports directory simply contains as Suresh rightly mentioned, only the Makefile( which is very very small since it includes majority of its macros from a master makefile), and the URLs for different locations for the same source and its MD5 sum. Once u hit make or make install inside say /usr/ports/net/netcat or something, it downloads the original source either from soureforge or elsewhere as the case may be, checks the integrity with size and checksum, unpacks it, applies the FreeBSD specific patches, then compiles and installs.

  Of course, you can tune certain parameters like which library to link against, what should be the database backend etc. using make config. But in most cases it doesnt bother u with questions since most ports have sensible default options already set.

  Sorry for the digression. I just wanted to clear the point that the ports tree doesnt actually have sources apiori.

   b) This is the most important point. CVSup may have been written for FreeBSD but it is by no means restricted to FreeBSD at all. It is just a network efficient tool for syncing CVS sources since it understands CVS quite well. It is a good improvement on the stupid network protocol of CVS. I have used CVSup only on Debian so far ironically. I used to use both CVSup and rsync for synching my sources and backing up the CVS repository with a cron job. 

   Now, CVSup has two modes of operation, one in which it replicates the CVS repository itself and another in which it syncs the source checked out of CVS.

   I am not really sure how CVSup compares to rsync. It  looks as though CVS uses rsync on its backend. rsync actually is quite generic for syncing any sort of data, as it is a mathematical algo whereas CVSup works at a higher level for synchig CVS trees.

   And to add to the confusion I see lot of discussions on the mailing lists about portsnap being the latest tool for the job of CVSup and that CVSup is obsolete. :-)

   I think we should just forget about CVSup and look at portsnap. It certainly is going to kill CVSup just like how ssh(1) killed  the insecure dinosaur telnet(1).

   Just google for portsnap. I think we should be using portsnap for syncing the mirrors too. I will do more digging and get back on that.

   So long,
   Girish

From srini.it at gmail.com  Sat Sep 16 17:40:30 2006

Date: Sat Sep 16 17:40:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FOSS Migration related studies
Message-ID: <328077850609160510u221a5e42n452194dd722f7423@mail.gmail.com>

Dear friends: NRCFOSS has been involved in promoting migration to FOSS
-- equivalents for proprietary products for a variety of applications
.

At present, we are gathering information on equivalents for products
like Auto CAD, Auto Desk (3Ds Max, Maya, Flame, Combustion, etc.),
Adobe Photoshop / Studio, 3-D/Visual effects products like Furnacs,
Anvil, Silhouette, PFTrack, etc.

We plan to prepare brief writeups / comparative reports on the
proprietary and the equivalent FOSS products. Those interested in this
exercise are requested to contact me at
srinivasan@au-kbc.org   /  94443 02439.

Thanks and best wishes, Srinivasan.

Dear friends,

We celebrated software freedom day at asiad colony ,chennai on sept 16 06.
It was indeed a fabulous meet we had. Our team had good chemistry at work. I
thank the team ,Mr.Saravanan (ASAN) for sponsoring this event through his
organisation (financially,morally and physically).       Mr. Raman ,
Volunteers from JEC and  Mr.Saravanan were on with heavy preparation right
from tieing the banners to organising the event,The office assistant of
lynus academy needs a kudos for his contribution, guyz showed excellent
character of work culture.

We started the event by 6:25( 5 minutes before the intended time) with
Tamizh thai vazhuthu( The prayer song) anchored by  Jaya Engg College
volunteers, Mr. Raja and myself  played a skit as a lay man asks questions
regarding with open source to a consultant. I played the role of a lay man
and Raja lived in the role of an opensource consultant. The program went on
with demos for kids, We had visitors from  UK and USA, Mr.Raman gave
inspirational explanatory speech on opensoure. The Twin brothers of ilugc
Mr.Srinivasan and Mr.Bala Vignesh demoed the  3d desktop. SRM college
student gave a demo on open office. we had quizzes for the audience.I  gave
the vote of thanks and  with National anthem we summed the  festival.

We had a good time. I will upload the photos in a day or two, I thank the
oppurtunity and the team for the contribution and commitment.


Cheers,

Thyagarajan shanmugham

From rajaramcomputers at hotmail.com  Mon Sep 18 17:12:49 2006
From: rajaramcomputers at hotmail.com (ramkumar lakshminarayanan)
Date: Mon Sep 18 22:43:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] SFD @ mahadanapuram
Message-ID: <BAY116-F33427B547C278C98AC2FE2DD2D0@phx.gbl>

   Software Freedom Day Celebration At Mahadanapuram.

   Our Software Freedom Day Celebration Started on August 15, (Independence
   Day of India).
   To Celebrate the event from the grass root we started giving computer
   training program to  school students of the follwing Schools.
   1. Government High School, Theethampalayam, Mahadanapuram,
   2. Government High School, Mettu Mahadanapuram,
   3. Government Higher Secondary School, Krishnarayapuram.
   4. Sri.M.V. Muthu krishna Iyer Industrial Training Institute,
   Mahadanapuram.

   Some of the Newspapers has written articles about SFD Celebrations are as
   follows.

   1. Dinamalar
   2. Kalai Kathir
   3. Daily Thanthi
   4. Dinamani
   5. Indian Express.

   On the day of SFD, the students were given demo of using Ubuntu and other
   FOSS Software.

   We prepared around 2000 pamphlets about the SFD celebration and
   distributed it.

   Since our centre is located in village, our team decided to form a free
   computer game centre to create more interest among the students.

   We inaugurated a Free Computer Game Centre named " Rajaram Siruvargal
   Video Game Ulagam"

   The session started with the prayer.

   Mr. Jaganathan, Principal, Sri. M.V.M ITI gave a brief introduction about
   computers and its uses.

   Mr. Rajasekaran, Vice Principal Sri MVM ITI gave a lecture about
   utilisation of computers in industrial Training Institute.

   Mr. Rajaram, wished that there should be lot of support from city and
   international groups for making the technolgy to reach the village.

   Mr. L.Ramkumar, Organiser SFD, Mahadanpuram gave the ideas of Software.
   then he told about What is Software Freedom and what are the reasons for
   celebrating Software Freedom Day.

   Mr. Mathivannan, Regional Director, Lexicon Training Academy told his
   experience with software monopoly and he conveyed Software Freedom is
   necessary for India.

   Mr. Muthukumar asked the student community to create their own open source
   software which should help others for future development.

   Dr. Meena, Cheif Guest relesed the Ubuntu CD for public distribution.

   She described briefly about the neccessity of Software Freedom. She
   distributed nearly 100 Certificate to the students and public participated
   in the Computer Awareness Camp.

   Around 500 members of different age group and sector witnessed and shared
   their thoughts in the Software Freeom Day Celebration at Mahadanapuram.

   The media persons made visit to Schools and wrote a brief article before
   and after the celebration.

   The Students, Government Officials, Teachers, Public Participated with
   enthu and SFD 2006 has spread the message of Software Freedom.

   Make a Visit to Mahadanapuram and share your software thoughts.
    
    
   Regds,
    
   L.Ramkumar

From girish1729 at gmail.com  Tue Sep 19 06:06:57 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Sep 19 06:07:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] day to day Doubts..
In-Reply-To: <2d0135b0609181339w1ed74ca6r8c86e7179ee71084@mail.gmail.com>
References: <2d0135b0609181339w1ed74ca6r8c86e7179ee71084@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060919003657.GA18695@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Tue, Sep 19, 2006 at 02:09:06AM +0530, raja sekar wrote:
|hi sens
|
|i hav following doubts and problems that have been encountered during the
|course of my proj and regular use.
|
|1.difference between locate and find command.
locate uses a static database updated from cron. I think most linux distros run it once a day at nite. which means that unless u update it manually with updatedb run as root, u will not find recently deleted or created files.

find works in real time and can be painfully slow since it has lot of work to do. so unless u r looking for needles in a haystack find is for u.
|2 in ctime(3) what does 3 in the parentheses signify.
3 is the man page section. this is to avoid confusion in cases where socket(1) and socket(2) are two diff things. One is a shell command and another is a system call. Read man man to know more about what each section contains. You can also do a "man 2 intro" or a "man 3 intro" on a decent linux distro to know what each section is supposed to contain. 

Also there are cases where the same program is split into multiple man pages , for instance, when i do an "apropos cron", i get several pages and crontab(1) and crontab(5) both refer to diff parts of the same program. 
|3.  give a simple sample code that uses to find the time of execution of
|thread (thread created using the pthread.h)
	I wonder why you guys are so hung up with threads. Real UNIX never had any threads and never will have. fork() is the way to go. Multi threaded programs are buggy and crash often. I know nobody in this list will appreciate this fact but this is the truth. 
|4.whenever i boot debian linux the esd starts running automatically and
|gives sound ,for which i goto th e terminal and kill it every time.
|Is there a way to stop this?what config file should ideal with.
My debian doesnt do that. Maybe ur using gnome? ESD is gnome sound daemon. I think sound daemons like esd and arts are used for software mixing and other cool audio mixing stuff. Never got the time to play with it. 

But I dont know the answer to ur question. sorry.
|
|5)the concept of I-node
Pick up any book on UNIX and u will know the answer. Even google will help. It is very simple. It is nothing but the index of a file. In UNIX file systems like ffs, ufs, ext*fs etc., files are represented as a doubly linked liston disk. And i-nodes are linked list node identifiers. Simple and straight. Of course, files mean directories too.
|6)Is there any limit for the number of args that can be passed to the shell
What do u mean passed to shell? Shell is also a userland program like any other. It has no special privileges. Generally there is a limit on the buffer size of command line arguments enforced by the C compiler or something else. I dont know where the limit comes from ,but u cant pass a 1024 char long string on the command line. It will cause a buffer overflow.

Number of args purely depends on the program in question. 

RTFM getopt(1).
|7what is the use of sticky bit .
It is a theoretical concept not used much practically. sticky is often used in the context of CVS tags. It is used in file permissions to signify something, I dont remember, pick up a book and find out. Or RTFM chmod(1) or chattr(1)
|8)give me simple recursion program explaining how the values are viewed thru
|gdb,,using all possible commands such as setting breakpoint,backtrace,step
|over and so on.

I dont use gdb much. I prefer using printf() for debugging. You can set breakpoints easily using the command "b <line>" or "b <function>". Very easy to use. 

You can use bt or where to backtrace after a crash. Two steps are useful, step and next, which is abbreviated as s and n.

Simple recursion program? what do u mean? recursion is a theoretical concept not used much in practice. It finds use during directory traversal and other such niche areas where recursion is an elegant way to solve problems. Usually real life doenst demand much recursion. :-)
|9)The differnce b/w simple bidirectional and cascaded pipe..along with a
|simple code..(some confusion already)
	I dont know what u mean. I know only unidirectional pipe as the man page for pipe clearly mentions that pipe is a unidirectional channel for communication between related processes.

	I know that perl supports some bidirectional pipe using two pipes,maybe u r talking some advanced stuff I dont know. But pipes have always been unidirectional. If there are variants, they may be built on top of the basic thing, not in exclusion of it.
|10) how to send a message from
|                            i)one linux system to another running linux
|.(provided n/w are all well configured)
	You can use write(1) or talk(1). talk is junk , so ur better off running an irc server. Or use mail to send mail bet users. Noadays ppl simply use something like yahoo! or jabber even for local chat. Not an ugly solution IMHO.
|                            ii)system in windows to linux .
yahoo! seems to be a good idea. If u dont have internet, u can of course do a ssh and use linux mechanisms or use one of Windoze clients for the above.
|                     list the package or utility  and steps to follow
|clearly and briefly
|
|11) how to rename some 1000 files in a dir with *.txt to *.htm  (tried mv
|*.txt *.htm --> not working)
yes, move does not work with shell patterns. For good reason, if you were to write mv, how would u do it. You have to write a simple script like this.
for i in *
do
 j=`echo $i | cut -d'.' -f1`
 mv $j.txt $j.htm
done
|
|thanks in advance
|regds
|Rajasekar
Wish u all the best in ur UNIX journey!

regards,
Girish
|

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Tue Sep 19 14:23:41 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Tue Sep 19 14:23:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [job] Antispam operations - Outblaze Limited
Message-ID: <450FB015.5080308@frodo.hserus.net>

Well, as there are several job reqs posted today, I'll post one too.

I manage the antispam operations at Outblaze (http://www.outblaze.com) -
we're a Hong Kong based company and do antispam filtering and/or email
hosting for some of the largest webmail / ISP services in the world
(such as mail.com in the USA, and rediffmail, indiainfo in India)

We're shortly setting up an office here in Madras and are recruiting a
few good people to start with.  There's an initial requirement of two
freshers to do tier 1 email responses on our abuse desk [aka: receive
spam complaints from people about our users, and shut down the accounts
caught spamming.

The job will actually require a decent amount of competency in using
linux as a desktop, preferably some competence in using a console based
mail reader like mutt.  Also, basic skills in shell, mysql etc to
automate certain of your tasks as you go on.

One absolute requirement is excellent spoken and written English
communication skills - by which I mean English that is standard,
grammatically correct, without either

1. Messenger / IRC spelling ("hai. how r u")

2. Outdated Wren and Martin style or "Indian business english" ("I will
revert back to you regarding this")

Please send me your CVs in plain text format [no word, openoffice, pdf,
html etc please] - send these to suresh@outblaze.com

To others around: If you can do more than this, and have a better than
average understanding for this list of SMTP, DNS, mysql / c / perl
skills, AND have excellent english spoken and written skills, of course,
please do send me your CVs as well.  There are various other positions
open if we find the right people to fill them.

All these jobs are based in Madras.

regards
srs

-- 
suresh ramasubramanian suresh@outblaze.com gpg # EDEDEFB9
manager, security & antispam operations, outblaze limited

From binand at gmail.com  Tue Sep 19 11:19:29 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Tue Sep 19 14:49:41 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] day to day Doubts..
In-Reply-To: <20060919003657.GA18695@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <2d0135b0609181339w1ed74ca6r8c86e7179ee71084@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060919003657.GA18695@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609190219i3cdc45b0w77374e5c7fba91fe@mail.gmail.com>

On 19/09/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
> I wonder why you guys are so hung up with threads. Real UNIX never had any threads
> and never will have. fork() is the way to go. Multi threaded programs are buggy and
> crash often. I know nobody in this list will appreciate this fact but this is the truth.

Do you mean:

a. fork()ing programs do not crash?
b. The fact that a few programs are buggy is enough to ridicule
threads entirely?

What do you mean by "Real UNIX"? POSIX - an IEEE standard for Unix
operating systems - has a standard for threads. Does that mean POSIX
is not "Real UNIX"?

> It is a theoretical concept not used much practically. sticky is often used in the context of CVS tags.

Hmm. Ever looked at ls -ld /tmp ? In fact, I don't remember ever
encountering sticky bit in the context of CVS. Maybe you are confused
between the sticky bit and the setuid/setgid bits?

> recursion is a theoretical concept not used much in practice.

Can you spell DNS??

>         I know that perl supports some bidirectional pipe using two pipes,maybe u r talking some advanced stuff I dont know. But pipes have always been unidirectional. If there are

POSIX specifies a pipe(2) system call for bidirectional pipes.
Implementations might choose a pair of unidirectional pipes, but that
is irrelevant.
From deepakd at midascomm.com  Tue Sep 19 14:58:09 2006
From: deepakd at midascomm.com (Deepak)
Date: Tue Sep 19 14:55:27 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to execute tftp to transfer file(s)
In-Reply-To: <450FB0BC.7090606@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <450FB0BC.7090606@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <450FB829.8040402@midascomm.com>

Hi,
I need to transfer some files from remote PC using tftp (don't want to 
use rsync/ftp/scp or more).
I have enabled tftp in both PCs using 'ntsysv' and making "disable=no" 
in /etc/xinetd.d/tftp file.
Both PCs are reachable. But tftp is not working as i followed simple 
syntax given in man page.

Do i need to start any service? I tried 'service in.tftpd status' but it 
is displaying error: Unrecognized servce.
Pls reply the following queries:
i)  How can I use tftp?
ii) What is the maximum file size i can transfer?
iii) Any idea, How this mechanism works in UDP?
iv) Some more practical inputs/usage/links/limitations.
v) Any information about transfer speed and System load?

I am not sure about the validity of query (iii) as I have only read from 
net.

Thanks & Regards,
Deepak Dikshit

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Tue Sep 19 15:38:35 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Tue Sep 19 15:37:34 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to execute tftp to transfer file(s)
In-Reply-To: <450FB829.8040402@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0609191526070.32750-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

On Tue, 19 Sep 2006, Deepak wrote:

> I need to transfer some files from remote PC using tftp (don't want
> to use rsync/ftp/scp or more).

You are in B and want to TFTP a file from A, then TFTP must be running
in A & need to specify the tftp src location in /etc/xinetd.d/tftp

Example: server_args = -s /tftpboot/dir/

and place the "file" in /tftpboot/dir/. 

U@B> $ tftp HostA
  tftp> get myfile
  Received 2148699 bytes in 1.4 seconds
  tftp> exit
U@B> $

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

From girish1729 at gmail.com  Tue Sep 19 15:40:12 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Sep 19 15:40:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to execute tftp to transfer file(s)
In-Reply-To: <450FB829.8040402@midascomm.com>
References: <450FB0BC.7090606@frodo.hserus.net>
	<450FB829.8040402@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <20060919101012.GA12965@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Tue, Sep 19, 2006 at 02:58:09PM +0530, Deepak wrote:
|Hi,
|I need to transfer some files from remote PC using tftp (don't want to 
|use rsync/ftp/scp or more).
|I have enabled tftp in both PCs using 'ntsysv' and making "disable=no" 
|in /etc/xinetd.d/tftp file.
|Both PCs are reachable. But tftp is not working as i followed simple 
|syntax given in man page.
|
|Do i need to start any service? I tried 'service in.tftpd status' but it 
|is displaying error: Unrecognized servce.
|Pls reply the following queries:
Any particular reason why you want to use tftp? It is the stupidest protocol I have come across as it is a simple stop and wait protocol that does not even work properly sometimes across devices on the same LAN or thro' serial lines. 

Its rexmit mechanims and error detection mechanisms are all very very unsuitable for common use. 

Moreover being a UDP protocol, reliability is not guaranteed. Just try pingint your other remote machine and observe how many packets get lost due to timeout and various other reasons. Do you think tftp shud be different? Of course it will rexmit and if you are lucky you will get what you want.

I say, why torture yourself when you have so many other options?

I normally use scp. If you dont want that you can run a simple httpd server at the remote end using yaws or thttpd. Sorry , I know this is not what you want but I thought you changed ur mind after reading my mail? :-)
|i)  How can I use tftp?
Maybe your tftp files dir is not created or something, check the logs. You are better off using nc to check whether something is listening at UDP port 69 at the other end. You can also use nmap of course.
|ii) What is the maximum file size i can transfer?
Don't know. Normally tftp is used for downloading firmware. I guess there might not be a limit, but I might be wrong. I faintly remember there is a limit. As I told you embedded device with restrained mem and cpu use tftp since it is simple to deploy and just works in an error free environment. 

This is extracted from my OpenBSD tftpd man page.

<cut>
BUGS
     This implementation of tftpd does not support blocksize negotiation (RFC
      1783), so files larger than 33488896 octets (65535 blocks) cannot be
          transferred.

      Many TFTP clients will not transfer files over 16744448 octets (32767
           blocks).

<cut>

Octet is nothing but a byte.

Using it across the Internet is certainly not a good idea.
|iii) Any idea, How this mechanism works in UDP?
I didnt understand the question.
|iv) Some more practical inputs/usage/links/limitations.
I have given enuf above. :-)
|v) Any information about transfer speed and System load?
It uses a very simple flow control mechanism called stop and wait. No, it hardly causes any load on the system.

So I guess transfer speed is suboptimal as you have no concept of windows like TCP in which you can pipeline sends without receiving ACKs.

It just rexmits for I think five times if a packet gets lost. 

It has no user auth mechanism though you are somewhat safe since nobody can normally clobber your files. Everyone can read it however.

Best,
Girish

-- 
Whenever people agree with me I always feel I am wrong.

    - Oscar Wilde
From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Tue Sep 19 15:49:50 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Tue Sep 19 15:50:03 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to execute tftp to transfer file(s)
In-Reply-To: <20060919101012.GA12965@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <450FB0BC.7090606@frodo.hserus.net>
	<450FB829.8040402@midascomm.com>
	<20060919101012.GA12965@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609190319o65523613wf2900af493cfe458@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/19/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
> On Tue, Sep 19, 2006 at 02:58:09PM +0530, Deepak wrote:
> |I need to transfer some files from remote PC using tftp (don't want to
> |use rsync/ftp/scp or more).
> Any particular reason why you want to use tftp? It is the stupidest protocol I have come across as it is a simple stop and wait protocol that does not even work properly sometimes across devices on the same LAN or thro' serial lines.

tftp is very simple to implement and thus has found its way into
the firmware (bios) of several computers.  My old Alphastation and
SGI Indy bootroms had a tftp client and could diskless boot off the
network.  tftp is still being used to load kernels on diskless nodes.

The possibility that the OP is using an embedded or diskless
computer could not be far fetched, given that he's posting from
a Midas Comm email ID.

- Raja
From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Tue Sep 19 16:11:04 2006
From: toufeeqh at gmail.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Tue Sep 19 16:11:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to execute tftp to transfer file(s)
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560609190319o65523613wf2900af493cfe458@mail.gmail.com>
References: <450FB0BC.7090606@frodo.hserus.net>
	<450FB829.8040402@midascomm.com>
	<20060919101012.GA12965@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<92f9a9560609190319o65523613wf2900af493cfe458@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <c293dd340609190341ud40bac8m39187453bcadc4b2@mail.gmail.com>

> The possibility that the OP is using an embedded or diskless
> computer could not be far fetched, given that he's posting from
> a Midas Comm email ID.

++1.
RedBoot and uboot are bootloaders usually found on embedded devices
and they both have tftp client functionality built into them for
downloading images via network. The OP would be using a similar
bootloader.

If you want to have a simple ftp client like functionality built into
a embedded device's bootloader program tftp makes sense.

-Toufeeq
-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net

Why do you are looking for a training institute to learn an FOSS subject 
? Get books, sit with the computer, learn - if doubts come or you get 
struck some where ask the community. In additional there are fantastic 
tutorials and pretty helpful & active forums there for PHP and MYSQL. If 
you have real interest you can learn Basic PHP and MySQL within a week, 
no big deal.

In-Reply-To: <450FD666.6010809@midascomm.com>

	<450FD666.6010809@midascomm.com>

On Tue, Sep 19, 2006 at 05:07:10PM +0530, Deepak wrote:
|
|
|Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
|
|>
|>If you want to have a simple ftp client like functionality built into
|>a embedded device's bootloader program tftp makes sense.
|>
|I am needed tftp for almost same. I got the idea.
|Thanks to all.
|
|Regards,
|Deepak Dikshit
All is well as long as the tftp server is not remote. :-)

Anyway I owe an apology to all since I said that tftp is used over serial lines. That is utter nonsense. tftp is usable only over TCP/IP over UDP. So tftp is mostly usably only using ethernet. 

The reason for my confusion was that I used to download the firmware/image using the serial line using ymodem/zmodem whenever the boot loader on the device was hosed. The boot loader had the tftp client.

Sorry for the confusion.

Best,
Girish

On 19/09/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
> Anyway I owe an apology to all since I said that tftp is used over serial lines. That is utter nonsense. tftp is usable only over TCP/IP over UDP. So tftp is mostly usably only using ethernet.

TFTP is usable over serial lines if a protocol capable of
encapsulating IP over such lines is used at the OSI layer 2 (eg: PPP).

Binand

Hi,

> both are linux frienldly if ethernet adsl modem/routers are used. But
> supportwise
> airtel is verygood, bsnl is pitiable. Problems come rarerly in
> Airtel/BSNL. Once it comes airtel will attend immediately, in BSNL you
> will have to run pillar to post.
>

I will disagree with this. Day before yesterday, my DataOne was
disconnected due to an outstanding bill (The phone was disconnected
about a week before that). On payment, within one hour the telephone
was rectified but not the broadband, and so I thought that it was a
technical issue and I called Customer Care(1500). Firstly, I was
surprised to get a young female voice at the other end:) who said it
will be fixed in 24 hrs. I said I wanted the net urgently, and I was
called by a Service Engineer within 20 minutes, who did not even
assume I used Windows and asked me which operating system I used, and
when I said Linux, gave me instructions for Linux. I was eventually
told this was due to the non payment of the bill, and will be
corrected as soon as their database is updated.

Within an hour even they called me again, and told me that it was restored.

Also no other service gives wireless routers for such a cheap rent.

DataOne Rocks!!!

--arnie

From rhariharan at gmail.com  Wed Sep 20 12:29:10 2006
From: rhariharan at gmail.com (hari)
Date: Wed Sep 20 12:29:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Net,usb drive not working on Kubuntu 6.06
In-Reply-To: <20060911025827.18777.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <72288b670609100835v66876aeem72c78c1904dc71af@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060911025827.18777.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <895952550609192359g8956e72rc707e630bcb6d94e@mail.gmail.com>

I have a similar USB Pendrive problem in Fedora 5 and Windows.

I have 2 usb Pendrives: one from Transcend(128 MB) Works properly.
I have another, a new one(512MB) from I-dont-know-who company.

This gets recognized first..then after a minute or so, the mount fails and I
get a bunch of
"device not accepting address " errors in syslog.

When I touch the USB device, I see its real hot.
But I remember this device working somewhat ok (even though it was very hot)
in Redhat 9.

(In windows, after a couple of minutes this drive is thrown out and get a
usb device removed improperly error.)

So I guess it might be worthwhile to test with a good USB pendrive and
confirm if things are ok with that. The issue being with the device and not
with your Drivers.

--hari

On 9/19/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On 19/09/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> > recursion is a theoretical concept not used much in practice.
>
> Can you spell DNS??
>
>
Solving a problem using recursion, though elegant, can be a hog on the
stack. At least one book on data structures/algorithms suggests that after
solving a problem (which is recursive in nature) it is advisable to
reimplement the recursive part in a non recursive way for the sake of
efficiency.

On a philosophical note: all of life is recursive at some level. To find out
more about this read the GEB book (at least the first 100 or so pages -
thats what I could handle :-) )
-- 
War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Sep 20 00:34:00 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Sep 20 13:04:08 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Job] Linux device driver developers, Flextronics 
Message-ID: <20060920073400.16618.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

Job: Linux device driver developer(s)

Requirements:

* Programming in C.
* ARM assembly language programming, a plus.
* Scripting languages (bash shell scripting); know-how
of Perl is useful. 
* Atleast two years of work experience in Linux device
driver development for 2.4 Linux kernels. 
* Knowledge of operating systems, and Linux kernel
internals.
* Knowledge of 2.6 Linux kernel, a plus.
* Experience on hardware debugging.
* Good problem-solving, troubleshooting skills.
* Know-how on participating in the free/open source
community.

* Networking domain knowledge: protocols, and Linux
network stack implementation.
AND/OR
* USB domain, and Linux USB subsystem knowledge.

This division of Flextronics Software Systems in
Chennai is an embedded/VLSI division. You will be
working in a GNU/Linux environment. You will have 24x7
Internet access. No official dress code. The positions
are based in Chennai.

Please e-mail your resumes in any open standard format
(.txt, .html, .pdf, .ps) to shakthi dot kannan at
flextronicssoftware dot com.

No recruiters or consultants please.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

> Talk 2: Role of FOSS in UCH Project.
>         By Alex Cravan
>
>         An Australian Volunteer for the Uluru Children's Home (UCH)
>         Project, Is Look for a help from ILUGC members to setup a

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Wed Sep 20 20:19:58 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Wed Sep 20 20:17:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [Fwd: Arrr! Linux 2.6.18] The' Talk like a Pirate Day' Mail
	!
Message-ID: <45115516.1070301@gmail.com>

Hello LUGies,

Thought of sharing this interesting mail with you all. Here is Linux 
Torvalds, informing the kernel update on the sidelines of 'Talk like a 
pirate day'. Hope most of you would have read this one, but I got this 
one the LKML and thought of sharing with you all :)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@osdl.org>
Date: Sep 20, 2006 10:03 AM
Subject: Arrr! Linux 2.6.18
To: Linux Kernel Mailing List <linux-kernel@vger.kernel.org>



Ahoy!

She's good to go, hoist anchor!

Here's some real booty for all you land-lubbers.

There's not too many changes, with t'bulk of the patch bein' defconfig
updates, but the shortlog at the aft of this here email describes the
details if you care, you scurvy dogs.

Header cleanups, various one-liners, and random other fixes.

                 Linus "but you can call me Cap'n"

---

Adrian Bunk:
       Ahoy! Make fs/jffs2/nodelist.c:jffs2_obsolete_node_frag() static
       fs/jffs2/xattr.c: maroon dead code

Al "Bilge rat" Viro:
       [IPV4] fib_trie: missin' ntohl() when callin' fib_semantic_match()

Alexey Dobriyan:
       headers_check: improve #include regexp
       headers_check: clarify error message

Alexey Korolev:
       [MTD] Fixes of performance and stability issues in CFI driver. Arrr!

Cap'n Andrew Morton:
       Blimey! hvc_console suspend fix

Andy Walker:
       [SPARC]: Fix mutimous regression in sys_getdomainname()

Arnaud Patard:
       IPMI: Fix oops on ipmi_msghandler removal for non ipmi systems. Gar!

Artem B. Bityutskiy:
       [MTD] NAND: keelhaul marooned URL in Kconfig

Aubrey Lee:
       [MTD] DEVICES: Fill more device IDs in t'structure of m25p80

Auke Kok:
       e1000: fix bilge-sucking TX timout hang regression for 82542rev3

Ben Dooks:
       [ARM] 3784/1: S3C2413: keelhaul config for MACH_S3C2413/MACH_SMDK2413
       [ARM] 3785/1: S3C2412: Fix idle code as default uses wrong clocks
       [ARM] 3793/1: S3C2412: fix barnacles in wrong serial info struct
       [ARM] 3794/1: S3C24XX: do not defined set_irq_wake when no CONFIG_PM

Benjamin Herrenschmidt:
       [POWERPC] Fix G5 DART (IOMMU) race causin' occasional data corruption

Benjamin LaHaise:
       i386/x86-64: Add core 2 to oprofile

Chas Williams:
       [ATM]: [he] when transmit fails, unmap t'dma regions right smartly
       [ATM]: [he] don't hold t'device lock when upcalling

Chuck Ebbert:
       Kconfig: move CONFIG_EMBEDDED options to submenu. Gar!

Corey Minyard:
       IPMI: keelhaul handlin' of OEM flags

Dale Farnsworth:
       mv643xx_eth: Unmap DMA buffers in receive path

Dan Williams:
       [ARM] 3780/1: Fix iop321 cpuid

Dave Kleikamp:
       [Shiver me timbers] EXT2: Remove superblock lock contention in 
ext2_statfs

David S. Miller:
       [OPENPROMIO]: Handle current_node bein' NULL correctly. Arrr!

David Woodhouse:
       [MTD NAND] Fix lookup error in nand_get_flash_type()
       [POWERPC] Implement PowerPC futex_atomic_cmpxchg_inatomic(). Arrr!
       headers_check: reduce user-visible noise in <linux/nfs_fs.h>
       headers_check: remove <asm/timex.h> from user export
       headers_check: move inclusion of <linux/linkage.h> in 
<asm-i386/signal.h>
       headers_check: move kernel-only #includes within <asm-i386/elf.h>
       headers_check: don't expose PFN stuff to userspace in 
<asm-i386/setup.h>
       headers_check: keelhaul userspace build of asm-mips/page.h
       Fix scurvy 'make headers_check' on biarch architectures
       Fix 'make headers_check' on s390
       Fix 'make headers_check' on ia64
       Fix 'make headers_check' on i386
       Fix 'make headers_check' on x86_64
       Fix 'make headers_check' for Alpha
       headers_check: use a different default directory
       Add headers_check' target to output of 'make help'

Davy Jones:
       Didn't do anything, the scurvy lad. Ahoy!

Eli Cohen:
       IPoIB: Retry failed send-only multicast group joins. Gar!

Frank Pavlic:
       s390: minor s390 network driver fixes
       s390: netiucv driver fixes
       s390: Makefile cleanup
       s390: qeth driver fixes [1/6]
       s390: qeth driver fixes [2/6]
       s390: qeth driver fixes [3/6]
       s390: qeth driver fixes [4/6]
       s390: qeth driver fixes [5/6]
       s390: qeth driver fixes [6/6]

Geert Uytterhoeven:
       Well blow me down, if he didn't fix 'make headers_check' on ia64

Greg KH:
       We can not allow anonymous contributions to t'kernel

Haavard Skinnemoen:
       MTD: Convert Atmel PRI information to AMD format
       MTD: Add lock/unlock operations for Atmel AT49BV6416

Havasi Ferenc:
       [JFFS2][SUMMARY] Fix a bilge-suckin' summary collectin' bug. Arrr!

Herbert Xu:
       [NET]: Drop tx lock in dev_watchdog_up

H?vard Skinnemoen:
       MTD: Fix bug in fixup_convert_atmel_pri

Imre Deak:
       genirq: Fix the typo in IRQ resend smartly, cabin boy!

Ingo Molnar:
       lockdep: double the number of stack-trace entries
       genirq core: keelhaul handle_level_irq()

Ishai Rabinovitz:
       IB/srp: Don't schedule reconnect from srp

James Morris:
       [NETFILTER]: Add secmark headers to header-y

Jeremy Fitzhardinge:
       x86: reserve a boot-loader ID number for Xen

Jon Loeliger:
       [POWERPC] Add new, missin' argument to of_irq_map_raw() for 86xx. 
Arrr!

Josef 'Jeff' Sipek:
       [MTD] Use SEEK_{SET,CUR,END} instead of hardcoded values in
mtdchar lseek()

Josh Triplett:
       Add preprocessed files (*.i) to .gitignore
       Add mixed source and assembly listings (*.lst) to .gitignore
       Add symbol type files (*.symtypes) to .gitignore

Kenneth Lee:
       bug fix for bilge-suckin' in kernel/kmod.c

Kirill Korotaev:
       [NEIGH]: neigh_table_clear() doesn't free stats

Linus "Cap'n" Torvalds:
       x86: save/restore eflags in context switch
       Avast! Belay those mmiocfg heuristics and blacklist changes
       Linux v2.6.18. Arrr!

Matthew Wilcox:
       headers_check: Clean up asm-parisc/page.h for user headers

Michael De Backer:
       alim15x3.c: M5229 (rev c8) support for DMA cd-writer

Michael S. Tsirkin:
       RDMA/cma: Increase t'IB CM retry count in CMA

Mike Miller:
       cciss: version update, new hw

Mohan Kumar M:
       [POWERPC] Fix interrupt clearin' in kdump shutdown sequence

NeilBrown:
       knfsd: Have ext2 reject file handles with bad inode numbers early
       knfsd: Make ext3 reject filehandles referrin' to invalid inode number

Olaf Hering:
       [POWERPC] update prep_defconfig

Oleg Nesterov:
       rcu_do_batch: make ->qlen decrement irq safe

Patrick McHardy:
       [PACKET]: Don't truncate non-linear skbs with mmaped IO
       [NETFILTER]: xt_quota: add missin' module aliases

Paul "Peg leg" Mackerras:
       [POWERPC] Update defconfigs
       [POWERPC] Fix MMIO ops to provide expected barrier behaviour

Ralph Siemsen:
       [ARM] 3815/1: headers_install support for ARM

Remi Denis-Courmont:
       [IPV6]: Accept -1 for IPV6_TCLASS

Richard Purdie:
       MTD: [NAND] Fix t'sharpsl driver after breakage from a core 
conversion

Roland Dreier:
       [ATM]: linux-atm-general mailin' list is subscribers only

Rolf Eike Beer:
       remove #error on !PCI from pmc551.c

Ross Biro:
       Add a missin' space that prevents buildin' modules that require
host programs

Sachin P. Sant:
       [POWERPC] kdump: Support kernels havin' 64k page size. Arrr!

Simon Horman:
       [IPVS]: Document t'ports option to ip_vs_ftp in kernel-parameters.txt
       [IPVS]: auto-help for ip_vs_ftp
       [IPVS]: Make sure ip_vs_ftp ports are valid
       [IPVS]: remove the debug option go ip_vs_ftp

Stefan Richter:
       SCSI: lockdep annotation in scsi_send_eh_cmnd

Stephen Hemminger:
       [TCP]: Turn ABC off. Arrr!
       [BRIDGE]: random extra bytes on STP TCN packet
       [NET]: Mark frame diverter for future removal. Arrr!

Suparna Bhattacharya:
       ext3 sequential read regression fix

Takashi YOSHI:
       MTD: Add Macronix MX29F040 to JEDEC

Takashi YOSHII:
       [MTD] Maps: Add dependency on alternate probe methods to physmap

Tejun Heo:
       libata: ignore CFA signature while sanity-checkin' an ATAPI device

Trond Myklebust:
       NFS: Fix Oopsable condition in nfs_readpage_sync()
       NFSv4: Fix incorrect semaphore release in _nfs4_do_open()
       NFS: Fix nfs_page use after free issues in fs/nfs/write.c

Ulrich Kunitz:
       zd1211rw: Fix of signal strength and quality measurement

Ville Herva:
       block2mtd.c: Make kernel boot command line arguments work (try 4)

Vitaly Wool:
       [MTD] NAND: OOB buffer offset fixups
       [ARM] 3786/1: pnx4008: update defconfig
       MTD NAND: OOB buffer offset fixups

Wong Hoi Sing Edison:
       [TCP] tcp-lp: bug fix for oops in 2.6.18-rc6
       [TCP] tcp-lp: update information to MAINTAINERS

YOSHIFUJI Hideaki:
       [IPV6]: Fix tclass settin' for raw sockets.
       [ATM] CLIP: Do not refer freed skbuff in clip_mkip(). Arrr!

Zoltan Sogor:
       JFFS2: SUMMARY: keelhaul a summary collectin' bug

-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.
Research/Project Engineer, NRCFOSS
A Proud Ubuntero and Linuxian
[Tech Blog: http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com]
[NRCFOSS HelpLine: http://nrcfosshelpline.in/code/wiki/]
From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Wed Sep 20 20:20:15 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)

Thought of sharing this interesting mail with you all. Here is Linus 
Torvalds, informing the kernel update on the sidelines of 'Talk like a 
pirate day'. Hope most of you would have read this one, but I got this 
one the LKML and thought of sharing with you all :)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@osdl.org>
Date: Sep 20, 2006 10:03 AM
Subject: Arrr! Linux 2.6.18
To: Linux Kernel Mailing List <linux-kernel@vger.kernel.org>



Ahoy!

She's good to go, hoist anchor!

Here's some real booty for all you land-lubbers.

updates, but the shortlog at the aft of this here email describes the
details if you care, you scurvy dogs.

                 Linus "but you can call me Cap'n"

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Sep 20 11:35:24 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Sep 21 00:05:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] podcasts on linux in indian english
In-Reply-To: <dd680c2b0609200956h7ac461f9r318b3895f957656c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060920183524.51553.qmail@web50209.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Shrinivasan T <tshrinivasan@gmail.com> wrote:
> today i found a nice podcast site on linux

Which Internet connection do you use and from where?

> If the podcasts were in indian english, or tamil
> it will reach more and more rural students.

Do you know what download speeds the students or
people in rural places get?

Next time you visit a rural village in India, try
opening up any .html webpage on a dial-up connection
(say BSNL). It will be *pathetically* slow (in the
order of minutes). I have seen this in the outskirts
of Tiruchirapalli, Karaikudi, and Erode. So, you can
imagine how much time it will take for any CMS to
load.

Why rural village, go to any town and use the Internet
connection and see it to believe it.

Your idea of having speeches recorded is good. But,
the methodology to spread it would be to burn it in
CDs, and courier it to towns/rural villages.
Professional courier is very much affordable and it
reaches remote places in few days time. Cds4grabs
(temporarily down in chennailug wiki) is a good
example.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

Hi Abhishek,

--- Ingeneur <goda.abishek@gmail.com> wrote:
> On the other hand ,most of the colleges have decent
> internet
> connections(i believe). 

It depends on whom you are refering to as colleges. In
Chennai city, there are mostly Arts and Science
colleges, and I haven't worked with them much to know
about their Internet connection. Maybe an Arts and
Science student in this mailing list can shed light on
the connection and speeds.

Most and all engineering colleges are in the outskirts
of Chennai. If you go down south, they are again in
the outskirts of a town. It doesn't matter because the
Internet speeds aren't very different between towns
and rural villages. They are slow.

> On the other hand there are so many ppl in the
> cities, maybe

The OP was targetting students in rural places.

The other approach would be to broadcast the podcast!

Anna University, Chennai has on-campus radio
broadcast.

Kongu Engineering College, Erode also have their own
FM radio station. 

Cheers,

SK

Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From: Alex Craven 

Hi,

Sorry for the delay getting back to you on this - was out of action
(unwell) for most of last week.

In terms of the kind of help we may be looking for, basically anything
you could offer in the following areas would be useful; I can provide
more specific details as needed...

1) Help in locating a linux system administrator for the new center
   (we may need some advice on 'appropriate' skill levels, salary
   expectations etc for that sort of position, also perhaps in
   distributing the position description through your networks).

2) Could use some advice on any system administration/training
   documentation in Tamil language (if such things exist), and perhaps
   some help with system administrator training down the line.

3) Help in locating suitable educational applications for a Linux
   platform (possibly with Tamil variations if necessary; I know a
   couple of your members expressed interest in helping with this sort
   of development).

4) Further down the line, perhaps a bit of a demonstration as had been
   suggested for last Sat. I think it may be better if this happence
   once the new center opens (hopefully a couple of months from now).

UCH address is as follows:

  Uluru Children's Home & Uluru Health Care Centre
  No 1, Kamala Avenue, off Alamparai Beach Road, Kadapakkam
  Cheyyur Taluk, Kanchipuram District 603 304

Right now there are 32 children, aged from 2-14. This is going to grow
to about 80 by the end of the year, by which stage the new center
should be functional.

Some information on the children's home:

 http://www.tewfi.org/patasala.html

Some information on the computer center:

 http://www.tewoaf.org.au/compcent.html

Engineers Without Borders also has a "support network" site where a
lot of technical discussion on the project takes place:

 http://www.ewb-isn.com/

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Sep 21 06:47:29 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Sep 21 19:17:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Need SATA controller driver for Intel d945gnt chipset.
In-Reply-To: <1158776351.S.19245.21550.webmail21.rediffmail.com.1158830728.16488@webmail.rediffmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060921134729.20497.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Nagappan L <nagappan_l@rediffmail.com> wrote:
> The configuration is P4 3.06Ghz&nbsp; -
> Intel D945gnt chipset motherboard - 512MB DDR2 RAM -
> Seagate SATA 80Gb Harddisk. 

Nice.

> The problem is, I can\'t
> install RHEL 4.0. 

Don't you get support for this? 

Are you booting from a 2.6 Linux kernel? The 2.6 Linux
kernels have SATA drivers and they should detect your
hard-disk. In Debian Sarge, you can pass linux26 to
the "boot:" prompt to boot a Linux 2.6 kernel during
installation.

All recent distros do boot with a 2.6 Linux kernel.

Regards,

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From vijaysanand2002 at yahoo.com  Thu Sep 21 09:20:11 2006
From: vijaysanand2002 at yahoo.com (Vijay S Anand)
Date: Thu Sep 21 21:50:28 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] DEMO: Chennai?
In-Reply-To: <20060921063002.1F6B01DB28E@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <20060921162011.49309.qmail@web36803.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Hello Guys:

By the way, I have been talking to some folks about putting together an event, somewhat similar to DEMO [www.demo.com], where we can get some fascinating ideas together on stage with working prototypes and pre-releases, bring the public there, and invite the VC circles there. The demo of the technology , depending on how well it resonates with the audience will give the VC a good perspective on how relevant the product is, and how well the team is capable of conveying their story - which might drive the VCs to invest int hem -, and it will help the small companies which are struggling to get some exposure. 

With a lot of VCs here in India, and news about over-investments all over the place, and sadly all the good companies getting too few notice, it might be something worthwhile.

Chennai could use an event like this, since the whole technology space really does need a boost. If it does pick up, it has potential to spawn, just like barcamp or whatever. It cant be an unconference, as there has to be a set of entrepreneurs and VCs (I am sure TIE will be happy to be part of it) to screen the technologies, and make sure that the pitches are compelling enough and help them brush up, but it could be fun neverthless. 

Your thoughts?

Vijay

PS: Both the unconferences, Blogcamp and Barcamp have been organized by the same team, and there is a fair bit of initial interest with this as well. If you know of any companies based in Chennai, in and around India, keep them posted.

bLOG: http://blog.leadstep.com

 		
---------------------------------
Do you Yahoo!?
 Everyone is raving about the  all-new Yahoo! Mail.

A thought to provoke Wisdom:

"Na tasya pratima asti"
"There is no image of Him."
[Svetasvatara Upanishad 4:19]

"Andhatama pravishanti ye asambhuti mupaste"
"They enter darkness, those who worship the nature" (Air, Water, Fire,
animals,trees,hills, rivers etc.).
"They sink deeper in darkness, those who worship sabhuti."  (sambhuti -- man
made things (idols, yantras etc))
[Yajurveda 40:9]

From guitarvasu at gmail.com  Fri Sep 22 10:44:52 2006
From: guitarvasu at gmail.com (vasudevan rk)
Date: Fri Sep 22 10:45:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] PerlModule Issue when restarting httpd !
Message-ID: <902eb7080609212214s1124ac04mb888a4f141f37cc4@mail.gmail.com>

Hi Luggies!
 Please suggest me how to over come this difficulties in
httpd.conf when restarting httpd.
root@sai [/usr/local/apache/conf]# vi httpd.conf
<IfModule mod_perl.c>
    PerlFreshRestart On
    PerlInitHandler Apache::StatINC
    PerlRequire /usr/local/apache/etc/perl/startup.perl
    PerlModule Apache::Registry
    PerlModule Apache::Status
    PerlModule Apache::Leak
    PerlModule Apache::DBI
    PerlModule Apache::AuthDBI
    PerlModule Apache::OutputChain
    PerlModule Apache::EmbperlChain
    PerlModule HTML::Embperl
    PerlModule DBI
    PerlModule DBD::mysql

<Files ~ "\.phtml$">
    SetHandler perl-script
    PerlHandler HTML::Embperl
    Options ExecCGI
    Order allow,deny
    Allow from all
</Files>

AddType text/html .phtml

</IfModule>

<VirtualHost 70.84.54.106>
 ServerName rt.adsmx.com
 DocumentRoot /opt/rt3/share/html
 AddDefaultCharset UTF-8

 PerlModule Apache::DBI
 PerlRequire /opt/rt3/bin/webmux.pl

 <Location />
  SetHandler perl-script
  PerlHandler RT::Mason
 </Location>
</VirtualHost>

root@sai [/usr/local/apache/conf]# service httpd start
Syntax error on line 1682 of
/usr/local/apache/conf/httpd.conf:
Invalid command 'PerlModule', perhaps mis-spelled or
defined by a module not included in the server
configuration
/etc/init.d/httpd start: httpd could not be started

I installed these dependencies in my system.

root@sai [~/.cpan/build]#ls
Apache-DBI-1.03/  Apache-Test-1.28/  DBD-mysql-3.0002/
 DBD-mysql-3.0007/  DBI-1.52/
HTTP-Server-Simple-Mason-0.09/ and also
perl-5.8.8,DB-mysql-2.1018 resides in /usr/local/ &
mod_perl-1.29 resides in /usr/local/src

Regards
vasu

Subject: [Ilugc] M$ word steals unwanted information
In-Reply-To: <48bd74c50609211526qf164d23n4e924a94c8719f48@mail.gmail.com>

> I am doing a report on M$ 's antitrust allegations and other unhealthy
> competition by MS and I remember reading a post in this list which says that
> M$ word steals and stores some sensitive (private ) information about the
> author  in a sort of a paper.
> I tried searching net and archives and couldnt get hold of it,

As far as I know, MS Word doesn't do anything of that sort. Similar to
any word processor, it maintains a set of "properties" for each
document created, but that is hardly anything worth reporting.

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Fri Sep 22 12:44:14 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Fri Sep 22 12:44:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] M$ word steals unwanted information
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610609212230u31b1be4et962669519244eca8@mail.gmail.com>
References: <48bd74c50609211526qf164d23n4e924a94c8719f48@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610609212230u31b1be4et962669519244eca8@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609220014r7d6aa434i9ba9bdf97faeb309@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/22/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> As far as I know, MS Word doesn't do anything of that sort. Similar to
> any word processor, it maintains a set of "properties" for each
> document created, but that is hardly anything worth reporting.

Tsk, tsk...  Word stores a *lot* of hidden metadata about your
document.  If you enabled Versions or Track Changes, deleted text
can be recovered from the document, along with the time of edits.
If you use any form of collaboration, all the names of your
contributors are also shown in the document.  Even enabling Fast
Saves creates hidden information.

I remember recently someone at Microsoft releasing a public
statement on their website in word format with all the hidden
text still present.  Maybe they forgot to use this:
   http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?kbid=834427

To the OP:
    http://addbalance.com/usersguide/metadata.htm

- Raja

From binand at gmail.com  Fri Sep 22 09:45:56 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Sep 22 13:16:08 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] M$ word steals unwanted information
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560609220014r7d6aa434i9ba9bdf97faeb309@mail.gmail.com>
References: <48bd74c50609211526qf164d23n4e924a94c8719f48@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610609212230u31b1be4et962669519244eca8@mail.gmail.com>
	<92f9a9560609220014r7d6aa434i9ba9bdf97faeb309@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609220045n1eec00c5vc8059b7f1ed8de71@mail.gmail.com>

On 22/09/06, Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:
> Tsk, tsk...  Word stores a *lot* of hidden metadata about your
> document.  If you enabled Versions or Track Changes, deleted text
> can be recovered from the document, along with the time of edits.

That is the way the said feature is -supposed- to work. What help is a
version control system; if it cannot let you revert to an older
version?

> If you use any form of collaboration, all the names of your
> contributors are also shown in the document.  Even enabling Fast
> Saves creates hidden information.

Ditto. See above.

> I remember recently someone at Microsoft releasing a public
> statement on their website in word format with all the hidden
> text still present.  Maybe they forgot to use this:
>    http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?kbid=834427

Yep. Microsoft provides a tool to remove such information if you so desire.

The point I wished to make is that the information is required for the
features it provides; I really can't see how a document preparation
system can offer version control as a feature if it doesn't store
information about previous versions.

Anyway, I never circulate Word documents, I rely on PDFs.

Binand

Noted.  The point I wished to make is that the presence of
this information should be effectively communicated to the
user.  Removing this information should not require you to
download/use some obscure tool.

In the real world, every Word document I receive, has all
kinds of sensitive information attached.  And the senders
are oblivious to it. Not a great thing for business
correspondence.

We better stop this MS debate before the GNU Police shoots
us down :-)

From girish1729 at gmail.com  Fri Sep 22 20:00:51 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Fri Sep 22 20:01:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Few tips
Message-ID: <20060922143051.GA19950@lakshmi.susmita.org>


Dear friends,

     This is an article I wrote some time ago specifically for a non technical audience. I got good feedback. So I am sending it to you hoping that you benefit. 

     Please please dont start a flame war on this. :-)

     If u dont like it, just press the d key.

     regards,
     Girish


Hello,


Here I am sharing with you certain highly effective practical ways to save money.  I use only free software. So none of the tools I speak of cost any money!

1) Tape recorders, music systems etc. are dead or are at the verge of extinction. If you are buying something new and
you already have a cassette player at home or if you don't have any cassettes , then don't even touch a cassette with
a ten foot barge pole. There is also no meaning in shelling 10,000 rupees on some fancy music system. Your computer can
do a much better job than any other device. Or get a cheap CD/MP3 player . Now the  real  magic lies in the fidelity/frequency
response/power handling capabilites of the speakers.

Money should be spent only on speakers. The audio processing better be done by a computer or a portable device with a
DSP chip like portable mp3 players.

It is not prudent to rely on computers completely for music since they may crash and boot slowly and are an overkill if it is not on. So get a tiny portable device and connect powerful speakers with amplifiers.

There are several creative things you can do with the computer that no off the shelf component in the market can even imagine.
a) play songs in any order
b) play songs in random order
c) delete and introduce songs from anywhere
d) download songs from the Internet
e) schedule to play a song at a particular time or stop at a particular time
f) play the song at double or half the rate

Also you can buy any CD and rip it to convert the audio into mp3,Ogg Vorbis or flv format. CD are notorious for getting spoilt.
Also CD is dead technology. Buy DVDs for anything; that is the future.

2) For new purchases , please dont't go in for CRT monitors, those bulky thingies that look like old television sets. :-)

LCD monitors have become very affordable these days. LCD technology is digital, consumes very little power, occupies a fraction
of the space, has excellent resolution and durability.

The comparison is something like the difference between transistor and valve tube or between electric bulb and tubelight.

Only problem is viewing from a distance or from an angle, viewability is affected. But things might change anytime.

I guess it is also easy on the eyes which is very very important.

3) Present day television technology is soon dying. Modern TVs will have two important changes. First it will throw away CRT tech and go for LCD monitors. And the television signal decoding is going to be done digitally with the end result that new TVs will have very little
similarity with what you see today.

I view television on .. yes, u guessed it right, on my computer screen. You can buy a very good PCI TV card for around 1200 bucks.
And immediately a whole new world opens before you.
You can
a) record TV shows
b) schedule TV recordings and time shift with which you can fast forward and rewind television
c) You can sit at one foot distance and watch
d) Eyes won't get spoilt one bit bcoz PAL refresh rates are 50 Hz and most modern day computer monitors easily do around 85 Hz. And the resolution of the computer screen is an order of magnitude higher than that of TV. With the result that you enjoy the experience with such surrealism and also you can do other things with the computer while watching television.
e) Of course you can take snapshots when your favourite stars appear on screen
f) Many TV cards come with an in built FM tuner too! You can listen to FM radio, record it, do whatever
g)There are countless other things you can do like streaming the TV signals to another computer or monitor in some other room

External TV cards are available but I don't think they are worth the cost. If you already have a TV at home, still buying a TV card
is worthwhile since you don't want to miss the next episode of Selvi if you want to drop your son at the bus stand,Do you? :-)

But I think the real payoff is in terms of preserving our eyesight. LCD screen computer monitors give u such clarity and they are so soothing to the eyes...

Along similar lines you can easily switch over to next gen television tech like DVB, DTH, HDTV etc. Already cheap TV cards support these things. But alas, only DTH has free to air channels in India today. And you need to also buy a small dish antenna. And pay for
the set top box.

4) Want a home theatre ? No problem. My solution will cost only 1/10th or less. :-)

First of all here, the main components are the six or so speakers placed appropriately on the room. The acoustics of the room has to be taken into consideration. Things like carpets and curtains to absorb sound, supress echo and promote only the requisite reverbration is reqd.

The other two components are a projector and a ... yes again , a computer that decodes DVD and TV signals. This can be a box too.

With these individual components one can easily come up with a much better home theatre for around 35,000 instead of two lakhs or so.

5) Present day radio still has lot of fastination with the masses.That too with the creative, informative programming being done in Chennai FM channels, radio has become an unalienable part of everyday life.

FM and to a small extent AM radio technology though ancient , unfortunately or should I say fortunately also are dying albeit slowly.

Already technology is available that uses the present day electromagnetic spectrum allocation done in various countries to air "Digital AM" which uses high fidelity audio in AAC format that give you not only audio, but also display text about the song being played, allow some interactivity along the lines of "dial a song" thro' the radio itself. Of course this is a distant dream since this requires both transmitter and radio receiver technology to be completely changed.

Today FM radios are available for 100 rupees or so. Very good value for money. Once you connect it to speakers you have very high
fidelity stereo audio.

6) Want new jazzy ringtones for your Nokia mobile? Ask me! :-) You can make it in no time with linux based tools. Get me the song
and I will make the ring tone in no time.

7) Wireless technology has also come a long way today but this mostly applies to laptops and I don't know much about it. Wi Fi,WiMax and what not have a great future.

8) Wanna call friends abroad? Use VoIP technology. Go to www.skype.com or www.voipbuster.com. Download the free software,
buy regular phone numbers in most advanced nations for free! Only condition is u shud use Win XP or for skype Linux or FreeBSD.

I have spoken to several countries for hours without spending a single rupee. On one end is ur computer, on the other end is a telephone.

9) The best DVD player is your computer again. :-)

10) You can do several other things. The sky is the limit the moment computing power is at your disposal. You can become completely self sufficient and self reliant. If you want to publish a book ,all the tools are available for free. If you want to do image processing, reduce the brightness, apply red eye correction, make a photo album, change the background, create a group photo etc. all these can be done with free software tools.

You can record your voice, songs or music if you are good at singing or playing musical instruments and release a CD with cover design done all by yourself with a computer.
-- 
Mulla Nasrudin was relaxing one night rocking in his easy chair when an ostentatiously dressed woman came running and asked him,

      "Doctor, doctor can you please tell me what is wrong with me?"

Nasrudin considered for a moment and said,

      "You are wearing too much makeup. You should reduce it. And you will look much better if you shed few kilos. By the way the doctor lives across the street."

From binand at gmail.com  Fri Sep 22 16:55:08 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Sep 22 20:25:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Few tips
In-Reply-To: <20060922145839.GA3365@ee.iitm.ac.in>
References: <20060922143051.GA19950@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<20060922145839.GA3365@ee.iitm.ac.in>

On 22/09/06, Kumar Appaiah <akumar@ee.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> Are you sure this is legal in India? Though people do it, if you don't
> use something like PhoneWala, a company which has paid license for
> VoIP use, I thought you shouldn'y use these.

The Wikipedia article on VOIP, Legal section, has this:

"In India, it is legal to use VoIP. But it is illegal to have VoIP
gateways inside India. This effectively means, people who have PCs can
use it to make a VoIP call to any number. But if the remote side is a
normal phone, the gateway that converts VoIP call to POTS call should
not be inside India."

Remember that companies like Yahoo, MSN, Rediff etc. offer VOIP
services via their instant messaging software, and also have Indian
presence.

Binand
From jtrjtrjtr2001 at yahoo.com  Fri Sep 22 09:00:06 2006

hi,


 try search on sourceforge or freshmeat. you can also
look for opensource database implementations as they
commonly use B trees or its variants to build an index
for effeciently searching huge databases.
  Its not too hard to code it up either if you have
the time and patience :-)

Introduction to Algorithms by Rivest,Coremen and
Stein,PHI is another book you might like to look at.

Sarad.

The licenses for most software are designed to take away your
freedom to share and change it.  By contrast, the GNU General Public
License is intended to guarantee your freedom to share and change free
software--to make sure the software is free for all its users.

From girish1729 at gmail.com  Sat Sep 23 16:38:32 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sat Sep 23 16:38:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Open Source Software for Call Center Units
In-Reply-To: <e32dffb219083.4514af3e@eth.net>
References: <e32dffb219083.4514af3e@eth.net>
Message-ID: <20060923110832.GA22093@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Sat, Sep 23, 2006 at 03:51:26AM +0000, dhana_1@eth.net wrote:
> Dear Lugs
> 
> Requesting you to guide me on the Open Source Softwares (linux) available 
> for succesfully running a Call Center (both INbound & Outbound) Unit.
> 
> Thanking you,
> 
Someone told me that call centers use only linux. I think that makes sense bcoz you would want to cut costs where it hurts the most; telecom.

Today you have entire EPABX in software itself that will make the most expensive solution hang its head in shame. Google for Asterisk and you will know what I mean.

ISTM you will have to buy the appropriate card from Digium and setup Asterisk that will route your calls either thro' PSTN or VoIP.

Apropos of VoIP you have skype that runs very well on linux.

Others should add to whatever I have told here.

All the best!

regards,
Girish

From km at mrna.tn.nic.in  Sat Sep 23 20:44:08 2006
From: km at mrna.tn.nic.in (km)
Date: Sat Sep 23 20:36:41 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] swap needed or not ?
Message-ID: <20060923151408.GA16052@mrna.tn.nic.in>


Hi all,

when i have an 8 GB Physical RAM on a Linux do i still need swap partition ?
have heard reports saying that one does indeed need it, howmuch ever physical RAM  u have, as it considerably improves performance. how far is it true ? swap partition of what size could be made for maximum performance of the OS ?
does the thumb rule of 2 x PhysicalRam hold true here also ?
tia,
regards,
KM
From binand at gmail.com  Sat Sep 23 17:55:41 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sat Sep 23 21:25:49 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] swap needed or not ?
In-Reply-To: <20060923151408.GA16052@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20060923151408.GA16052@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609230855i467f45f8v69b7bbad8149fc18@mail.gmail.com>

On 23/09/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> when i have an 8 GB Physical RAM on a Linux do i still need swap partition ?

No. If you have the disk space, there is no harm in having a swap
partition of up to 2GB, though.

> have heard reports saying that one does indeed need it, howmuch ever physical RAM  u have, as it considerably improves performance. how far is it true ? swap partition of what size could be made for maximum performance of the OS ?

Depends on the application you intend to run; and the load the box is
expected to support. Each case is unique, and should be dealt such.

> does the thumb rule of 2 x PhysicalRam hold true here also ?

No.

Binand
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Sep 23 08:58:57 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sat Sep 23 21:29:09 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] swap needed or not ?
In-Reply-To: <20060923151408.GA16052@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <20060923155857.85245.qmail@web50207.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> when i have an 8 GB Physical RAM on a Linux do i
> still need swap partition ?

AFAIK, not required. Linux kernel memory management is
pretty good. You can create one if you want to.

> does the thumb rule of 2 x PhysicalRam hold true
> here also ?

Nope. It was only applicable for very, very old
hardware.

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Sat Sep 23 22:54:38 2006

[OT]

On 9/23/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> when i have an 8 GB Physical RAM on a Linux do i still need swap partition ?

A few years ago, I had access to two unique boxes that
is worth mentioning:

64 CPU SGI, 32GB RAM, 50TB disk and 512MB (yes it's MB)
swap.  The swap partition was there just to keep the OS
and config tools happy and was never used.

8 CPU Alpha, 8GB RAM and 4GB HDD.  When we ran out of HDD
space, we created a RAM disk and stored files on it!!
Ofcourse the machine was never rebooted.  This continued
for a few months, until an infrastructure upgrade brought
us more disk.

It's true that the world down-under is really upside down.

- Raja

> How does it matter? This is a Linux list, not a Free
> Software list. If it runs on Linux, it ought to be

Deja-vu.  See this from a few years ago:

http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc/9793/focus=9793


The only thing this argument accomplishes is that it divides
the lug into two opposing camps: those who are okay with
the discussion of non-FOSS topics, and those who oppose it.
(Of course, being a lug, any non-Linux topic is definitely
OT.  There's no debate in that.)

Since we only have one mailing list/forum, it's best that
both camps acknowledge the presence the other and learn to
respect each others views.

Personally, I can tolerate different views and opinions, and
at times I even solocit opposing views.  It is this nitpicking
and intolerance towards others that I find irritiating.

I also find it ironic that while we talk about freedom, the
moment someone has an contradicting opinon, they get slammed.
Jeez...

- Raja

Hello everyone,
One thing really bugs me. Cedega by Transgaming technologies is a closed
source app which is used to run windows games in linux. Given the fact
that wine is LGPL'd and cedega uses its code, isnt it violating LGPL
taking into account the viral nature of LGPL..Which rises to another
question, whats the difference between LGPL and GPL
--

From mohan.tux at gmail.com  Sun Sep 24 09:52:39 2006
From: mohan.tux at gmail.com (Mohan Sundaram)
Date: Sun Sep 24 09:52:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] LGPL violation or not
In-Reply-To: <1159069331.5280.6.camel@tuxbox>
References: <1159069331.5280.6.camel@tuxbox>
Message-ID: <4516080F.5050206@gmail.com>

Sudharshan S wrote:
> Hello everyone,
> One thing really bugs me. Cedega by Transgaming technologies is a closed
> source app which is used to run windows games in linux. Given the fact
> that wine is LGPL'd and cedega uses its code, isnt it violating LGPL
> taking into account the viral nature of LGPL..Which rises to another
> question, whats the difference between LGPL and GPL
> 
AFAIK, this is not violation. LGPL is not viral. If the company has used 
GPL libraries, they are clearly violating the licence.

You can use LGPL code and not liable to publish your code as required in 
GPL.

Mohan
From prashmohan at gmail.com  Sun Sep 24 10:00:34 2006
From: prashmohan at gmail.com (Prashanth Mohan)
Date: Sun Sep 24 10:00:49 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] LGPL violation or not
In-Reply-To: <1159069331.5280.6.camel@tuxbox>
References: <1159069331.5280.6.camel@tuxbox>
Message-ID: <451609EA.1020006@gmail.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Sudharshan S wrote:
> Hello everyone,
> One thing really bugs me. Cedega by Transgaming technologies is a closed
> source app which is used to run windows games in linux. Given the fact
> that wine is LGPL'd and cedega uses its code, isnt it violating LGPL
> taking into account the viral nature of LGPL..Which rises to another
> question, whats the difference between LGPL and GPL
> 
> 

``Google'' with its Do No Evil paradigm also released their Linux
version of Picasa with a modified version of wine. and Picasa is not
Open Source. Google also in the process submitted a number of patches to
the Wine Project (http://code.google.com/patches.html).

AFAIK, GPL implies that any application which modifies or even links to
GPLed libraries will have to make that application GPLed too. Whereas,
what LGPL states is that applications can link to LGPLed libraries and
remain closed source, however, If they do modify the LGPLed library
itself, they will have to show the modifications made to the library.

- --
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

Version: GnuPG v1.4.3 (GNU/Linux)

Edai1gXN4tIEJsorjPALKgU=
=6upP
-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----

   I'll second the recommendation of 2.6.18 - it was a drop-in
replacement for my previous 2.6.16 and FC4 userland, and
everything just worked painlessly.

seems to drop fewer frames, even on a PIII/500 notebook
running on batteries. Check it out.

   On another note, I'm no longer going to upgrade to FC5
and all future Fedora releases - FC4 already meets all my
requirements for the foreseeable future. I may selectively
rebuild SRPMs and install RPMs from future Fedora releases,
but only on an as-needed basis.
