On 9/24/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
> a) Are folks only interested in linux, GPL, blah blah blah? Or is it ok to talk about open source and free software? Bcoz I know that most of you know BSD and are very interested in it. For me personally UNIX is all I care.

Two responses:

1.  Keep your OT volume low:
Unlike this recent animosity, in the past, this list has
been fairly tolerant towards OT discussions. Only when the
OT volume has gone too high has it been discouraged.

2. If you want others to tolerate you, you must first
learn to tolerate others:
Like how Unix is all you care about, there are people here
who only care about Linux.  If you create your post with
this understanding, and take care not to offend these guys,
you can almost get away with anything.


Your wild statements -- academic projects are bad, Tanenbaum
is a loser, OpenBSD/Debian have silly ideologies -- are all
insensitive, offensive and hurtful remarks.  Those who are
associated with these people/projects will feel assaulted
and hit back.

The real damage is that you will lose all credibility with
those who matter.


> b) I do not think it will be a good idea to divide this list further down into kernel list, hw list, bsd list, linux list etc...

Yes.  And that's why we have only one list.

- Raja

PS: Please stop using a 10 line signature.  You've already
been told once.  It's bad email etiquette.  And your new one,
makes offensive and derogatory remarks about women.

Losing credibility with sensible people may be bad, but losing
your credibility with the ladies is even worse!  :-S
Be careful with your comments.

On 23-Sep-06, at 8:44 PM, km wrote:

> when i have an 8 GB Physical RAM on a Linux do i still need swap  
> partition ?

no
> have heard reports saying that one does indeed need it, howmuch  
> ever physical RAM  u have, as it considerably improves performance.  
> how far is it true ? swap partition of what size could be made for  
> maximum performance of the OS ?

swap slows things down - even if you have a swap partition, keep it  
off until your system slows down - even with 512 MB RAM i keep swap  
off until the ram is really overloaded

> does the thumb rule of 2 x PhysicalRam hold true here also ?

1 x physical RAM is best

From siva.ilugc at gmail.com  Sun Sep 24 14:37:37 2006
From: siva.ilugc at gmail.com (Sivasankar Chander)
Date: Sun Sep 24 14:37:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] OT: Alan Cox's Thinkpad laptop battery explodes
Message-ID: <a8f990120609240207m3e879710n3b68b501e628cd91@mail.gmail.com>

Folks,
         By now, we've all heard of Sony OEM batteries catching fire
and exploding in Dell, HP and various other notebooks. Here's an
example of an IBM Thinkpad 600 (perhaps 8+ years old), belonging
to Alan Cox, catching fire from a replacement battery.

http://zeniv.linux.org.uk/~telsa/boom/

Any new Li-Ion battery today is suspect, due to materials contamination.
Perhaps there's a good case for sticking with old batteries as long
as possible, and subsequently to run the machine off AC mains alone.

There's going to be widespread nostalgia for NiCd and NiMH batteries -
their only problem was the so-called memory-effect that sometimes
occurred when partially discharged and then recharged again.
I have a few that are over 10 years old and going strong - including
one in a Thinkpad 760xl, predecessor to the Thinkpad 600 (That was
the last Thinkpad that I purchased - I switched to Toshiba and Dell after
that, with no battery-related issues yet - all running on their factory-
original Li-Ion batteries still).

-Siva
From girish1729 at gmail.com  Sun Sep 24 14:44:21 2006
From: girish1729 at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sun Sep 24 14:44:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] OS concepts -Threads
In-Reply-To: <48bd74c50609240033q1490a4c3v49e4843d438db217@mail.gmail.com>
References: <48bd74c50609240033q1490a4c3v49e4843d438db217@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060924091421.GA28796@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Sun, Sep 24, 2006 at 03:33:09AM -0400, peevee wrote:
> Hi friends,
> 
> This is not related to OSS or Linux,
> but I want to be cleared some concept of Operating Systems in general.
> 
> What happens if a process exits, and there are still threads of that process
> running?
> 
Wonder why you marked it OT.

If a process exits, the threads also die. Remember a process is defined by context and the most important aspect is its address space. A context has several components like contents of Ax,Bx,Cx,Dx regs if it is x86, signal mask, state(running,sleeping etc.) , stack etc...

Now, each thread has a lightweight context associated with it, the most important thing here being its stack. 

So when a process is divided into threads , basically the global process context is split into diff threads. All of them map to the same address space.

If you try to access memory outside the bounds of the address space allocated to the process, a hardware trap is generated by the MMU.

Now, the moment a process dies, its address space is removed from the MMU and all page tables cleared of its existence.

So there is no room for any thread to run. Essentially I mean that thread's context has to be stored somewhere, if it does not have an address space mapping where will it go?

Remember I am only talking of user space threading. Kernel threading is a different ballgame.

This is a deep theoretical topic and my memory certainly is rusty. Maybe u shudnt trust my words much. :-)

Best,
Girish

PS : I think some student will do a much better job than me in elucidating this
From peevee.chaitanya at gmail.com  Sun Sep 24 05:41:41 2006
From: peevee.chaitanya at gmail.com (peevee)

Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] OS concepts -Threads
In-Reply-To: <20060924091421.GA28796@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <48bd74c50609240033q1490a4c3v49e4843d438db217@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060924091421.GA28796@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <48bd74c50609240241u212454adl35e9af240499f950@mail.gmail.com>

>
> Wonder why you marked it OT.
>
> If a process exits, the threads also die. Remember a process is defined by
> context and the most important aspect is its address space. A context has
> several components like contents of Ax,Bx,Cx,Dx regs if it is x86, signal
> mask, state(running,sleeping etc.) , stack etc...
>
> Now, each thread has a lightweight context associated with it, the most
> important thing here being its stack.
>
> So when a process is divided into threads , basically the global process
> context is split into diff threads. All of them map to the same address
> space.
> If you try to access memory outside the bounds of the address space
> allocated to the process, a hardware trap is generated by the MMU.
>
> Now, the moment a process dies, its address space is removed from the MMU
> and all page tables cleared of its existence.
>
> So there is no room for any thread to run. Essentially I mean that
> thread's context has to be stored somewhere, if it does not have an address
> space mapping where will it go?
>

> different ballgame.

Ya, I am also on the same thoughts initially,
but when I thought about Unix/Linux threads, Unix clones a process to make
thread, and this may share memory or it may not share memory,
in this case, if the parent thread (process) is killed, will the cloned
(thread/process) continue to exist?
I remember reading somewhere that in Solaris, even if the parent
process/thread is killed , the child process/thread can run.
Even I am not sure if this parent child process is the same as parent child
thread.

Please throw some light on my doubts.
Regards

peevee

> Hi,
> Im having BSNL broadband connection (400 MB plan) with Smart ATX MT841
> USB port External modem. Im having Debian Sarge(kernel 2.6.8) in my
> pc.Can any one help me in connecting with the broadband from my pc.
> 
> PS: I look into the archives and found a similar mail. The reply
> pointed to the wiki page
> http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/Chennai_Broadband_guide
> But i get a page not found message...
> 
Yes, we can  certainly help you out. But I need some technical details. Is that modem a USB only modem? Does it have an ethernet port?

If it has an ethernet port, then buy an ethernet straight cable or BSNL should give you one, and you are done.

If it is a USB only modem, then it is more work. 

Contact me offlist if it is a USB only modem.

regards,
Girish

From sundaram at fedoraproject.org  Sun Sep 24 18:17:35 2006
From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul)
Date: Sun Sep 24 18:17:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] LGPL violation or not
In-Reply-To: <1159069331.5280.6.camel@tuxbox>
References: <1159069331.5280.6.camel@tuxbox>
Message-ID: <45167E67.8040404@fedoraproject.org>

Sudharshan S wrote:
> Hello everyone,
> One thing really bugs me. Cedega by Transgaming technologies is a closed
> source app which is used to run windows games in linux. Given the fact
> that wine is LGPL'd and cedega uses its code, isnt it violating LGPL
> taking into account the viral nature of LGPL..Which rises to another
> question, whats the difference between LGPL and GPL

No. Its not a violation. Wine was historically under the MIT license 
which is similar to the revised BSD license and allowed proprietary 
modifications. Wine switched to LGPL because many commercial 
contributors were not returning changes.

Rahul

Subject: [Ilugc] RAID0 with partitions

> Is it prudent to configure RAID0 on a single harddisk with partitions ( /, /boot, /home/, /var and /usr) ? any experience and suggestion ?

RAID is for multiple physical HDDs only.  No point in running
*any* RAID setup using a single HDD.

- Raja

On Sun, Sep 24, 2006 at 08:58:09PM +0530, Raja Subramanian wrote:

> >Is it prudent to configure RAID0 on a single harddisk with partitions ( /, 
> >/boot, /home/, /var and /usr) ? any experience and suggestion ?
> 
> RAID is for multiple physical HDDs only.  No point in running
> *any* RAID setup using a single HDD.
It is possible to do it in FreeBSD with gstripe(1), gmirror(1) and friends.

But I doubt if you would want to install it just for RAID on one HDD...

I frankly don't know the logic behind doing it. I think there are ways and means of figuring out when your disk crashes as it usually dies a slow death. There are tools that tell you that the patient is about to expire.

And you can save your data. HTH.

Best,
Girish

From girish1729 at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 08:02:19 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] BIOS upgrade
Message-ID: <20060925023219.GA4024@lakshmi.susmita.org>

Hello,

	I have a peculiar problem. My old machines can't boot off USB devices since the BIOS is really old. Is there a way I can upgrade the BIOS?

	The machines in question are PII and PIII motherboards.

	Please help.

	regards,
	Girish

From rajagopal.n at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 09:14:08 2006
From: rajagopal.n at gmail.com (Rajagopal Natarajan)
Date: Mon Sep 25 09:14:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] BIOS upgrade
In-Reply-To: <20060925023219.GA4024@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20060925023219.GA4024@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <e0900f3e0609242044m6da42bdfv88bd321d016e98bd@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/25/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>         The machines in question are PII and PIII motherboards.


PII PIII are all processors; not motherboards. Your mobo would be named
something like i815, i845, etc. if u use intel.


-- 
N. Rajagopal,
Visit me at http://www.rajagopal.tk
From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 09:24:24 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Mon Sep 25 09:24:33 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] BIOS upgrade
In-Reply-To: <20060925023219.GA4024@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <20060925023219.GA4024@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609242054n2649df89x7c50554c3e028bef@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/25/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote:
> I have a peculiar problem. My old machines can't boot off USB devices since the BIOS is really old. Is there a way I can upgrade the BIOS?

The only safe answer is to check with your MB manufacturer's website
and see if they offer an update.

There are plenty of bios hacking applications (for AMI, Award, etc)
using which you could patch/modify your own BIOS.  You could pull
off the bootup code detection module from an update BIOS version
and apply it to your BIOS.  Needless to say, you would be voiding
warranty and possibly breaking a number of EULAs in the process.

Check with the LinuxBios project and see if your motherboard/chipset
is supported.

Warning, warning:  Attempting BIOS programing without an EEPROM
programmer is a sure way to brick your motherboard!  If your BIOS
chip is soldered on the motherboard and is not removeable, then
the slightest error will render your board useless.

I think GRUB supports USB booting, so a floppy/CDROM with the
appropriate GRUB would also solve the problem nicely.

- Raja
From girish1729 at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 09:36:58 2006

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Mon Sep 25 10:20:58 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Mon Sep 25 10:20:44 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] .NET guy
Message-ID: <1082.61.247.255.57.1159159858.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

>> Posting a job opening
>> in .NET is _not_ acceptable by any standards in this
>> mailing list. And

> And would not to be useful too, as no .NET guy would be subsrcibed to this
> list, besides it only brings heated arguments.

Not sure about that because I have received response to this posting already.

We prefer people with exposure to Linux/*BSD even if it is for programming
on platforms like Java/.NET because typically these users have more than a
passing interest in computer science and have better grasp of computer
fundamentals. They also tend to have a more inquisitive mind, and a
tendency to not shy away for experimentation which are both desirable
qualities in an engineer. Most of our computers dual boot windows and
linux.

On a related note -  If you want to be taken seriously as an analyst and
if you want to make an informed decision on the choice of technology to
best address a problem a client is facing, you must be familiar with
atleast two platforms - the platforms may be Linux + Windows, FreeBSD +
Windows etc.

The same applies to technology as well - in terms of the type of people I
look out for, I prefer those who are comfortable with atleast two
platforms - .NET + Java, C++ + Java, Java + PHP etc. I vastly prefer those
with reasonable skills on multiple platforms and expert level skills in
atleast one platform. That explains how this job was posted on this
mailing list.

Also, I will wager that there are multiple people on this forum who have
programmed for the .NET platform, and perhaps many more who have
programmed for Java. I have programmed professionally on all three - .NET,
Java and in C/C++ for Linux and ofcourse PHP.

Thanks,
Prem

On Mon, Sep 25, 2006 at 09:24:24AM +0530, Raja Subramanian wrote:
 
> I think GRUB supports USB booting, so a floppy/CDROM with the
> appropriate GRUB would also solve the problem nicely.
> 
> - Raja
Hmm, hard luck. It turns out grub uses BIOS drives for identifying bootable devices. So if BIOS cannot see USB, then grub can't either. 

If only life were so easy...

From vprajan at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 11:52:53 2006

Date: Mon Sep 25 11:53:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Creating a dummy RPM package
Message-ID: <d6e7f37f0609242322k4ba64510w197235c4e16da424@mail.gmail.com>

Hi friends,

iam using a binary installer (.BIN file) which forcefully depends upon
two RPM packages,
     tomcat5-5.0.28-2jpp_5rh
     tomcat5-admin-webapps-5.0.28-2jpp_5rh

There is no possibility of ignoring this dependency since it is binary
package. So, i decided to create a dummy RPM package with the package
name as above. But, i cannot find correct way to create a dummy RPM
package.

My doubt is,
"whether is it possible to create a fake RPM file which can be
installed and uninstalled without creating any files in the host
system?.."

Thanks for ur help.

From binand at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 08:31:52 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Mon Sep 25 12:02:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Creating a dummy RPM package
In-Reply-To: <d6e7f37f0609242322k4ba64510w197235c4e16da424@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d6e7f37f0609242322k4ba64510w197235c4e16da424@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609242331n6df55455l126bafeacb8cc8a0@mail.gmail.com>

On 25/09/06, Pushparajan V <vprajan@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi friends,
>
> iam using a binary installer (.BIN file) which forcefully depends upon
> two RPM packages,
>      tomcat5-5.0.28-2jpp_5rh
>      tomcat5-admin-webapps-5.0.28-2jpp_5rh
>
> There is no possibility of ignoring this dependency since it is binary
> package. So, i decided to create a dummy RPM package with the package
> name as above. But, i cannot find correct way to create a dummy RPM
> package.

Ignoring dependencies is probably the easiest way to hose your system.
Why aren't you installing tomcat 5 and getting done with it?

In any case, you can install the package with the --nodeps option to
tell RPM not to check the dependencies.

Binand

Hi,

> Hmm, hard luck. It turns out grub uses BIOS drives

> see USB, then grub can't either.

boot USB via floppy:

http://linuxgazette.net/116/okopnik1.html

From binand at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 09:42:00 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Mon Sep 25 13:12:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Creating a dummy RPM package
In-Reply-To: <d6e7f37f0609242322k4ba64510w197235c4e16da424@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d6e7f37f0609242322k4ba64510w197235c4e16da424@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609250042u7a1da040xabd6e391795b6a94@mail.gmail.com>

On 25/09/06, Pushparajan V <vprajan@gmail.com> wrote:
> "whether is it possible to create a fake RPM file which can be
> installed and uninstalled without creating any files in the host
> system?.."

Didn't realize that you are installing a non-RPM package...

To create such a fake RPM file, first ensure that you have the
rpm-build package installed. Then, save this text somewhere as
dummy.spec:

=== cut here ===
Summary: Dummy Package to provide tomcat5
Name: dummy-tomcat
Version: 1.0
Release: 1
Group: System Environment/Base
License: Beerware
BuildArch: noarch
Provides: tomcat5, tomcat5-admin-webapps

%description

This meta-package fools other packages to think you have tomcat5 installed

%files
=== cut here ===

Now, run the command: rpmbuild -bb dummy.spec

It will create a dummy-1.0-1.noarch.rpm which when installed, will
provide tomcat5 (assuming your software looks at the provides list
rather than the name list).

Binand
From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Mon Sep 25 13:11:33 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Mon Sep 25 13:13:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] customising
In-Reply-To: <451786CF.4010801@gmail.com>
References: <451786CF.4010801@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4517882D.7070907@gopalarathnam.com>

Prasanna Kumar wrote:
>    hi all,
>        We are about to adopt Openoffice.org for all our document needs with
>    in our office . But we need some cusotmizations
>    to be done with openoffice. I came to know that openoffice i written in
>    java 
> 
(snip)
 From where?
OpenOffice.org contains more than 7.5 million lines of C++ code IIRC.

Moreover, for customising OpenOffice.org, you need not write C++ or Java 
though you can.  They have exposed an interface (somewhat in similar 
lines with Mozilla) for writing extensions on top of it.  It depends on 
what level of customisation you're gonna need.

So, you could choose even JavaScript (or Basic) to write extensions to 
customise OpenOffice.org to your needs.

More here:
http://api.openoffice.org/DevelopersGuide/DevelopersGuide.html

HTH.

-- 
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

http://gopalarathnam.com/

From sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in  Mon Sep 25 15:25:29 2006
From: sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in (Prof. P. Sriram)
Date: Mon Sep 25 15:25:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: reply to munging
In-Reply-To: <4BF34F98-DFB3-4EB8-87B8-4C3B44A0FE09@thenilgiris.com>
References: <20060923151408.GA16052@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<92f9a9560609231024p2cbfccfayeaf20925699fcbc3@mail.gmail.com>
	<1c4dc2780609231126v207ddddr518655cab4cf05ab@mail.gmail.com>
	<loom.20060924T160524-751@post.gmane.org>
	<4BF34F98-DFB3-4EB8-87B8-4C3B44A0FE09@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251441510.23375@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>

On Sun, 24 Sep 2006, a list user wrote:
> first time i have ever mailed a listadmin directly - could you please  
> implement reply-to munging

i will respond to the list instead. i have been doing my own reading
up on reply-to munging. yes, i have gone over the two usual documents
referred for and against - both dating back a few years, if i may add.  
there is also enough material on record to suggest that this may be one of
those debian vs. openbsd type of religous wars. note, i did not say
windows vs. linux religous war since we all know in that one which side is
the faithful and which side is the infidel.  but, i have come to a
conclusion and here is an argument that helped me
(http://mlmmj.mmj.dk/archive/0919.html)

we will not do reply-to munging on this list (now).

why? well, i am swayed by the interpretation of rfc2822 which states that 

'When the "Reply-To:" field is present, it indicates the mailbox(es) to 
which the author of the message suggests that replies be sent.'

i agree with the argument that 'the list is not the author of the message,
so the list has no business creating a new reply-to header or worse,
rewriting an existing reply-to header.' message authors are free to post
to the list with their own reply-to headers present and the list will
faithfully carry this in the postings - so, those who believe that
reply-to should be pointing to the list are free to add a reply-to header
at their end which points to the list and postings will appear so. those 
who dont believe reply-to should point to the list need not add any 
reply-to header and the list will not add any either.

of course, we can start our own religious wars here. the list (not me) 
decides which way to go.

-- 
sriram

From binand at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 12:25:38 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Mon Sep 25 15:55:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: reply to munging
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251441510.23375@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
References: <20060923151408.GA16052@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<92f9a9560609231024p2cbfccfayeaf20925699fcbc3@mail.gmail.com>
	<1c4dc2780609231126v207ddddr518655cab4cf05ab@mail.gmail.com>
	<loom.20060924T160524-751@post.gmane.org>
	<4BF34F98-DFB3-4EB8-87B8-4C3B44A0FE09@thenilgiris.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251441510.23375@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609250325t55155d0exf9778e2429170f5@mail.gmail.com>

On 25/09/06, Prof. P. Sriram <sriram@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> why? well, i am swayed by the interpretation of rfc2822 which states that
>
> 'When the "Reply-To:" field is present, it indicates the mailbox(es) to
> which the author of the message suggests that replies be sent.'
>
> i agree with the argument that 'the list is not the author of the message,
> so the list has no business creating a new reply-to header or worse,
> rewriting an existing reply-to header.' message authors are free to post

IMO, the list the author of the message, even though the text of the
message was drafted by someone else. In this context, author =>
software responsible for injecting the message into the MTA's queueing
system. Thus, if I "Forward" or "Bounce" (f & b in mutt) an email, I
am the author of the message, since my mutt caused the message to be
injected into the local queue. On the other hand, if I had a .forward
or an /etc/aliases entry, I am not the "author" of the message, since
the injection was in continuation to the message being already in my
queue.

That is, the MLM software is to be considered as an MUA.

This is paraphrasing something I read in another list (populated with
really clued people).

Binand
From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 16:02:36 2006

Hello,

On 9/25/06, Prof. P. Sriram <sriram@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> we will not do reply-to munging on this list (now).
>
> why? well, i am swayed by the interpretation of rfc2822 which states that
>
> 'When the "Reply-To:" field is present, it indicates the mailbox(es) to
> which the author of the message suggests that replies be sent.'

I've checked with both and GNOME lists and LKML and they _DON'T_ do
reply-to munging. OTOH, YahooGroups seems to have reply-to munging and
various LUG's have their mailing list hosted on YahooGroups.

The above info is not an argument for munging of the reply-to header,
just my 0.02$

-Toufeeq

blog @ http://toufeeq.net

	<d2a92d610609250325t55155d0exf9778e2429170f5@mail.gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251631360.25442@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609250450v5d5c2f79m7b4837cff05c0c6b@mail.gmail.com>

On 25/09/06, Prof. P. Sriram <sriram@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> On Mon, 25 Sep 2006, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> > That is, the MLM software is to be considered as an MUA.
>
> which is where we disagree. IMO the MLM software is more like an MTA than
> an MUA.

This can be debated. I'd like to know why you think of mailman as an
MTA. RFC 2821 section 2.3.3 says:

"Mail User Agents" (MUAs or UAs) are normally thought of as the
sources and targets of mail.

In the case of ilugc, I send the email to ilugc@ae - the target -
which is mailman, and the emails I get have envelop sender set to
ilugc-bounces@ae - the source - which is also mailman.

(It also says:

the implied boundaries between MUAs and MTAs often do not accurately
match common, and conforming, practices with Internet mail.)

Binand

From devafree at yahoo.com  Mon Sep 25 08:22:25 2006
From: devafree at yahoo.com (deva free)
Date: Mon Sep 25 20:52:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Open Source Software for Call Center Units
In-Reply-To: <20060923110832.GA22093@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <20060925152225.14139.qmail@web50807.mail.yahoo.com>

Dhana_1,
 Try gnudialer.org or astguiclient.sf.net. I'd recommend the latter , but its only a personal choice. They are both asterisk based. Avoid the asterisk 1.2.11 tree for call center applications. You do not need a NIC from digium or anything for below 30 seats at least. But make sure your timer is set from 250 default to 1000 in a re-built kernel . Use ztdummy with zaptel as a timer and no need for a card. Also, use at least kernel version 2.6.5+ to avoid a  bug in the ztdummy use that will give jitters in the voice.
 Please do mail me if you encounter difficulties.
 Plenty of guys are re-branding these as their solutions and they are very much in the market under various names.
 Regards
 Devafree

Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote: On Sat, Sep 23, 2006 at 03:51:26AM +0000, dhana_1@eth.net wrote:
> Dear Lugs
> 
> Requesting you to guide me on the Open Source Softwares (linux) available 
> for succesfully running a Call Center (both INbound & Outbound) Unit.
> 
> Thanking you,
> 
Someone told me that call centers use only linux. I think that makes sense bcoz you would want to cut costs where it hurts the most; telecom.

Today you have entire EPABX in software itself that will make the most expensive solution hang its head in shame. Google for Asterisk and you will know what I mean.

ISTM you will have to buy the appropriate card from Digium and setup Asterisk that will route your calls either thro' PSTN or VoIP.

Apropos of VoIP you have skype that runs very well on linux.

Others should add to whatever I have told here.

All the best!

regards,
Girish

From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Mon Sep 25 21:00:41 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Mon Sep 25 21:01:41 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Apache and MySql
In-Reply-To: <200609252055.47608.jerregroups@gmail.com>
References: <200609252055.47608.jerregroups@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4517F621.1060205@gopalarathnam.com>

Jerre Louis wrote:
> HI
> 
> i am using Kubuntu,i installed apache and mysql.i happened to see both apache 
> and mysql,get loaded during the boot time.is there any way to stop both these 
> programs from starting in the boot time.
> 

You can de-select those services from the "Services" application, or use 
the update-rc.d(8) command to remove them.

HTH.

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Mon Sep 25 21:14:57 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Mon Sep 25 21:15:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Apache and MySql
In-Reply-To: <200609252055.47608.jerregroups@gmail.com>
References: <200609252055.47608.jerregroups@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4517F979.2050505@gmail.com>

Jerre Louis wrote:
> HI
> 
> i am using Kubuntu,i installed apache and mysql.i happened to see both apache 
> and mysql,get loaded during the boot time.is there any way to stop both these 
> programs from starting in the boot time.
> 
> cheers
> jerre

* Go to System --> Administration --> Services,

* You will be asked for password, enter that (i.e. administrator password)

* Check for httpd/apache and mysqld, stop both the server and click off 
the tick mark next to them.

* Close the window and you are done.

* Reboot to check whether it is not being started :)


-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.
Research/Project Engineer, NRCFOSS
A Proud Ubuntero and Linuxian
[Tech Blog: http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com]
[NRCFOSS HelpLine: http://nrcfosshelpline.in/code/wiki/]

some of the suggestion is that
1. use LDAP for u r office.
2. customise all your apps to contact central LDAP for authentication.
3. there are extensions available for each mentioned apps (i guess)

in that way, u have single login id which will be used for all apps.

Date: Mon Sep 25 21:39:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: [**LikelySPAM] ilugc Digest, Vol 28, Issue 59
In-Reply-To: <002d01c6e079$bc724d70$4e00a8c0@admin1>
References: <20060921063002.1F6B01DB28E@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<002d01c6e079$bc724d70$4e00a8c0@admin1>
Message-ID: <154eca020609250908w4f4fb27ft65a30b0f8e457c63@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/25/06, Support <support@inspacetech.com> wrote:
> please dont send me the mails

There are two ways to go about doing this:

a. you can contact our support team to get your id removed
from our mailing list. we charge $1000 per id for this service.
( visa and mastercard accepted, option available for paypal)

OR

b. You can follow the instructions at the footer of every email
from this mailing list. this process is free of charge.

--
saha

From sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in  Mon Sep 25 18:30:54 2006
From: sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in (sriram)
Date: Tue Sep 26 00:02:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: reply to munging
References: <20060923151408.GA16052@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<92f9a9560609231024p2cbfccfayeaf20925699fcbc3@mail.gmail.com>
	<1c4dc2780609231126v207ddddr518655cab4cf05ab@mail.gmail.com>
	<loom.20060924T160524-751@post.gmane.org>
	<4BF34F98-DFB3-4EB8-87B8-4C3B44A0FE09@thenilgiris.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251441510.23375@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<d2a92d610609250325t55155d0exf9778e2429170f5@mail.gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251631360.25442@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<d2a92d610609250450v5d5c2f79m7b4837cff05c0c6b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <loom.20060925T195127-781@post.gmane.org>

Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@...> writes:
> "Mail User Agents" (MUAs or UAs) are normally thought of as the
> sources and targets of mail.
> 
> In the case of ilugc, I send the email to ilugc <at> ae - the target -
> which is mailman, and the emails I get have envelop sender set to
> ilugc-bounces <at> ae - the source - which is also mailman.

envelop sender has nothing to do with the source of the mail; the envelop sender
is defined as the address to which bounce messages should be sent. this is how
rfc 2821 says it in 2.3.1 "The SMTP envelope is sent as a series of SMTP
protocol units (described in section 3).  It consists of an originator address
(to which error reports should be directed) ... "

now for target, we can stretch your argument to make an MTA into an MUA. in many
mail readers, one can configure how outgoing mail is to be handled. in
particular, one can specify an MTA to which mail should be handed over. does
this make the MTA a target of the mail, then? if yes, then we have just
established that an MTA is an MUA since it is the target of the mail. if no,
then mailing list managers will fall under this category, since it does exactly
what an MTA does in this instance - receives the mail as a temporary target and
then transmits it on to the ultimate target(s). in this sense, a mailing list
manager is never a source or target of the mail. a mailing list subscriber is
the source of the mail and all mailing list subscribers are the targets of the
mail. mailing list managers like mailman are only relay agents and relay is a
role generally associated with MTA's not MUA's.

ok, let me add more fuel to this fire.

we are using mailman for the list. here is a quote from the mailman faq. "The
Mailman developers strongly agree with Chip and Marc, and strongly disagree with
Simon" - chip and marc argue that munging reply-to headers is bad while simon
argues that munging reply-to headers is good. the same faq also states that
"Fundamentally, this problem really should be solved in the MUA" - so, the
developers of mailman (at least the one writing the faq) dont believe mailman is
a MUA.

sriram

	<loom.20060924T160524-751@post.gmane.org>
	<4BF34F98-DFB3-4EB8-87B8-4C3B44A0FE09@thenilgiris.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251441510.23375@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<d2a92d610609250325t55155d0exf9778e2429170f5@mail.gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251631360.25442@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<d2a92d610609250450v5d5c2f79m7b4837cff05c0c6b@mail.gmail.com>
	<loom.20060925T195127-781@post.gmane.org>
Message-ID: <f3cf3ae70609251215w7c90d39fvb725d693662936cd@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/26/06, sriram <sriram@xxxxxx> wrote:
> we are using mailman for the list. here is a quote from the mailman faq. "The
> Mailman developers strongly agree with Chip and Marc, and strongly disagree with
> Simon" - chip and marc argue that munging reply-to headers is bad while simon
> argues that munging reply-to headers is good. the same faq also states that
> "Fundamentally, this problem really should be solved in the MUA" - so, the
> developers of mailman (at least the one writing the faq) dont believe mailman is
> a MUA.


Besides, all good email clients honor the `List-Post' header, which is
there to specify where the replies to list should go to (if the user
desires so). Finally the user has three choices `Reply', `Reply All',
`Reply to List'. With Reply-To header munging the user has only two
options `Reply all' and `Reply to List'.

Though i believe the list members should decide what they are most
convenient with. Reply All is potentially dangerous option and i am
not in habit of using it.

Anurag

From devafree at yahoo.com  Mon Sep 25 15:58:06 2006
From: devafree at yahoo.com (deva free)
Date: Tue Sep 26 04:28:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Open Source Software for Call Center Units
In-Reply-To: <20060925162302.GA28491@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <20060925225806.88675.qmail@web50801.mail.yahoo.com>

Can u plz educate me on how to use it for less than 30 seats? That would do for me. Should I buy a PCI card with RJ11 ports on them? Where can I buy the hardware?
 
 -
 I think you are having a wrong idea on the physical networking and CTI. (computer -to -telephony integration). You just use a simple C class network at the minimum. Each agent will have either a hard phone or a soft phone, plus of course a computer. The computers will have one series of natted IPs. Each phone , say if it is soft will have the same IP as the computer naturally. If you need a hard phones for the agents, then you have to get a SIP device i.e, a VOIP gateway with FXS (foreign exchange stations) like an Audiocodes or a Linksys -T 2 port PAP, or a regular stand alone VOIP phone . This device will each have one IP, the multiple ports can be given one per agent. This port alone will be RJ-11. If using soft phones , no need for any RJ-11 at all anywhere. All the computers and the SIP devices go into the switch. Hope it is clearer now, I am sorry I missed the point the prev mail. The SIP devices as you would know are generally used to point at the SIP server of the
 far-end termination provider, who gives us thru our ISP, the service of converting IP packets into the PSTN abroad. Domestic BPO , the set up is more complex; the above is for international call center only, and we are going to point any sip devices at our Asterisk server.
 If you can read 'Asterisk - The future of Telephony - by Jared Smith ' its a great starting point and also great for experts too , as many have said too.
 Regards
 devafree

Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@gmail.com> wrote: On Mon, Sep 25, 2006 at 08:22:25AM -0700, deva free wrote:

Use ztdummy with zaptel as a timer and no need for a card. Also, use at least kernel version 2.6.5+ to avoid a bug in the ztdummy use that will give jitters in the voice.
>  Please do mail me if you encounter difficulties.
>  Plenty of guys are re-branding these as their solutions and they are very much in the market under various names.
>  Regards
>  Devafree

From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Tue Sep 26 18:43:21 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Tue Sep 26 18:47:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] which distribution will be good for dell inspirion E1505
In-Reply-To: <45192350.2010100@gmail.com>

	<45192350.2010100@gmail.com>

> 
> Try Ubuntu 6.06 LTS, Dapper Drake. Everything will work in a fly! If its 
> laptop, then one of the solution is "Dapper Drake" :D
> (Personal experience, I have a *designed for windows* Lenovo N100. Only 
> Ubtuntu Dapper Drake worked perfectly amongst the common GNU/Linux 
> distros :) )
> 

Ubuntu does work out of the box, but be sure to have both the "live" and 
the "alternate" ISOs handy.

There has been many a cases where the "live" CD installer has problems 
and crashes towards the end of installation process.

The "alternate" CD works like a charm though, and you have an option of 
choosing the classic Debian like text installer.

PS. avoid using your "corporate" mail id for mailing lists.

-- 
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

http://gopalarathnam.com/

From m_sathyz at yahoo.co.in  Wed Sep 27 01:51:43 2006
From: m_sathyz at yahoo.co.in (satheesh kumar)
Date: Tue Sep 26 23:21:49 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] software freedom day @ MIT - 16th sep 2006 - a report
Message-ID: <20060926175143.26366.qmail@web8909.mail.in.yahoo.com>


We conducted software freedom day in MIT in order
motivate students to get involved in open source
projects and as an free software awareness program on
sep 16th, 2006 at AU-KBC research center, MIT.



The function began by an introduction to open source
software by Mr.M.Satheesh Kumar. His speech is as
follows,

"Open source, roughly means the Linux, firebox,
contributed by nearly 5000 developers across 116
countries. What is open source? OSS is the software in
which the source code can be modified on the
requirement of users and developers. Government is
looking to cut costs associated with proprietary
packages to embrace open source. India's Communist
state Kerala has already logged out windows to avoid
monopoly in operating system and to promote Linux.



Application soft wares will never be free unless
otherwise there is free operating system. Though there
are a lot of Linux distributors Red hat, Suse etc.,
the desktop users still feel hard to use it. The most
famous Linux distributor "Ubuntu" (with the tag line
'Linux for human beings') solves this problem and
offers rich support to the users.



* As we have a lot of developers involved how the
standard of the software is maintained?  Most of the
operating systems like GNOME have its own set of
guidelines to be followed when we modify its source
code.



* What motivates developers contribute to open source?

(1) Developers see software as science knowledge to be
shared

(2) Somebody have the hobby of doing something that's
different

(3) Most of the operating systems have a log file
listing the contributors to code. Some developers find
it desirable to participate in operating systems to
signal their ability.



How open source is used in various domains. We
discussed most common open source soft wares in
networking, electronics and aeronautical.



(1)ELECTRONICS (by Mr.T.Sivabalan, ECE)



-gEDA is used in electronic design automation

-Robotics Darwin2k, is a simulation software

-TKGate

-XCircuit circuit designing



(2)MECHANICAL (by Mr.Kandasamy, Aero)



-VariCAD is similar to CAD, but we can edit at any
stage of drawing)

-flightTR is a flight simulation





(3)NETWORKING (by Mr.Savio Paul, ECE)



Most networking tools and Internet are using open
source, the various application of open source in this
context include,

-ENS, is a network simulation

-NFS (network file system), is used in the networking
of 2 UNIX computers

-tcp dump used for debugging network application and
setup, also for interception

-Wireshark

-Ethereal is similar to network monitor, for capturing
packets, sniffing unencrypted passwords, analyzing
protocols

-dsniff is a collection of tools for analyzing network

-Arpwatch

-snort, which is used for detecting network intrusion

-open SSH, which is open source version of secure
shell

-Samba, helps in the networking of Linux and windows
computers



Mr.Srinavasn, Project Scientist gave a short speech
about open source. He correlated a software with an
electronic circuit without knowing the internals of
the circuit we feel hard to use it or modify it
(imagine that we are given a simple black box saying
it be an amplifier). The free in free software doesn't
mean 'free' in price, it is the 'free' in freedom. The
open source projects are classified as code
development which involves developing the software,
testing in which most of the testing techniques are
used to test the soft wares and documentation for
documenting the operating systems. He wanted the
students to get involved in practicing scilab and
calculix for their experiments.



The function was concluded by a brief speech on
opportunities in open source. Hope this would be a
great motivation to the students to drive them into
open source.



Venue   :  AU-KBC research centre, MIT.

Date    :  Sep 16th, 2006

--
Satheesh Kumar M,
Computer  Society, MIT.

http://sg.movies.yahoo.com/
From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 00:00:40 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)
Date: Wed Sep 27 00:00:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Help needed-Fedora core4-adding service to Xinetd
In-Reply-To: <20060926145955.88550.qmail@web7707.mail.in.yahoo.com>
References: <20060926145955.88550.qmail@web7707.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310609261130n2456e2cw8dab2a7d09d2678c@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/26/06, tce tce <tcegrid@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
>   hi,
>
>           i am using fedora core4.I want to add an extra service called gsiftp.so i added the
> service file called gsiftp to /etc/xinetd.d and tried to start the service using
> /etc/xinetd.d/gsiftp reload it throws an error called gsiftp: unrecognized service.

It looks like you are confusing two totally different things.
1. xinetd is a super server that listens for connection on various
ports and based on the configuration files starts a particular service
when there is a request on a port.
2. /etc/init.d is the place where normally the startup scripts live.

Your script 'gsiftp' should probably go into /etc/init.d/ and you
should start it using /etc/init.d/gsiftp reload.

If the system hangs then you should inspect the offending script to
see what it does and probably enable some debug flags to get more
information.

--
Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/

From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 00:10:34 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)
Date: Wed Sep 27 00:10:48 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reiserfs RHEL
In-Reply-To: <20060926171712.GA11532@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20060926171712.GA11532@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310609261140m54380013hb8531d24890d02f6@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/26/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> I would like to format my /home dir with reiserfs filesystem, but unfortunately RHEL ES 4.0 version doesnot support reiserfs. how can i have support for the same ?
>
> heard that one doesnt need to recompile whole kernel since linux kernel v2.6.

You can probably compile it as a module or use a recent -mm tree which
comes with reiser4 support. You would also need the corresponding
userland tools to create and mange the file system. When I last looked
at it GRUB didn't have reiser4 support. You would be safe if your boot
partition is not formatted as reiser4.

--
Vijairaj
http://vijairaj.r.googlepages.com/

From chaks.yoper at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 08:16:46 2006
From: chaks.yoper at gmail.com (Chakkaradeep C C)
Date: Wed Sep 27 08:16:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Eric Raymond joins Freespire !
Message-ID: <a54a308e0609261946x6ce86f9dme421d3160f297107@mail.gmail.com>

*Open Source Guru Eric S. Raymond Joins Freespire Leadership Team*

*Urgency stressed as motive in joining Freespire's work to spread desktop
Linux to a broader audience *


*SAN DIEGO, September 27th, 2006 - *One of the co-founders of the
open-source movement has become the newest member of the Freespire
Leadership Board (http://www.freespire.org/leadership). Freespire (
http://www.freespire.org) is a community-driven, Linux-based operating
system that gives users the option of combining free open source software
with certain proprietary codecs, drivers and applications. Raymond,
well-known as both a theorist and an advocate for the open source movement,
joins twelve other Freespire Leadership Board members, composed of thinkers,
business people, evangelists, and key members of the Linux community.

In recent weeks, Raymond has surprised many by speaking publicly about the
"necessary compromise" that open source advocates must be willing to make,
by providing for an easy way for open source software to work with key
proprietary technologies for which there are not yet adequate open source
alternatives. Freespire is the most prominent desktop Linux distribution to
embrace this concept.

Mr. Raymond believes desktop Linux is entering into a critical period,
noting that historically, users have shifted operating systems during
periods of fundamental changes in hardware platforms. He believes the
movement to a 64-bit world will provide desktop Linux a unique window of
opportunity, which if missed, may not come along again for many years.

"Desktop Linux must advance now," said Raymond. "If desktop Linux is to
advance to a broader audience, it must work with iPods and other MP3
players, play DVD movies, view Windows Media and Quick Time content on the
web, and so on. I wish users didn't require these proprietary formats, but
it's naive and unrealistic to expect the masses to forgo these requirements
in the near future. Linux must make some compromises to attract mainstream
users."

Raymond believes the only way to influence ISVs and others to support open
standards and open software, is to attract enough end users to make Linux
too large to ignore. "There simply aren't enough Linux users today to put
much pressure on hardware and software manufacturers," added Raymond. "To
attract more users, Linux must support the popular drivers and file types in
use today. Freespire is the one distribution I see willing to make this
unfortunate but necessary compromise, so I'm happy to contribute to their
effort."

"We are extremely pleased to have someone with Eric's background, experience
and reputation involved in the Freespire project." said Kevin Carmony,
President and CEO for Linspire, Inc., the leading sponsor for Freespire.
"Eric has a keen interest in seeing desktop Linux become more workable with
the necessary codecs and drivers, and he sees Freespire as a good launching
off place for an ideal he and the Freespire community both share; getting
desktop Linux to just work, even if that means providing the option of
proprietary codecs in those cases where there are not yet viable open source
alternatives."

As a Freespire Board Leader, Raymond will help shape the direction of the
Freespire project, along with the other leadership board members, and those
from the Freespire community and technology boards. Raymond's participation
has already begun, including meetings in San Diego.

"Eric has already had a significant impact on our work," said Carmony. "Look
for some very exciting advancements, as a direct result of his active
participation."

*About Eric S. Raymond*

Co-founded and served as president of the Open Source
Initiative<http://www.opensource.org/>,
a 501(c)3 educational organization that builds bridges between the hacker
community and business with the aim of spreading the open-source development
method. A member of the Board of Directors of VA Linux
Systems<http://www.vasoftware.com/>(NASDAQ symbol LNUX), the leading
Linux hardware and systems company. One of
five Directors, who helped steer VA through its record-breaking IPO in
December 1999.

A principal researcher and author, Raymond often referred to as ESR, is the
author of "The Cathedral and the
Bazaar"<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Cathedral_and_the_Bazaar>and
the present maintainer of the "Jargon
File" <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jargon_File> (the printed version also
known as "The New Hacker's Dictionary"). Though the Jargon File established
his original reputation within hacker
culture<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hacker_culture>,
after 1997 <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997> he became a figure in the open
source movement <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source_movement>, and is
today one of its most recognized and controversial characters.

*About Linspire, Inc.*

Linspire, Inc. (www.linspire.com ) was founded in 2001 to bring choice into
the operating system market. The company's flagship product, the Linspire
operating system, is an affordable, easy-to-use Linux-based operating system
for home, school, and business users. Linspire pioneered CNR ("Click 'N
Run") Technology, which allows Linspire users access to thousands of
software programs, each of which can be downloaded and installed with just
one mouse click. The thousands of software titles available in the CNR
Warehouse (www.linspire.com/cnr <http:///>) include full office and
productivity suites, games, multimedia players, photo management software,
accounting tools, and more.

*About Freespire*

Freespire (http://www.freespire.org) is a community-driven, Linux-based
operating system that combines the best that free, open source software has
to offer (community driven, freely distributed, open source code, etc.), but
also provides users the choice of including proprietary codecs, drivers and
applications as they see fit. With Freespire, the choice is yours as to what
software is installed on your computer, with no limitations or restrictions
placed on that choice. How you choose to maximize the performance of your
computer is entirely up to you.

*About CNR ("Click 'N Run") *

CNR, with access to over 20,000 Linux software applications, makes it
extremely easy for non-technical users to install, uninstall, update and
manage Linux software on their desktop or laptop computers (
http://wiki.freespire.org/index.php/CNR_Warehouse). With the CNR Service you
can freely install thousands of Linux software titles direct from the CNR
Warehouse ( http://linspire.com/warehouse), all with just a single mouse
click. Users also get a powerful way to manage their entire software
library, with advanced features, such as customizable "aisles" where you can
install entire groups of software with a single click.

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:

> so in spite of the near unanimous request from the group (only one
> dissenter), and in spite of the fact that this is the only lug list in
> India without reply-to munging, it is not going to happen?

I don't think that munging "reply-to" header is requested unanimously. I
know several other people on the list who don't want "reply-to" header
munging (like me). They are in silent mode because they are tired of the
flame wars in the past on this topic.

I think that the user's freedom of selecting what should be done about
his reply should remain intact. Also the poster's choice of "reply-to"
field should be maintained and passed on. A lot of mail clients do have
the option of "Reply list". When given an option to deal with things in
the front-end level, why to have a workaround at the mail headers?

Thanks -
Praveen.

Praveen Kumar

This affects not only Debian, but all Debian based distros including Ubuntu.

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 09:55:13 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Wed Sep 27 09:58:05 2006
Subject: [Fwd: Re: [Ilugc] Re: reply to munging]
Message-ID: <4519FD29.6010205@gmail.com>

Praveen Kumar wrote:
> Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> 
>> so in spite of the near unanimous request from the group (only one
>> dissenter), and in spite of the fact that this is the only lug list in
>> India without reply-to munging, it is not going to happen?
> 
> I don't think that munging "reply-to" header is requested unanimously. I
> know several other people on the list who don't want "reply-to" header
> munging (like me). They are in silent mode because they are tired of the
> flame wars in the past on this topic.
> 
> I think that the user's freedom of selecting what should be done about
> his reply should remain intact. Also the poster's choice of "reply-to"
> field should be maintained and passed on. A lot of mail clients do have
> the option of "Reply list". When given an option to deal with things in
> the front-end level, why to have a workaround at the mail headers?
> 
Without any intention to renew this ever-continuing issue, I like just
to put my thoughts again.

If a person A joins Mailing List, then he is entitled to post to the
list. Anything he asks will be to the list and it goes to all the
members of the list. In return, the members post their replies to the
list, which goes to the person A and everyone in the list. I know this
is the normal procedure, but what I mean to point here is that the
intention of the mailing list is to share both your questions as well as
your ideas/replies with the community, i.e. the mailing list.

So, by default you are expected to send the mail to the mailing list.
But, sometimes you may need to go off the list and communicate
personally. When you are in personal communication, then it falls out of
the 'mailing list' activities and its your personal thing.

Hence, the mailing list should have 'send replies to the mailing list'
as the default practice, while a person wishing to mail someone
personally has to go off the list, i.e. it is his pain in the fingers to
type the email id of the person whom he wishes to mail personally.

Thus, 'reply-to' munging is to be implemented, to make sure all the
replies do come to the mailing list. Anyone wishing to go off the list
and mail people personally, still has the freedom to do so, without
affecting the default practice of mailing the mailing list.

P.S. Hope this doesn't add fuel to the quenching flames :D

Urgh, You knwo what happened ? I am actually sending (forwarding) this 
second time, this time to the Mailing List :D ;)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.

IRC: techno_freak @ #linux-india #ubuntu-in #python #django
Tech Blog: http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com

From binand at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 07:44:24 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Re: reply to munging

	<loom.20060924T160524-751@post.gmane.org>
	<4BF34F98-DFB3-4EB8-87B8-4C3B44A0FE09@thenilgiris.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251441510.23375@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<d2a92d610609250325t55155d0exf9778e2429170f5@mail.gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609251631360.25442@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<d2a92d610609250450v5d5c2f79m7b4837cff05c0c6b@mail.gmail.com>
	<loom.20060925T195127-781@post.gmane.org>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609262244x514ff08s96eedc870caf113@mail.gmail.com>

On 25/09/06, sriram <sriram@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@...> writes:
> > "Mail User Agents" (MUAs or UAs) are normally thought of as the
> > sources and targets of mail.
> >
> > In the case of ilugc, I send the email to ilugc <at> ae - the target -
> > which is mailman, and the emails I get have envelop sender set to
> > ilugc-bounces <at> ae - the source - which is also mailman.
>
> envelop sender has nothing to do with the source of the mail; the envelop sender
> is defined as the address to which bounce messages should be sent. this is how
> rfc 2821 says it in 2.3.1 "The SMTP envelope is sent as a series of SMTP
> protocol units (described in section 3).  It consists of an originator address
> (to which error reports should be directed) ... "

The way I read that, you are differentiating between "source" and "originator".

> now for target, we can stretch your argument to make an MTA into an MUA. in many
> mail readers, one can configure how outgoing mail is to be handled. in
> particular, one can specify an MTA to which mail should be handed over. does
> this make the MTA a target of the mail, then?

MTAs are never the target of any email; MTAs do just that 'T' part of
it - transportation of the email.

> established that an MTA is an MUA since it is the target of the mail. if no,
> then mailing list managers will fall under this category, since it does exactly
> what an MTA does in this instance - receives the mail as a temporary target and

Temporary or not, you are confirming what I said - that the MLM is the target.

> then transmits it on to the ultimate target(s). in this sense, a mailing list
> manager is never a source or target of the mail. a mailing list subscriber is
> the source of the mail and all mailing list subscribers are the targets of the
> mail. mailing list managers like mailman are only relay agents and relay is a
> role generally associated with MTA's not MUA's.

This is where we disagree. MLMs do not relay emails. They accept
delivery of emails, process the emails (unlike "normal" MUAs, they
don't display the email on a screen, but they still are the recipients
of the email and hence an MUA), and re-inject a NEW email message into
the queue, with different envelop sender/recipient addresses.

> we are using mailman for the list. here is a quote from the mailman faq. "The
> Mailman developers strongly agree with Chip and Marc, and strongly disagree with
> Simon" - chip and marc argue that munging reply-to headers is bad while simon
> argues that munging reply-to headers is good. the same faq also states that
> "Fundamentally, this problem really should be solved in the MUA" - so, the
> developers of mailman (at least the one writing the faq) dont believe mailman is
> a MUA.

Ultimately, it doesn't matter what anyone else thinks - each list
ought to be capable of taking this decision on its own; and in the
case of ilugc, the vast majority of subscribers seem to favour the
addition of Reply-To to the list. Protocol and RFC arguments
notwithstanding, I really don't see why the list itself isn't
configured as per the wishes of its subscribers.

Binand
From prem at songbirdtech.com  Wed Sep 27 11:35:28 2006

lists which works this way.

Is there a definite advantage in NOT using the "reply-to" header for the
mailing list? If not, I think there is a case for going with the popular
*voiced* opinion on this mailing list in favour of change. As for those
unwilling to voice their opinion ... well, you know how it works in a
democracy...

On Wed, 27 Sep 2006, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> Ultimately, it doesn't matter what anyone else thinks - each list
> ought to be capable of taking this decision on its own; and in the
> case of ilugc, the vast majority of subscribers seem to favour the
> addition of Reply-To to the list. 

i am afraid your 'vast majority' consists of less than 20 subscribers out
of the approx 1500 that are subscribed to this list. i made an open call
in the list to express a preference and less than 20 people have asked for
reply to munging to be turned on (and an even smaller number have asked 
that reply to munging not be done). pedantically, reply to munging should 
not be done. practically, reply to munging may be more useful. since so 
few subscribers are expressing a preference, i will go with pedantics over 
practicality.

-- 
sriram

the first 50 years of independance making huge losses and keeping our  
country down. I personaly feel that the inactive majority should not  
be allowed to dictate to the active minority. Imagine listening to  
people who cant be bothered to vote. One suggestion, why dont you  
poll those 1500 people and ask them this question: 'all those who  
want reply-to munging not to be implemented, please reply, failing  
which it will be turned on'. Would you be willing to abide by the  
decision of the silent majority then?

On 27/09/06, Prof. P. Sriram <sriram@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> few subscribers are expressing a preference, i will go with pedantics over
> practicality.

Without any offense meant, spoken like a true academic :)

I think your thinking is akin to reasoning that "even though the
opposition candidate won, since the turnout was 35%, we will declare
the incumbent as the victor as he/she is more qualified to hold the
post".

I could suggest a couple of things:

1. Slightly more formal referendum-type voting for the list's
collective majority view. I'm not sure if mailman can do that, but I
think other MLM software can handle polling (Yahoo groups  has the
poll feature). It could be a feature available as a plugin or
something to mailman. This has to be done in a way that each
subscriber gets to vote only once.

2. Since October 1st is around the corner, we could do a one-month
trial of "Reply-To set to list" during October, and revert/continue as
per discussions/feedback on the list during the month on 31/10. This
might be preferable since most list members are not stepping forward
to express their opinions.

Binand

	<27CFB953-E911-49F6-BA0B-E12647048106@thenilgiris.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0609271254190.13489@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610609270041x1effcc53m80f09e88f1ad50f6@mail.gmail.com>

On 27/09/06, Prof. P. Sriram <sriram@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> fine with me. i was going to suggest a poll in any case and i am not
> particular about how it is worded. i dont have polling ready to go on this
> server (or any of the servers i have ready accees to), but we do have it
> on our chennailug.org site, i think (?). if anyone on the list sets up the
> poll and returns the results to me, i will abide by it. we should agree on
> a minimum voter turnout - say, 5% (that would be 72 as of now). so, go on,
> set the poll and tell me what to do.

The problem with third-party hosted polls without access to the
subscriber database (without a well-defined voters' list, that is) is
that they are so easy to manipulate. Remember all those desktop-linux
polls which were allegedly manipulated by overzealous Ubuntu users? A
poll on this particular issue should:

- Have only one vote per list subscriber. First-cast vote counts.
- Only allow subscribers who are active (a thumb rule like at least
one post in the last six months) to vote.
- Not allow disciplined subscribers (people put on moderation etc. for
various reasons) to vote

Binand

Prof. P. Sriram wrote:
> On Wed, 27 Sep 2006, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
>> Ultimately, it doesn't matter what anyone else thinks - each list
>> ought to be capable of taking this decision on its own; and in the
>> case of ilugc, the vast majority of subscribers seem to favour the
>> addition of Reply-To to the list. 
> 
> i am afraid your 'vast majority' consists of less than 20 subscribers out
> of the approx 1500 that are subscribed to this list. i made an open call
> in the list to express a preference and less than 20 people have asked for
> reply to munging to be turned on (and an even smaller number have asked 
> that reply to munging not be done). pedantically, reply to munging should 
> not be done. practically, reply to munging may be more useful. since so 
> few subscribers are expressing a preference, i will go with pedantics over 
> practicality.
> 
IMHO, the active part of the mailing list should be considered rather 
than considering the total mass. If an analysis is made over the mailing 
list, around 30-40 people might be posting per month in the mailing list 
and the even in that 10-15 might be the ones who are pretty much active 
and post everyday at least a mail (am on the border of this category), 
even though there are 1500 people who have registered with the list. 
When a practical issue is being considered, such as reply-to munging, 
where the practical problem is faced by *routine* participants of the 
mailing list, considering the totally inactive and non participating 
mass of the mailing list is not welcomed. The rest 1400 (taking the 
count to be around 100, as usual participants) have no contribution to 
the mailing list other than making the numbers to 1500. The 
mere-onlookers are *not* affected by the problem faced (not having 
reply-to munging) by a majority of the participants and especially a 
majority of the active participants.

So, saying "*only* 20 people out of 1500 in the mailing list is asking 
for reply-to munging" is not appropriate. It is *20* people out of the 
normally active/participating 20-30 people of the mailing list, whose 
interaction with the mailing list will be further improved if their 
request is satisfied. Else, the sailing continues as usual, with a bit 
of pain in the fingers.. ;)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan.S.R.

IRC: techno_freak @ #linux-india #ubuntu-in #python #django
Tech Blog: http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com
NRCFOSS HelpLine: http://nrcfosshelpline.in

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 14:41:51 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Sep 27 14:42:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reiserfs RHEL
In-Reply-To: <20060927082721.GA16711@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20060926171712.GA11532@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<7c6561690609262136s5d3be0f9u499e45b5e6cb2f32@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060927082721.GA16711@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <20060927091151.GA28100@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Sep 27, 2006 at 01:57:21PM +0530, km wrote:
> After compiling the kernel module, do i need to recompile mkfs ? to add support for reiserfs?

No need. If the kernel supports the file system mount automatically invokes the right file system routines reading the superblock magic.

I think your reqmt is not at all complicated. 

Just run these commands and you are done. Provided you have reiserfs support built into the kernel.

Figure out the device on which you wish to mount /home. Say /dev/hda2

Now, run this. You need reiserfstools package. 

#mkreiserfs /dev/hda2

#mount /dev/hda2 /home

#mount

Now, if you are able to see this line, you are done.
/dev/hda2 on /home  type reiserfs (rw)


After that, just add this line to your /etc/fstab file.
/dev/hda2       /home        reiserfs    rw,auto         0       1

This ensures that everytime you reboot the /dev/hda2 is mounted as /home partition.

You need to RTFM mount to know more, but this shud work.

I have attached my sample run for your reference. HTH.

(But don't do my way, I was just testing :-)

Best,
Girish

# dd if=/dev/zero of=reiser count=100024 bs=1024
100024+0 records in
100024+0 records out
102424576 bytes transferred in 7.271094 seconds (14086543 bytes/sec)

# losetup /dev/loop1 reiser 
# mkreiserfs /dev/loop1
mkreiserfs 3.6.19 (2003 www.namesys.com)

A pair of credits:
Edward Shushkin wrote the encryption and compression  file plugins,  and the V3
journal relocation code.

Vladimir Demidov wrote the parser for sys_reiser4(), the V3 alpha port, part of
the V3  journal  relocation code,  and helped  Hans keep  the business  side of
things running.


Guessing about desired format.. Kernel 2.6.17.3 is running.
Format 3.6 with standard journal
Count of blocks on the device: 24992
Number of blocks consumed by mkreiserfs formatting process: 8212
Blocksize: 4096
Hash function used to sort names: "r5"
Journal Size 8193 blocks (first block 18)
Journal Max transaction length 1024
inode generation number: 0
UUID: 12e7c933-fdcd-4710-a42b-175b15d932a4
ATTENTION: YOU SHOULD REBOOT AFTER FDISK!
ALL DATA WILL BE LOST ON '/dev/loop1'!
Continue (y/n):y
Initializing journal - 0%....20%....40%....60%....80%....100%
Syncing..ok

Tell your friends to use a kernel based on 2.4.18 or later, and especially not a
kernel based on 2.4.9, when you use reiserFS. Have fun.

ReiserFS is successfully created on /dev/loop1.

# mount /dev/loop1 /scratch/

#mount
/dev/hda2 on / type ext3 (rw,errors=remount-ro)
proc on /proc type proc (rw)
sysfs on /sys type sysfs (rw)
devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,gid=5,mode=620)
tmpfs on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw)
usbfs on /proc/bus/usb type usbfs (rw)
/dev/hda4 on /storage type ext3 (rw,noexec,nosuid,nodev)
/dev/hda1 on /mnt type ntfs (ro,uid=1000)
tmpfs on /dev type tmpfs (rw,size=10M,mode=0755)
localhost:/var/lib/cfs/.cfsfs on /var/cfs type nfs (rw,port=3049,intr,nfsvers=2,addr=127.0.0.1)
/dev/sda on /usb type vfat (rw)
/dev/loop1 on /scratch type reiserfs (rw)

On 27/09/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> Hi,
> > i don't know why u want to format ur system as reiserfs. u might have
> > ur own reasons for that.
>
> We require reiserfs on the /home partition as it holds millions of smallfiles less than 0.5 Mb in size; and reiserfs is supposed to be good at performance if one has large number of smallfiles.

This is the kind of evaluation errors that cost people their jobs. If
you knew you had a requirement for reiserfs, whatever on earth made
you choose a distribution (paying money for support) that didn't have
reiserfs support?

Alternatively, did you ask your Redhat support guy which filesystem
that they support would be ideal for your requirement?

IIRC, using a custom-built kernel would make your support contract
with Redhat null and void - all those $$$ will be wasted.

Lastly, "supposed to be good at performance" is another way people
lose their jobs by doing scratchy product evaluation. Have you tested
it the performance yourself? Does it play nicely with all the other
device drivers you need?

Binand

>    i would say that reiserfs is a ultimate failure ....... and not much
>    prefered by most of the modern distribution
>    only suse seems to stick on with that ...

I am in no mood to start off a flame war, but would say that this is a
strong statement to make. No filesystem's success can be measured by
the number of distros which use it. For quite some time I have been
using reiserfs (now reiser4) and I am content. It's more a issue of
what the use case is, and the environment in which you want to deploy
the filesystem.

Ramkumar.

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 19:19:29 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Wed Sep 27 19:19:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reiserfs RHEL
In-Reply-To: <20060927082721.GA16711@mrna.tn.nic.in>
References: <20060926171712.GA11532@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<7c6561690609262136s5d3be0f9u499e45b5e6cb2f32@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060927082721.GA16711@mrna.tn.nic.in>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560609270649p23f5dce4lc6bbcf82eb801661@mail.gmail.com>

On 9/27/06, km <km@mrna.tn.nic.in> wrote:
> We require reiserfs on the /home partition as it holds millions of smallfiles less than 0.5 Mb in size; and reiserfs is supposed to be good at performance if one has large number of smallfiles.

The most annoying limitation with ext2/3, that is not in reiser,
is that you don't need to specify the max number of inodes during
fs creation.  Reiser is also more forgiving towards fs blocksize
settings.  You don't need to tweak knobs in reiser to produce
acceptable performance for almost all kinds of workloads.

For that matter, Solaris' ZFS looks most promising.

- Raja

	<loom.20060925T195127-781@post.gmane.org>
	<d2a92d610609262244x514ff08s96eedc870caf113@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0609271234260.13489@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>

On Wed, 27 Sep 2006, Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:

(before i argue, i have to caution you that even proponents of 'reply-to 
munging is good' may have to admit that it is not pedantically correct but 
practically more elegant.)

> The way I read that, you are differentiating between "source" and
> "originator".

i am not. that is not my argument at all. please read the rfc very
carefully. trying to argue envelope sender is source of mail is a lost
argument - you have to try something else. the ONLY purpose of the
envelope sender is to provide an address to which bounce messages should
be sent (has been so in good old rfc 821 too). that is what the rfc says.  
it says nothing about where the mail is coming from or where it goes. it
is equivalent to the 'if undelivered, return to' that is used in snail
mail. it may be the same as the sender but it may not be. it is perfectly
within all rfc's to have mail from fred@foo.com carry ginger@bar.org as
the envelope sender - presumably because ginger knows what to do with the
bounce message better than fred. you are arguing that in this case, ginger
is the source of the mail (and not fred) because thats the name on the
envelope sender. except for having the word 'sender' within it, the 
envelope sender may have nothing to do with who is sending the mail.

the only thing this means is that you cant use envelope sender to
associate a source relationship - you have to try something else like
where is the mail actually coming from etc.

> Temporary or not, you are confirming what I said - that the MLM is the
> target.

and in which case you have just stated that an MTA is an MUA (because it 
is a temporary target of mail that may be sent to it for relaying) and 
anything that is the target of a mail is an MUA.
 
> This is where we disagree.

[etc etc]

MLMs are MLMs. they do some things like an MUA and some things like an
MTA. thats why they are called MLM and not MTA or MUA. and thats why we
will never agree on whether an MLM is an MUA or an MTA.

> MLMs do not relay emails. They accept delivery of emails, process the
> emails (unlike "normal" MUAs, they don't display the email on a screen,
> but they still are the recipients of the email and hence an MUA), and
> re-inject a NEW email message into the queue, with different envelop
> sender/recipient addresses.

how 'NEW' is the injected mail? how much of it is verbatim what was 
received by the MLM? envelop sender is a lost argument as above - it 
has nothing to do with sender or receiver of mail. what about when an MTA 
does alias processing? or a primitve 'MLM' that is set up using aliases in 
the MTA? the MTA becomes an MLM. of course, one can do this type of 
aliasing in an MUA too and make an MUA into a primitve MLM. so an MUA or 
an MTA can both play the role of an MLM (to a limited extent). what does 
that prove?

-- 
sriram

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 20:52:23 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (R.Ramkumar)
Date: Wed Sep 27 20:52:32 2006
Subject: Reiser4 stability (Was: Re: [Ilugc] reiserfs RHEL)
In-Reply-To: <9a9bfc170609270820u625e642ey215347cac5151060@mail.gmail.com>
References: <9a9bfc170609270820u625e642ey215347cac5151060@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170609270822j3bef230cj24ffc9bd216903bd@mail.gmail.com>

> Just out of curiosity, do you find reiser4 stable?

Stable enough for me... but mine is a single-user laptop, and once in
a while (not frequent though) my comp crashes (I have no problems with
that :) ) as I use the latest in the beyond kernel patchset.... I
can't blame it on Reiser4 though... No big time corruptions till date
(I do periodically mirror to an external hdd though)... The free disk
space reported sometimes behave funnily when you have very less free
space (Dunno if this is a bug, though)... Only drawback for me is that
unionfs doesn't work with reiser4... I have to be content with a
slower unionfs-fuse...

> Reiser4 is not into the main kernel line yet.

Hopefully soon... by 2.6.20 (http://kerneltrap.org/node/7153)

> Also would GRUB complain if my /boot was reiser4?

Yes, you would need a patch to grub (unless support has recently been
added). But if you don't want to do (like me), make a small root
partition in something else (I use reiserfs) and make the other
partitions reiser4. (I don't like fragmenting my hdd so much... I end
up wasting space and doing unnecessary copying... So I have a single
partition with all the top level directories (home, opt, srv, usr,
var), mount it at something like /mnt/idata, and bind mount individual
directories to the top level directories)

it moves on...

From prashmohan at gmail.com  Wed Sep 27 22:30:03 2006

Balachandran Sivakumar wrote:
> ReiserFS get detected by other OS like the open solaris etc.

OpenSolaris does not detect ReiserFS. However FreeBSD >=6.0 makes
resierfs accessible. And there is a reiserfs driver for Windows too.

P.S all this is for reiserfs 3.6 not 4.0

- --
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Sep 28 07:13:40 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Sep 28 07:13:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Sharing /home
In-Reply-To: <1159360451.5205.5.camel@tuxbox>
References: <1159360451.5205.5.camel@tuxbox>
Message-ID: <20060928014340.GA29185@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Sep 27, 2006 at 06:04:11PM +0530, Sudharshan S wrote:
> Hi everyone,
> Just wondering is it ok to share /home partition between linux and the
> bsd family in the same harddisk?..I have shared /home between distros
> without any problems...

I guess you may have to compile both kernels with support for each other, i.e, either ext3 and ufs or whatever. If u r comfy with that,then it can be done. But normally these days I dont get in a multiboot situation, I find it a PITA.

Actually the kernels mostly support these file systems by default but sometimes it doesnt work.

It is a good idea however. You can most definitely share swap as well.

But with low disk prices these days I would go in for a file server kind of thing instead.

Best,
Girish

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Sep 27 19:46:59 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Sep 28 08:17:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Doubts in Kernel Compilation.
In-Reply-To: <451A7CC4.7080701@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <20060928024659.50878.qmail@web50203.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Sivaram Kannan <sivaramsk@midascomm.com> wrote:
> I think 
> i386 is for intel machines.

Yes.

> Still I tried booting the compiled image, but the
> system is not booting 
> up. I am getting only a blank screen.

Can you boot into single user mode and get a console
prompt?

You can edit grub on the fly. Highlight your OS entry
when grub loads and press 'e'. 

Move to the /kernel line and press <enter>, and add
"single" in the end of the line.

Press 'b' to boot this new configuration and you will
get a console prompt. If yes, then your kernel is
booting fine in run-level 1.

Now, check if you can move to run-level 3

  init 3

This will give you six consoles (Control+Alt+Fx,
1<=x<=6). If yes, then the only problem is with your
display driver and/or X configuration.

You can change your default run-level to 3 in
/etc/inittab file :

  id:3:initdefault:

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com
